story:
Short Summary

Hello!  My name is Julia Frith, I am a Hollywood born Bermudian Baha'i, a lover of the ocean - and pizza, a snuggler of small animals and babies, an aerialist, firebreather, freediver, Bermuda's first professional Mermaid, and a motivated performing artist ready to embark on my newest adventure:  Drama School.
MY PROJECT

"Match Me If You Can" is a comedy expose on the life and trials of a conscious performing artist. 

  As a swan song, before I leave, I have created a presentation on the power of the performing arts, its greatness, its pitfalls, its ability to shred a person... (If their aims are set in the wrong place), and its ability to be a platform for awakening and transformation.

If you can't be there in person, but still wish to contribute to my artistic endeavors here's where you can give a little love! Help me raise $5,000 through this Indiegogo campaign, whether you give $1 or $5,000 it doesn't matter, every bit counts!  And if you're in Bermuda, come see my show! 

Check out my website for more info: http://juliafrith19.wix.com/matchmeifyoucan

WHY I'M DOING IT

I have been accepted into one of London's top international Performing Arts Conservatoires, and through  generous scholarships from the Bermuda Arts Council and BMDS, I can almost afford the tuition.... but not quite. This is why I have developed a dynamic, comical fundraiser to give you the opportunity to see why I am worth the investment.
This campaign is an opportunity for you, dear friends, who are not able to come to my show, to show your support in my efforts to raise money for tuition fees! 


WHY YOU'RE IMPORTANT

With this extra money, I will be able to pay  for this year's tuition without taking out student loans, while also being able to pay for housing and travel between Bermuda and the UK. Not only are you contributing to my academic future, you are ensuring that I have a chance to make a change in the world and raise awareness through the arts, you are empowering me to empower others, and you're choosing to be a part of an awesome community - EARTH without ART is just Eh. 


THE COST BREAKDOWN

  • The BFA Acting course I have been accepted into at Rose Bruford College costs £9,000. That's exactly $13,985.10 when you convert it to USD.
  • Housing costs add up to £6,930, which is exactly $10,768.53.
  • Travel fees between Bermuda and the UK are approximately $1,200 roundtrip. Making three trips throughout the year will cost approximately $3,600.
Total costs for the academic year will come to about $28,500
  • I have already received a $10,000 scholarship from the Bermuda Arts Council and $5,000 from the Bermuda Musical & Dramatic Society.
  • I have saved approximately $4,000 this summer from working as a barista, babysitter, and fire performer for Rockfire Productions.
Total money raised: $19,000
  • This means I have $8,500 left to raise through my AWESOME SHOW FROM VIEWERS LIKE YOU!

Help me raise $5,000 through this Indiegogo campaign - and if you're in Bermuda, come see my show!

Travel fees between Bermuda and the UK are approximately $1,200 roundtrip. Making three trips throughout the year will cost approximately $3,600.

This means I have $8,500 left to raise through my AWESOME SHOW FROM VIEWERS LIKE YOU!
Help me raise $5,000 through this Indiegogo campaign - and if you're in Bermuda, come see my show!

story:
Los Angeles is home to the greatest concentration of Indigenous Peoples in the United States, but most Americans might not know that. Los Angeles Indigenous youth leaders now have an opportunity this July to meet with administration officials at the White House in Washington, DC, to discuss the local, state and national issues that indigenous communities struggle with to this day. President Barack Obama has convened native youth from all corners of the country to meet and discuss issues of critical concern to Indigenous Peoples on July 9, 2015.  This experience will empower Indigenous youth to serve as future heads of state, diplomats, entrepreneurs, divergent agents of social change and cultural elders generating an active voice for all Indigenous Peoples in Los Angeles, to guide our next seven generations. Los Angeles Indigenous youth will assume international leadership roles that can profoundly impact the lives of Indigenous Peoples worldwide.

Anahuacalmecac Indigenous youth have met with local and international leaders addressing issue sof concern to Indigenous Peoples

Help send urban native youth to the first ever White House Tribal Youth Gathering in Washington, D.C.

President Barack Obama has convened native youth from all corners of the country to meet and discuss issues of critical concern to Indigenous Peoples on July 9, 2015. The White House Tribal Youth Gathering is the first of its kind and four student leaders from Anahuacalmecac International University Preparatory, the only Indigenous Peoples' autonomous charter school in Los Angeles County have been invited to attend this historic gathering. Through our school's guiding philosophy that our children and youth are our Semillas del Pueblo or Seeds of the People, Anahuacalmecac engages youth in an intergenerational mission thorugh which our youth approach all meetings with community leaders, tribal heads of state and sovereign nations. 

About Anahuacalmecac International University Preparatory

Thirteen years ago, Semillas del Pueblo was board in El Sereno Park. Today,

Anahuacalmecac International University Preparatory (AIUP) advances the education of Indigenous youth in the urban innner city that is home to the largest concentration of Native Peoples outside of Mexico City through a harmonious regeneration of community, culture and consciousness as Indigenous Peoples. Our school emerged from the hearts of mothers, fathers, and teachers who took that first step thirteen years ago who organized a resistance to English-only laws in the State of California in effect to this day that prohibit maternal language education. Anahuacalmecac was born in forgotten barrios, in abandoned buildings, in neglected city parks, in dumpsters made libraries, in overcrowded schools, beneath compassionate trees, below ancient hills, blanketed by the thunder and rains of a southern California sky.  Vision, passion and commitment are requirements of the resilience and relentlessness cultivated in our students. The honor of being a xinaxtli or a 'seed of the people" in Anahuacalmecac require dedication and dreaming. 

Anahuacalmecac students and teachers recently led a delegation to Zuni Pueblo

AIUP is authorized by the State Board of Education of California for grades K-12. AIUP educates youth through native maternal language, cultural curriculum and a college preparatory inquiry-based International Baccalaureate continuum. AIUP is the City of Los Angeles' first public IB World School and WASC accredited. AIUP graduates college ready Native youth at higher percentages that surrounding comprehensive high schools.

What We Need & What You Get

With your support, Anahuacalmecac can raise $5,000 to  help send our four Indigenous students and one Indigenous teacher chaperon travel to the first-ever White House Tribal Youth Gathering in Washington, DC. In DC, our delegation will need housing and transportation around town to visit a couple of key sites in DC including a scheduled meeting with their U.S. Representative and the National Museum of the American Indian. The White House Tribal Youth Gather was convened to provide Indigenous youth from across the country the opportunity to interact directly with senior Administration officials and the White House Council on Native American Affairs.

All funds raised through this campaign will go to cover costs for airfare, overnight stay, meals and educational trips to museums.
COSTS INCLUDE:
  • BUDGET HOTEL: $400
  • ECONOMY AIRFARE: $3,300
  • MEALS & INCIDENTALS: $750
  • TRANSPORTATION & ENTRANCE FEES: $500

YOUR DONATION WILL BE MUCH APPRECIATED. In consideration of your donations Anahuacalmecac will offer:
    • Semillas del Pueblo Insignia Patches
    • Anahuacalmecac School Seal Tshirt
    • Pictures of youth at Gathering
    • Tour of the Anahuacalmecac (subject to schedule and availability)
    • A special meeting with the youth delegation upon return to Los Angeles either in person or via Skype
    • Formal dinner and discussion with youth delegates in Los Angeles

Funds raised over our goal will be applied to additional Indigenous youth delegation expenses across the continent.

The Impact

Through your support, you can contribute in a small way to help native youth overcome centuries of injustice through self-affirming community based organizing. Your support will help promote the continuity of indigenous peoples' languages, cultures  and knowledge as important testimonies to our shared humanity.

"The reason I want to go to the gathering in Washington DC  is to make a difference by understanding the issues first, than being able to inform others of these different issues. I think it's important to help solve the problems that native youth face today. The reason why I can make a difference is because I've attended a school that led a community struggle to stay open when LAUSD did not want to renew our charter.  We all found a way to overcome the issues and I can now help solve other issues."

                                                           - Nicole F. (AIUP Indigenous Youth Delegate)



"Hello my name is Nora and I am interested in attending the first annual Tribal Youth Conference for various reasons. I have always been aware of my Indigenous roots. I am Zapoteca. This knowledge builds my character and defines who I am. It's intriguing to know that there will be over 1,000 students at the Tribal Youth Gathering who I will get to know and relate to. Being able to discuss the issues native youth face-to-face and sharing our customs even if only briefly will be something exciting for me. Coming back I hope to be able to share this experience with my family and community. Thank you."

To date, youth delegates from Anahuacalmecac have participated in the following international gatherings across the continent:

United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues at the UN HQ in New York City


Pomona College Intertribal Youth Gatherings


UCLA American Indian Student Bridge and MUN programs

Wishtoyo Chumash Cultural Center 


7th Generation Fund for Indigenous Peoples Keeping the Homefires Burning Gatherings


Global Indigenous Youth Caucus in New York City and on-line


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help financially here's what you CAN do:

  • Take the IGEN Challenge yourself
  • Learn more about the Semillas del Pueblo Indigenous Youth Delegation Campaign
  • Sign up for our newsletter here
  • Connect to Anahuacalmecac via our social media pages

          www.facebook.com/semillascommunityschools

          www.twitter.com/semillasschools

          www.instagram.com/semillascommunityschools

          www.dignidad.org

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools

story:
‘Dream&Child’ Drawing Bags
image source:saveourchildreninnepal.com
Name of founder/director: Sol Yi Nam      Contact: dreamandchild@gmail.com

α. Project location: Nepal

Four sections:

a. Work plan and activities

b. Background and justification

c. Objectives and expected results

d. Help/Sponsor opportunities a.

a. WORKPLAN AND ACTIVITIES

‘Dream&Child’’s project is designed to provide unique opportunities for underprivileged children through providing drawing opportunities that enable them to express themselves as a great method of communication, especially for those who are un-confident/uncomfortable with doing so through verbal means of communication in the given situation. It is a way for them to express their thoughts, feelings and minds, which stimulates positive psychological effects.

Donors (those who participate in the projects/purchase the bags) seeing the drawings on the bags will strengthen their interest and awareness of child issues in Nepal (as visual images can add synapses to neurotransmitters, meaning the memories of helping children by purchasing the bag and writing positive, hopeful messages to the children are embedded in their mind).




1. Visit local schools/places where children can express their mind and hopes by providing them with energetic drawing activities including sketching, colouring and painting.

2. Children will be provided and assisted with drawing tools and guidance and will be free to draw anything in regard to topics including ‘dreams, hopes & love’.

3. Such drawings will be coated on a cotton/waterproof hand bag with a ‘Dream&Child’ logo on it. Each bag will have a specific message indicated in the drawing.

4. ‘Dream&Child’ bags will be advertised and sold to people who are interested in helping the children in Nepal. People can write a message/letter to the children about the drawings/in general which will be sent to them directly. Further long-term sponsorship with children can be given.

5. Funds raised from the sale will be donated to the charities in Nepal Planned activities Estimated duration Finding sponsors for the project 2-3 weeks + Preparing travel and drawing sessions 3-7 days Meeting with children at school and charities 3-7 days in Nepal Marketing and selling products Continuous β.

PROJECT BUDGET

Amount required to start: minimum £1000+

£200 (train, accommodation and food during the travel)

£650 Cheapest flight fee

min £200 Material fee for each bag. E.g. £200 for 100 bags to be made 2/bag Sale

Price £5-10 per bag

Profit per bag £3-8 per bag

First round of target amount of donation (aimed at selling 100 bags): £300+

b. BACKGROUND AND JUSTIFICATION

'Dream&Child' is a nonprofit project that gathers happy drawings from underprivileged children of all ages in Nepal. Bags with drawings of children will be sold to increase awareness of the issue and to raise funds, which will be donated to children helping them with basic education, health service and living requirements (food and clothes).

Project Beneficiaries of the project The Nepal Labour Force Survey (NLFS) 2008 estimates the child population between 5 and 17 years of age to be 7.77 million (33% of the total population); and the largest share of Nepal’s child population (38.3%) is in the 5‐9 year age group, followed by the 10‐13 year age group (33.8 per cent) and the 14‐17 year age group (27.9 per cent)* . These groups are expected to benefit from ‘Dream&Child’ project. The problem or critical issue which the proposal seeks to resolve is the poverty of most families, The Nepal Earthquake (on 25th of April 2014) and corrupted political society and economical instability has stolen children’'s lives and hopes. For example, domestic labour, street children, children in armed conflict and sex workers who are exposed to the risk of HIV/AIDS. Other facts to be noted: o Child marriage (%) 2002-2012 married by 15-18, 50.8%** o Attendance in early childhood education 2005-2012, 30.1%** Basic health care (physical and mental illness), education and provision of shelter needs urgent help.

There is a serious need for awareness creation and disciplinary action in an innovative, proactive and structured manner, which is what this project is all about.

This proposal relates to the national strategies and policies of children rights. ‘Since the early 1990s the issue of child rights and child labor has received greater attention which is being reflected in national policies and programs. Because of the social and economic circumstances of the country, child labor issue in Nepal are rather difficult and complex. About 90% of the population in Nepal lives in rural areas; and about 42% f Nepalese live under the absolute poverty line, with income less than one dollar per day.***’ g.

c. OBJECTVIES AND EXPECTED RESULTS

Unintended challenges such as lack of interest in the products will be addressed through extensive marketing at my university and other universities/schools/charities/organisations who are willing to help. Main objectives:

1) To raise interest and awareness of the issue by spreading ‘Dream&Child’ bags as the idea would consciously/unconsciously come into peoples mind every time they use and see them.

2) To encourage people to get involved in a creative way. For example, giving the buyer of bag the chance to write a short letter/message to the child that made the drawing.

3) To sponsor underprivileged children with the money raised from the product sales.

4) To contribute to improving the development of living standard for the children and the community. I will be responsible for preparing periodic project progress reports; leader ship of the organisation project and report s of project monitoring will be made to ensure planned procedures and actions are carried out in line with the aimed objectives.

d. HELP/SPONSOR OPPORTUNITIES

I need help with:

a. Finding a sponsor with the start up cost of the project

b. Connecting with charities/schools (any places children drawing activities can be held) in Nepal

c. Finding people who are interested in participating in the project (globally, starting in the UK)

d. Identifying organisations that can provide bag materials. e. Organisations/schools/universities where ‘Dream&Child’ bags can be advertised.

Your donation

Thank you for giving hopes&dreams to children in Nepal!

Any donation will be greatly appreciated.

Once you have made a donation, you can write a message to the children in Nepal which will be delivered by 'Dream&Child' project.

story:
Our Mission

Project Lift aims to rehabilitate traumatized children through therapeutic and expressive art workshops. With creativity, we hope to break the cycle of trauma and violence, and prevent it from reoccurring in future generations.


Our Vision

We envision a brighter future for children in which they can express themselves freely, think creatively, and reach their greatest potential.


About Us

Founded in 2014 by 16 year old Emir Özsüer, Project Lift is a non-profit organization consisting of trained mental health professionals and a dedicated organizational team. We help children who have experienced traumatic life events through art workshops and creative expression while offering them a safe and therapeutic environment. We offer five day workshops to a maximum of sixty children at one time to ensure the quality of our services and individual attention for each child. We create opportunities for these children to express themselves in hopes that they will begin to heal and cope with their burdens, and work towards a brighter future. 

We are currently focusing on Syrian refugee children due to the Syrian Crisis, however, we eventually hope to reach all children of misfortune around the world.


Break it down 

What is childhood trauma and what can be done about it?


What your help will mean for Project Lift

About 65% of the money raised goes towards therapeutic services. 15% of the money raised is used for administrative and organizational aspects of the project. 17% is spent on art and creative supplies, including gifts for the children who attend our workshops. This way, when they go home, they can continue to be curious and creative! And the final 3% is used to pay for transportation - we want to make sure our children arrive and depart safely from our workshops.

With your $10 donation, one child can take home their very own art kit.
With your $25 donation, one child can attend one day of our workshop. 
With your $125 donation, one child can attend the full five day workshop. 
With your $600 donation, every child in our workshop can take home an art kit. 

Help us reach our goal of $24,300 to help us organize our next three workshops. 
We thank you for your support!



Other Ways You Can Help!

Along with helping these children, Project Lift also seeks to increase awareness and encourage individuals to take an active role in social responsibility efforts.

Here are even more ways you can help support us and the children we work with:

  • Spread the word about our campaign to friends, family, and loved ones!
  • Think of ways you can promote Project Lift within your own community, and then contact us with your ideas :)
  • Visit the following for even more:
    http://project-lift.net/default_en.html
    https://www.facebook.com/projectlift.tr
    https://instagram.com/project_lift/

story:
Who We Are                          

Playing to Live! is an organization that brings art, play and yoga therapy to children affected by trauma. Evidence-based research shows that child-centered, creative art therapy techniques greatly improve a child's ability to express and understand complex emotions resulting from trauma. Children can lack the words to communicate their feelings and Playing To Live! gives them a voice. We empower local community members by collaborating with them to create culturally relevant therapy techniques and trainings.  We also partner with numerous local NGOs to ensure sustainability of our programming. While we work towards becoming our own non-profit, we are accepting charitable donations through our fiscal sponsor, the 501c3 Ahali Elephants. Playing to Live! is in its first year of existence and has already experienced incredible growth and recognition in Liberia, where the program was born. Our vision is to continue to expand and bring the healing arts to more children worldwide. 

When PTL! began in Liberia, we responded to a crisis situation. Alexis Decosimo, our Founder and Executive Director, asked Jessi Hanson, our Co-Founder and Director of our Liberian program, to fly to Liberia during the height of Ebola to help build an essential program to identify the mental health needs of children experiencing the trauma of Ebola. The Playing to Live! clinical team was created and built our program quickly in order to respond to the urgent need of the children in Liberia. We partnered with the non-profit Ahali Elephants in order to accept charitable donations, and we partnered with a Liberian NGO Renewed Energy Serving Humanity (RESH) to help us recruit and train local caregivers in art, play and yoga therapy techniques. RESH is also responsible for on the ground oversight of the caregivers and the Playing To Live! programming.  These techniques were then brought to the children living in isolation centers after experiencing the loss of their family members to Ebola. 
We have had incredible success in Liberia, and we will be growing thanks to a generous grant from UNICEF through our Liberian partner Renewed Energy Serving Humanity (RESH). In the next 6 months, we will be be training 40 female Ebola survivors to implement our program, 40 Liberian social workers to support the program, and access 800 children who are identified for being the most highly affected from the trauma of Ebola. 
Our program has thrived in Liberia and we would like to bring this same program to the homeless children of South Africa! The Playing to Live! Liberia program was only possible because of your generous support- we need your help to make this happen in South Africa! 

  • The success of our program has been featured in several publications:                                                                                    

Expanding Towards a Global Initiative

In less than a year we have grown from an idea to an organization serving hundreds of children and providing effective and lasting skills to local caregivers. As Playing to Live! matures we want to build a strong and effective global response program. This requires intensive and diverse fieldwork and evaluation. 

Meet Alexis! 

               


Since the beginning of Playing to Live!, Alexis has utilized her current doctoral work at ETSU in the field of public health to help build Playing to Live!'s capacity, evidence based protocol, and sustainability. Alexis is currently in South Africa for 10 weeks (June 1-August 13), where she is combining her required doctoral internship with the chance to expand PTL with a partnership with a local organization called Tshwane Leadership Foundation. The partnership between Tshwane Leadership Foundation (TLF) and Playing to Live! came together thanks to a connection through some members of OPSSA . During this 10 weeks Playing to Live! will provide programming and training  to TLF for support in a winter program for homeless youth as well as expansion to a year log program. 

Alexis's goals during this 10 weeks are: 

 ·  Train TLF staff in the PTL training

 ·  Build assessments for the training to evaluate the trainee’s understanding

·  Continue to build the training program based off of the assessments

·  Support the trainees to implement our expressive therapy program for 80  homeless youth in South Africa in TLF’s winter (July) program

·  Build assessments to evaluate the children’s and trainee’s response to the programming

·  Hold focus groups to record feedback from the implemented program from children, implementers, and community

·  Build the evidence based practice by building the connection to literature

·  Write journals for publications based off of evaluations and research

·  Connect with local expressive therapists and build connections for future work

·  Advocate for expressive therapies in South Africa and globally by reporting our results and progress through social media, blogging, and publications

·  Build a sustainable year long program for TLF


Meet Kate!

 

Kate received her Master's Degree in Art Therapy and is currently a Board Certified, Licensed Creative Art Therapist. She is also a yoga teacher! She currently works in Washington DC at a hospital supporting children with life threatening diseases and chronic medical issues. Kate grew up abroad and enjoys international aid work, which is what brought her to volunteer at Playing To Live! The last 2 weeks of the programming will involve intensive development towards a year long program at TLF. As the PTL! Fundraising and Marketing Director Kate, will be joining Alexis in South Africa to provide support and expertise.

Kate's goals are: 

·  Participate in post-program focus groups to record feedback from program participants- the children, the trained caregivers, NGO partners and local community members.

·  Formally review the program assessments and participant evaluations gathered by PTL! and TLF staff

·  Collect qualitative evidence of program benefits from child participants and trainees, including photographs, video and personal accounts

·  Formulate the next steps in the partnership between PTL! and TLF, including our programming goals for 2015 and 2016.

·  Establish relationships with local expressive therapists to build connections for future partnerships and support

·  Connect with local leaders of locally-based nonprofits as well as international NGOs that provide psycho-social support to children in South Africa to explore partnerships and funding opportunities

·  Meet with members of the American Embassy in South Africa to ensure continued support of our programming

·  Advocating for the PTL! program throughout the trip via social media to share our program progress 

It will take about 10 weeks to piloting the program in South Africa and we can't do it without your help!  While our local South African partners will be supporting our efforts on the ground, we will need funding to cover our plane tickets, housing, transportation, food and other essential items for the duration of the project so that we can meet our goals. 

As in Liberia, we are not working alone. We have partnered with the following South African NGOs: Tshwane Leadership Foundation, Lerato House, and the Organization for Pediatric Support in South Africa (OPSSA). These partners will help us recruit caregivers for the trainings, provide space for the children to receive care and continue to oversee the program into the future.  

  • This program is immensely important to Playing To Live! because if we succeed organizations such as UNICEF will support the South Africa program just as they have done in Liberia. 
  • You hold the key to making this pilot program happen. We know we can do this, but we need your support!
  • Join those who are already supporting our work!

                      

     

What We Need & What You Get

  • Airfare: $1275.  Alexis' roundtrip airfare from the US to Johannesburg was generously provided by a scholarship from ETSU.  Kate's roundtrip airfare to Johannesburg from the US is $1275. 
  • Housing: $2200.  We will be renting an apartment in Pretoria during our stay. The apartment is $200 per week, per person. Alexis we will be there for ten weeks. Kate will be renting for the final two weeks. 
  • Transportation in country: $540. Petrol and transportation is expensive in South Africa, and we have opportunities to travel to many places to expand our work. We can only do as much as we are funded to do. 
  • Food: $765. We won't be splurging at fancy restaurants and we plan to eat as the locals do so we are budgeting about $85 per week. 
  • Communication/Internet: $225. We plan to stay connected to all our supporters (that's you!) as well as our partners on the ground. To do this we will need to spend about $25 per week. 
  • Work supplies/Art materials/ Research capabilities/ extra costs: $1700. TLF is generous in providing us with some art supplies and staff, but there are going to be many extra costs, including work supplies. Alexis is planning to write research and present on our findings and work in South Africa, so we can expand our academic reach and development of global expressive arts therapy. Though in order to do so there will be many costs beyond this fundraiser, this budget will allow for time and supplies to get this part off the ground. This budget will also allow for chances to travel in country to make essential connections and advocate for expressive arts therapy. 
  • Travel Insurance: $200
  • International Health Insurance: $200

  • Donation Perks! The great thing about supporting art therapists is that we love making and sharing our artwork! As a perk for donating we offer several levels of artful rewards. Perks range from surprise postcards to silly animal prints to commissioned paintings! Our Gold and Platinum Level supporters will be proudly listed on our website as Key Contributors. Please check out our perks page for more info! 

               

  • We know we will reach our goal with your help, but in case we don't all of the funds we are able to raised will still go to directly support Alexis & Kate's travel and program expenses.

The Impact

This is your chance to make a difference in the lives of children and caregivers! Your contribution will directly impact the lives of homeless South African children and help support the local economy. Your donation makes it possible to build a sustainable and effective program that is unique to this region. 

  • This pilot program will bring some of the most effective methods of working with children to the most vulnerable children in the world. 
  • We know this pilot project will succeed because we have the track record to prove it! In Liberia, just six months ago, we piloted the Playing To Live! program with 2 caregivers and 80 children. We were so successful that UNICEF awarded us a six month grant to expand our program. This month we will begin to train 70 caregivers, many Ebola survivors, to provide creative art therapy techniques to 800 children! Our goal is to reach every child who was orphaned by Ebola in Liberia by the end of this year.  Due to our success in Liberia we are confident that the pilot program in South Africa will follow the same path. 
  • Your support will allow us to train 20 caregivers to provide creative art therapy techniques to 80 children, ranging in age from 6-18. Not only will your donation directly impact the children, but because we employ the caregivers once they complete the training your donation will also help support and build the local economy.  

Risks & Challenges

Like any new project, there are always obstacles to overcome. While we succeeded in Liberia, we understand that South Africa is a different country with its own challenges.  We will be working for the first time with many of our South African partners and we plan to carefully evaluate these partnership to ensure sustainability. 

  • We have witnessed the essential role our Liberia partners played in helping us navigate the waters of starting our program and we are confident that our South African partnerships will be equally helpful.
  • Our South Africa partners will provide us with on the ground support, knowledge of how local systems work as well as the cultural norms, expectations and practices- making the program more likely to succeed. 
  • The US embassy in South Africa has also reached out to aid in our efforts and is an enthusiastic supporter of our organization's expansion into the region.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways that you can help support Playing To Live! and we welcome all of them!

  • Help us get the word out! Share our campaign with everyone you know and encourage them to donate!
  • Like us on Facebook! 
  • Follow us on Twitter!
  • Throw a donation party!
  • Contact us to donate a special skill (blogging, artwork, etc!)
  • If you are a Creative Art Therapist and would like to contribute to our Activity Database we are always looking for engaging and creative ideas!  
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!

Thank you so much for you support!

story:
Our Foundation

The SAME Foundation is a non-profit organisation which raises funds and manages corporate social investment allocations to improve the health and education environment in South Africa. The SAME Foundation has created a platform whereby private and corporate donors can make a tangible and sustainable difference with their funds. The Hospitals and Schools we work with rely solely on government financing and are utilised by over 85% of our country’s population, and are therefore under severe strain. Our aim is to assist donors by aligning their annual donation budgets to projects where the investment will make the biggest tangible impact. The SAME Foundation takes all the research work and hassle out of finding worthy projects and facilitates the entire process from identifying the need to the grand opening or unveiling of the completed project. We focus our effort on facilities in poverty-stricken communities where there is no short/medium term governmental budget for improvements. This means that, without intervention by you and the SAME Foundation, these communities won’t be able to receive the healthcare and education that they deserve. Not only does this ultimately save lives and educate children, but it allows the staff to do their jobs efficiently in an environment that enhances their morale. Patient and student comfort is essential to our outcome on each project, this is ensured by supplying each of our partner facilities with all the necessary equipment, furniture and stationary required to operate effectively. While our main focus is on improving the state of our countries health and educational facilities, we also realise that our donors deserve recognition for their involvement in the transformations we perform. We reward all donations with a section 18A donation receipt and BEE letter of thanks making the donations Tax deductible and allows the donor to claim full BEE points under the SED category. We also facilitate on site donor recognition through different branding options and also arrange media PR.

The money raised will be used to renovate/build and equip schools in poor underprivileged areas around South Africa. This will ensure that these children get access to quality education and daily meals are provided. The model is currently being used with great success and we need more capital to expand our reach and assist more children.


Manzomthombo Senior Secondary School Background

Manzomthombo Senior Secondary School is situated in Khayelitsha, South Africa. This is a predominantly Xhosa speaking community of which about 54% are unemployed. The community has a population of about 1 500 000 people of which approximately 85% of them live in informal settlements. Manzomthombo is a typical township school - born out of a previously disadvantaged community, poor infrastructure setup (RDP structure), poorly trained educators and learners from a society riddled with social ills yet, against all odds, Manzomthombo Senior Secondary school rises above all in striving for quality and excellence, as stated in its motto. This is evident from the continued excellent academic performance across all grades. This school strives to offer quality teaching and learning to the High school learner population which currently stands at 1588 pupils.


This is the CURRENT CONDITION of the Manzomthombo Senior School in the informal settlement of Khayelitsha, South Africa:

With your help we can give the teachers at Manzomthombo Senior School an environment conducive to providing these children with a quality education. Our Foundation turns these run down schools into state of the art learning institutions with the assistance of donor funds as seen in the pictures below of previously completed projects.

THE TRANSFORMATION: Only possible with your donations.


School Revitalization Project Overview

Phase One:

The first phase of the project includes, but is not limited to the following:

  1. Science and Maths laboratory
    1. Completely renovate, upgrade and secure the room.
    2. Fully equip the classroom for science and maths according to the curriculum.
    3. Included is comprehensive training and monitoring of teachers.
    4. Quarterly reports will be made available to monitor the progress of the learners.
  2. Library
    1. Refurbish the library.
    2. Stock the library with appropriate books for the age groups.
  3. Computer Centre
    1. Establish a room big enough for at least 50 computers.
    2. Fully equip and network the room.
    3. Provide software as requested by the school.
    4. Ensure that the teachers are trained to use and manage the facility.
  4. Bathrooms
    1. Refurbish and upgrade (hygiene) a block of male and female learners’ bathrooms.
  5. Learner and facility safety
    1. Install a security system with beams, sirens and spot lights.
    2. The security system will include 24 hour armed response.
    3. Monthly fee after initial installation has been agreed to be taken over by the school and has been allocated to their budget.
  6. Classrooms
    1. Refurbish and upgrade classrooms with the SAME Foundation blueprint of custom-made auditorium-style seating, with a seven year guarantee.
    2. Classrooms are equipped with the latest Smartboard teaching technology with curriculum-aligned software. This package includes teacher training.
    3. 50 desks per class: Custom-made solid-core Formica top desks custom made with steel encasing, with polypropylene flip-up chairs (Most indestructible resources currently available).
    4. Fully equip classrooms as per the school’s needs and equipment wish-list.


Costing Summary (Phase One)

·  Library (with seating, carpets, desks, computers, TV, DVD, Books) – R200 000

·  Computer Centre:  R500 000                     ($45 500)

·  Science Laboratory:  R350 000                  ($31 800)

·  Bathroom:  R70 000 each                             ($6 400)

·  Ad-hoc Repairs and Painting:  R80 000   ($7 300)

·  Security System:  R45 000                           ($4 000)

·  Ten Classrooms – Smartboard Technology:  R150 000 each        ($13 600)

Total: R3 000 000 estimated.                         ($280 000)

*Costing is subject to change and dependent on availability of suppliers. Costing includes all furnishings from top to bottom to create a world-class learning environment up to SAME Foundation standards.


Phase Two and beyond (long-term)

Once the priority needs of phase one are met, the Foundation will move onto phase two and continue to work with and complete the whole-school revitalization model. Manzomthombo is our flagship education project in the Western Cape. The classroom design follows the SAME Foundation blueprint. They are auditorium-style fitted with solid-core Formica desktops set in steel with poly-propylene gravity flip-up seating and includes the latest interactive Smartboard technology with CAPS aligned software. Each classroom will be a state-of-the-art learning centre. The package includes comprehensive teacher training.

Throughout 2015 and beyond The Foundation will continuing to work with management of the school to ensure that the resources are used to full potential and complete the rooms in phases. A future objective of the Foundation is to make use of existing land on the school’s property to provide the school with a sports field where they can participate in sports such as soccer and athletics.

This continuous work allows for us to address needs that arise with the management and maintenance of the project on an on-going basis, as well as create a sustainable impact going forward. The timeline of these projects are dependent on the rate at which the income (donations) are received to complete the work.

Help us Help these children now by making an once off easy donation!!!!

We thank you in advance for your generosity :)
story_txt:
Our FoundationThe SAME Foundation is a non-profit organisation which raises funds and manages corporate social investment allocations to improve the health and education environment in South Africa. The SAME Foundation has created a platform whereby private and corporate donors can make a tangible and sustainable difference with their funds. The Hospitals and Schools we work with rely solely on government financing and are utilised by over 85% of our country’s population, and are therefore under severe strain. Our aim is to assist donors by aligning their annual donation budgets to projects where the investment will make the biggest tangible impact. The SAME Foundation takes all the research work and hassle out of finding worthy projects and facilitates the entire process from identifying the need to the grand opening or unveiling of the completed project. We focus our effort on facilities in poverty-stricken communities where there is no short/medium term governmental budget for improvements. This means that, without intervention by you and the SAME Foundation, these communities won’t be able to receive the healthcare and education that they deserve. Not only does this ultimately save lives and educate children, but it allows the staff to do their jobs efficiently in an environment that enhances their morale. Patient and student comfort is essential to our outcome on each project, this is ensured by supplying each of our partner facilities with all the necessary equipment, furniture and stationary required to operate effectively. While our main focus is on improving the state of our countries health and educational facilities, we also realise that our donors deserve recognition for their involvement in the transformations we perform. We reward all donations with a section 18A donation receipt and BEE letter of thanks making the donations Tax deductible and allows the donor to claim full BEE points under the SED category. We also facilitate on site donor recognition through different branding options and also arrange media PR.The money raised will be used to renovate/build and equip schools in poor underprivileged areas around South Africa. This will ensure that these children get access to quality education and daily meals are provided. The model is currently being used with great success and we need more capital to expand our reach and assist more children.Manzomthombo Senior Secondary School BackgroundManzomthombo Senior Secondary School is situated in Khayelitsha, South Africa. This is a predominantly Xhosa speaking community of which about 54% are unemployed. The community has a population of about 1 500 000 people of which approximately 85% of them live in informal settlements. Manzomthombo is a typical township school - born out of a previously disadvantaged community, poor infrastructure setup (RDP structure), poorly trained educators and learners from a society riddled with social ills yet, against all odds, Manzomthombo Senior Secondary school rises above all in striving for quality and excellence, as stated in its motto. This is evident from the continued excellent academic performance across all grades. This school strives to offer quality teaching and learning to the High school learner population which currently stands at 1588 pupils.This is the CURRENT CONDITION of the Manzomthombo Senior School in the informal settlement of Khayelitsha, South Africa:With your help we can give the teachers at Manzomthombo Senior School an environment conducive to providing these children with a quality education. Our Foundation turns these run down schools into state of the art learning institutions with the assistance of donor funds as seen in the pictures below of previously completed projects.THE TRANSFORMATION: Only possible with your donations.School Revitalization Project OverviewPhase One: The
first phase of the project includes, but is not limited to the following:

story:
Fund for Nepal Relief and Development

The recent earthquake in Nepal has devastated many communities, including homes, schools, businesses, temples, and important cultural heritage sites. The students of the class "Global Issues in Travel and Tourism" at the University of Southern Maine understand that the needs will be great in both the short and long term, and would like to contribute what they can. 

Through this site they are raising funds from family members, friends and classmates to donate to several well-established emergency and community development funds serving Nepal, including the Sir Edmund Hillary Foundation, the Seva Foundation, and other certified aid organizations selected by the students after the funds have been raised.

Students in this class have learned about the scope and impacts of global tourism, and looked specifically at Nepal and the role of the tourism industry there. They feel a special responsibility to support the people of Nepal as they rebuild their communities and economy following this natural disaster. The loss of another climbing season on Everest, destruction of trekking routes and tourism infrastructure, and the loss of irreplaceable World Heritage Sites will mean a devastating impact on the tourism industry, and the communities it supports, for years to come. This is of course on top of the human tragedy of loss of life and property, and of the medical, food and other needs at this time.

In a larger sense, the students in this class and in the Program in Tourism and Hospitality at USM believe in supporting communities around the world as they strive to achieve economic and environmental sustainability, whether or not this includes tourism. They would like to show their support for the people of Nepal and surrounding regions as they seek to recover from this latest disaster, and offer their support and encouragement in this time of great need.

Use of Funds

Students have set a goal of $1000, which will be donated to one or more funds that the students select after careful research on their financial management and their support of the goals of disaster recovery, community development and environmental protection in Nepal. Whatever amount is raised by the deadline will be immediately transferred to one or more such funds as selected by the students.

Perks for Donors

There are no material rewards for contributing to this fund, but know that you have the appreciation of students in this class, and the people in Nepal who will be helped by your generosity.

story:
What we are about

Our names are David and Dani. David is a software engineer and law student. Dani is an Innovation, Design & Technology teacher at a local Independent school. We own Techielab - a community based incubator that makes cutting edge technology accessible, inspiring, positive and creative for young people. We do this by offering after school and holiday camp programmes that teach Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Mathematics. 

We have a dream to make 3D printed prosthetics affordable as well as a participative process for children and adults.

We have set out to develop, design and 3D print affordable prosthetic hands. Lara and enablingthefuture.org have been inspirations and a starting point for us. Lara's E-nable hand as well as all the E-nable hands we have printed have been warmly donated to children.

Funds raised on this campaign will go towards finalising a new design already on the drawing board. A design that mimics the functionality and dexterity of a human hand inspired by Biomimicry - or imitating biology!  Our ThinkTank is led by adults and children. Our next stage looks at bringing together ideas and designs in Biomedical and Materials Engineering, introducing electronics to create a hand that also takes human factors into account.

So here is the gist: We have examined many designs for 3D printed hands, each with their contribution toward mimicking a real hand... Yet, our team has developed a wish list of other functionalities and innovations we would like to include. Our new design (still at its initial stages) augments the current designs, looking not only at its mechanics but also at its control. Now that we have printed quite a few purely mechanical hands, we wish to add electronics, explore 3D printed conductive components and develop new materials to interface between the skin and 3D printed parts. Ultimately, we want to produce a hand controlled by thought alone, providing the ability to control each finger and each angle of movement, allowing for greater precision and dexterity- and one that does not involve surgical intervention.

Your contribution will help us print hands for those who need them. It will allow us to try out our innovations in collaboration with the children that will be using them and bring together groups of children and adults who want to be part of researching and developing solutions. Be part of our journey! 

What We Need & What You Get

What do we need?  Well, firstly, we need to buy different types of 3D printers. Ours seem to be working 24 hours a day!  We want to determine the optimal balance between cost, speed, functionality and material. We want to put together events for children in schools and teach them about 3D printing as well as product development, biomimicry and the mechanics of how our hands work! We need to consult with specialists, try new materials, develop new concepts and implement new technologies. In addition we intend to create and share lesson plans about what we are learning and doing with many students and teachers. 

What do you get, you ask? You get the opportunity to help this amazing group of children and adults take existing technology up a notch! You get to help a child do the tasks we take for granted. Oh yes... We also have a whole range of perks for you as well! Just check them out. 

New Designs

Our R&D has just discovered even more ways to make the prosthetics mimic the human hand... using all printable components keeping the cost low. Our design is now being prototyped and will be printed within the next week. Keep an eye out here for updates. 

The Impact

The impact of your contribution will be life changing! Look at Lara and so many other children who have received a 3D printed hand? Knowing you have given someone the ability to pick up an apple, brush their hair, or use a knife and fork is priceless! Simple tasks we all take for granted...

We are excited about the prospects of the many offshoots that could come about from this project… not least a journey that allows for children to have an "Aha!" moment in their lives. It is vital to do what we can to inspire a generation of future inventors, scientists and engineers. 

Read about our efforts in the media: http://www.kentonline.co.uk/tonbridge/news/3d-hand-built-by-classmates-38932/

And our mention on Channel 5 national news: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uKjNStsRetI 

Risks & Challenges

Our main challenge is funding! It truly takes a village to create something amazing… We will need collaborators in areas where we require additional expertise. We need the machinery and the raw materials to attain the next stage of development. R&D is key!

Other Ways You Can Help

Talk about the project to your friends colleagues, family. Share it on social media. Get the word out there about what we are doing and why. Lets make a big noise, and make prosthetics affordable and accessible to everyone. As Lara says, "We want to change our OWN world." Together we can make it happen!

Thanks for giving a hand!

story:
Overview

The vulnerable childhood and youth in Colombia is in great need of opportunities for education in the arts and the values that can foster and enhance a successful path towards peace, a better economy, and a better quality of life. The Foundation Constructores de Patria has designed a comprehensive program that aims to empower children and adolescents through education in music, sports, plastic arts, languages and environmental issues combined with coaching in the core principles and values of a healthy and peaceful society—such as tolerance, solidarity and respect—. The pilot program of this initiative was launched 10 months ago and it benefits a group of children and adolescents from the public schools in the township of Rozo, in the region of Valle del Cauca, Colombia.


What exactly is the program about?


The program beneficiaries can choose from courses in five main areas: music, sports, languages, plastic arts & crafts, and environmental education. Each class is two and half hours long and takes place on a weekly basis. The five areas of study are:

  • Music: Violin & Violoncello.


The music area is under the direction of Jaime Cifuentes y Aura Judith Martinez, founders of ARCOS - Suzuki school of violin & violoncello (certified by the Suzuki Association of the Americas). ARCOS has been involved in previous educational programs for children from vulnerable populations (In the photo below: Juan Manuel Santos, President of Colombia, takes a photo with Jaime and his students). 


  • Languages: English



  • Sports: Tennis (on clay court)


  • Plastic Arts & crafts: painting, sculpture, woodcarving, among others.


  • Environmental education: topics will include sustainable farming, recycling, production and transformation of agricultural products and nutritious organic products


Additionally, beneficiaries will receive continuous coaching in 10 values and principles, as follows:

·  Discipline

·  Healthy self-esteem

·  Honesty

·  Integrity

·  Justice

·  Love & Friendship

·  Perseverance

·  Respect

·  Solidarity

·  Tolerance


Where will the classes take place?

The courses will take place on the country house Granja El Sembrador, a beautiful installation in the heart of the region with access to sports facilities, open auditorium, bathrooms/showers, and all the activities involved in farming.



What is the expected impact of this program in the social and economic development of the community?

By facilitating access to education in the arts, sports, and environmental, social and humanitarian awareness we are without doubt helping to reduce the high rates of social vulnerability that deny children and adolescents the possibility to have better opportunities in their life projects.

On the long term, the Foundation Constructores de Patria will enhance the offer of courses and create partnerships with specialized institutions that will allow students to continue their education as they grow up. The implementation and sustainability of this program depends greatly on your support!


What have you done so far?

The Foundation Constructores the Patria launched this program 10 months ago and since then has achieved:

·  Development of the educational program, with the advice of a humanities professor from the ICESI University.

·  Approval of the project from the municipal authorities and the school directors.

·  Meeting with the potential students and their families to present the project.

·  Selection of the teachers for the courses.

·  Auditions for the violin and violoncello classes.


·  Auditions for the tennis classes.

·  First pilot classes before summer vacations of the schools.


·  Fundraising and presentation events.

What will the money be invested in?

The Foundation Constructores the Patria and the children involved in the program greatly appreciate your donations and support (like sharing this project with friends, family and colleagues!)

The donations from this campaign will be directed towards:

·  The salaries of 5 professional teachers for each academic area

  • Musical instruments—16 violins and four violoncellos—
  • Art supplies and educational materials
  • Operational and logistic expenses

This is beautiful and exciting! How can I help?

Thank you in advance for your interest, support and feedback in this project to give children from a vulnerable community in Colombia an opportunity to build a better future for them and their community.

You can support us by making donations through this campaign, every donation counts! Wait there is more: you can also support us by sharing in your social circles this project, telling our story to others so that we can get as much donations as possible before the deadline of the campaing!

We understand that not everybody can make a donation but, hey, money isn’t everything! Our children would love to hear your words of support, your ideas and encouragement. Also, if you want to send supplies our way (notebooks, pens, pencils, colors, clothe, etc) they are very welcome! Please contact us for details.


Thank you for your time!

Have a great day, full of blessings and love.

and presentation events.

What will the money be invested in?
The Foundation Constructores the
Patria and the children involved in the program greatly appreciate your
donations and support (like sharing this project with friends, family and
colleagues!)
The donations from this campaign will be directed towards:
· 
The salaries of 5 professional teachers for each academic area

Musical instruments—16 violins and four violoncellos—
Art supplies and educational materials
Operational and logistic expenses


This is beautiful and exciting! How
can I help?
Thank you in advance for your interest, support and feedback in this
project to give children from a vulnerable community in Colombia an opportunity
to build a better future for them and their community.
You can support us by making donations through this campaign, every
donation counts! Wait there is more: you can also support us by sharing in your
social circles this project, telling our story to others so that we can get as
much donations as possible before the deadline of the campaing!
We understand that not everybody can make a donation but, hey, money
isn’t everything! Our children would love to hear your words of support, your
ideas and encouragement. Also, if you want to send supplies our way (notebooks,
pens, pencils, colors, clothe, etc) they are very welcome! Please contact us
for details.

Thank you for
your time!
Have a great
day, full of blessings and love.

story:
This past May, we took a dream of my daughter's and mine and made it a reality: a festival that was designed for kids and families to come together and play in a safe environment, to camp out and connect, to learn circus skills together and share in a family festival adventure. We had great media coverage and excellent feedback from parents, circus skills school, music workshops for kids, interactive art and international talent...but it put me in deep personal debt. Now families who attended or want to attend in the future are asking when the next kids themed event is taking place....but before I can plan the next, I need to clear up outstanding fees from this event. 

$3500 gets us in the clear and able to go forward to the future of family festivals....on Vancouver Island and beyond.

Your donations make sure this beautiful plan to make this an annual (or more often if interest and financial backing is there) festival with ongoing local events for our kids and families come to fruition, so we can celebrate together, build the skills and confidence levels of our children and connect as a community.

Here is what was offered at the last PLAY! Festival:

*Interactive Art 
*Jedi Ninja Training
+Circus Playshops and workshops all weekend for kids AND parents
-Aerial silks and aerial hoops
-Flow arts and Fire Dancing
-Live bands & electronic music
- Circus Toy Creation workshops 
- Kids Trade & Exchange (bring what you love to make or trade what you no longer love)
-Costume Corner 
-Foam sword battles and live action role playing
-Acrobalance and acrobatics
-Bboy & Bgirl breakdancing 
* Vendors Village

Help us bring this event into the future.

story:
They had so little before the fire. 

On May 11, 2015, a fire swept through the neighborhood of Cockle Bay in Freetown, Sierra Leone. It destroyed everything in its path. Nobody was killed, but now 80 children are destitute, surviving thanks to the generosity of a man named Joseph Lamin.

  • I am a friend of Joseph's, having stayed at his guest house in Cockle Bay in the summer of 2010 and 2011 while volunteering in the country. 
  • On his 53rd birthday five years ago, My friend Cherie and my daughter and I attended the party he threw for the children in his neighborhood. He said the greatest gift he could have is to see the children eat a huge meal, laugh and play for an afternoon. 
  • Now he is feeding these children every day as their parents try to rebuild their homes. 
  • They need basics such as toothbrushes and clothing and sandals. They need vitamins and food. They need uniforms so they can go back to school in the fall.

Will you help these children? They've lost everything.

Cockle Bay children at Joseph Lamin's birthday party in 2010. They wore their best clothes to honor him.


What We Need & What You Get

  • If we can raise $100 per child, it will go a long way towards helping them survive the next six months of the rainy season. 
  • Every cent raised will go to Joseph to feed and clothe these kids.


The Impact

Life in Cockle Bay was already unspeakably difficult. The homes are made of scraps of tin with no running water or electricity. Ebola devastated the city, sowing fear and disfunction for more than two years. Just as schools reopened for the children, this fire took everything.

  • These children have nobody else to turn to. The government is unable to help the families rebuild their homes. There is no daycare or safe place for the children to go. There are not even nearby parks or beaches for them to safely play.
  • $100 goes a long ways in Sierra Leone and will help stabilize life for these kids while the neighborhood is rebuilt.
  • Schools for Salone will wire all the funds from this campaign directly to Joseph Lamin. I served on the board of Schools for Salone from 2011-2014. 
  • This non-profit, non-denominational organization, created by Peace Corps Volunteers and based in Seattle, has successfully built 16 schools and two libraries in the country over 10 years. 

This is the Cockle Bay neighborhood before the fire. I took this photo in 2010.

People tried to fight it but it was impossible.


This is the neighborhood today, June 2015.

The ruins of a home. What will this mother do for her child?


Who is this man? An entrepreneur turned humanitarian.

  •  Joseph Lamin owns the Cockle Bay Guesthouse in Freetown, a compound of eight or so apartments that are rented out to guests traveling in Sierra Leone. He and his organization, Programme for Children, also partner with Schools for Salone, overseeing construction and financing of each of the schools built by the organization. 

    He was born the youngest in  a large family in Sierra Leone. He says he learned very early to fend for himself or he wouldn’t get anything to eat. This taught him resilience and how to recognize good opportunities. 

    He got his start in business as a young man by purchasing a videotape cassette player and taking it around to different villages and screening tapes for a few leones. This money eventually allowed him to purchase a car. He then convinced one of his brothers to let him take his plastic barrels of palm oil to sell, using his car to get a better price for them than his brother could get in his home village. Joseph was very successful at this.

    And so Joseph took the money from the palm oil and bought a second car, fixing it up and selling it for a profit. This led him to buy two more cars, and he sold those and bought four cars. This went on for some time, buying two cars for every one car he sold. Eventually, he bought some property in Freetown and went into business with a local real estate company, learning the way the market worked.

    When war came in the 1990s he emigrated from the country with great reluctance and guilt. While living in England, he earned a masters degree in business. During his dissertation work, he read about American companies that invest part of their profits back into their communities, and when Joseph returned to Sierra Leone after the war ended, he did the same. 

    Though he has a wife and four children living still in England, Joseph chose to come back to Freetown to build live in one of the capitol's poorest areas, a shanty town neighborhood where there are no roads and where people live in rotting tin sheds with mud floors. When his guest house became profitable nearly 10 years ago, he took the proceeds and started a neighborhood charity, now called Programme for Children, which finances the school fees for local children and helps their parents out of destitution. 


Heart of gold.

  • On the last day of my stay in Sierra Leone, Joseph invited my teaching colleague Cherie Eulau and my 20-year-old daughter to attend his birthday party. He was turning 53 that day, and he had invited 30 neighborhood children, ages 2 to 12, to come to his compound. All morning he and his work crew set up for the party. They swept and raked and brought in sand, a swing set, new bicycles and scooters. That morning it started to pour rain and it did not stop. Joseph bought huge umbrellas and filled the court yard with them. The children arrived dressed in their nicest clothes and in spite of the rain, they laughed and played and reveled in the party food and the music. Joseph looked like the happiest man alive, his eyes lit with joy as he observed the children playing.

Joseph on his 53rd birthday in July 2010. He gave the neighborhood Cockle Bay children a party.


Risks & Challenges

  • There are no risks to donating to this cause. All of the money raised will be wired directly to Joseph for these children. He is one of the most honorable men I have ever known. 
  • If you wanted to help during the Ebola crisis but didn't know how, now is your chance. 
  • The challenge is great, but together we can demonstrate the goodness of humanity.

Joseph's birthday party in Cockle Bay was pure joy.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this link on Facebook and Twitter
  • Email it to your friends and family. Ask them to donate in honor of your graduation or birthday or just because they love you

St. Augustine said “Since you cannot do good to all, you are to pay special  attention to those who, by accidents of time or place or circumstance, you are brought into closer connection with.” 

Can you help?

Joseph's birthday party in Cockle Bay was pure joy.

story:
At the moment, life in Nepal is miserable for children. We want the kids to eat, smile, learn and play. (like us on Facebook)

Hi Friends,

Help us buy relief material and supplies to operate Bikalpa Mobile School Program.

It is estimated that 1 Million plus children are displaced and looking for shelter. The latest quake, May 12,2015, only adds to the stress for residents of a region who had been trying to return to normalcy. Hit with this news, children, particularly the younger ones, are bombarded with emotions, questions, fear and uncertainty. Let's cheer them up and let them know they are not forgotten and that they can indeed survive this and will one day be able to rebuild a better Nepal. Your support will help protect helpless children and provide urgently needed relief.

Bikalpa is a local NGO worried about the children and their families who may have been affected, it has been running its mobile school program at the camps for earthquake victims where the children are let to release their anxiety, fear and trauma of earthquake through games. Bikalpa staffs are facilitating the children at camp of Lalitpur. It has been working as a legal entity in the country with up-to-date registration documents.

Kids playing games at the temporary camps for Earthquake victims.

We believe that this program will help children gain emotional and psychological support, while keeping children engaged in learning activities during the reconstruction and rehabilitation phase.


EDUCATION IS A MUST.

Education and knowledge for disaster risk reduction fosters to build a culture of safety and resilience at all levels, the overall target being to contribute to a drastic shift in mentalities and perceptions as well as a behavioral change towards a more proactive preventative approach to disasters. Bikalpa Nepal has recognized children, as “tomorrow’s leaders”, to be the primary target of these efforts. 

Teams of volunteers and local teachers will help these children get involved in carefully designed learning experience. Volunteers and teachers will also receive training on counselling children in distress.


Children taking a nap @ a temporary shelter.

Your generous donation, no matter how big or small, matters immensely.

 Please join us and help us put a smile on their faces!!

TRANSPARENCY

 The items are hand delivered directly to the students and faculty. Everything will be 100% transparent. All of our donors will be connected with children through letters and photos. We are so grateful for your contributions and want YOU to become a part of our family.  

Thank you for you support.

story:
After the Local Ferry Capsized Killing Dozens, The People of Ponson Island Need Your Help More Than Ever

(For More Infomation) - http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/03/asia/philippines-...

Help Rural Youth Reach Their Full Potential

We are a small international team made up of former U.S. military personnel and American high school students who are dedicated to the youth of a small, underdeveloped island in the Philippines.  These children are eager to learn and eager to develop skills that will help raise their families out of poverty.  Currently, their efforts are hampered by residual damage to their school from a massive 2013 hurricane and a complete lack of computers on which to learn the skills that afford endless employment opportunities to other children in more developed areas of their country.  The goals of this campaign are to 1) repair the damage to the school, 2) construct a secure facility for use as an island-wide computer learning center, 3) equip the facility with computers and WIFI and 4) establish a fund for the upkeep of the facility and upgrades to the hardware and software as necessary.

*Donations are tax deductible

What We Need

Because our facility will be run by volunteers, we are keeping long-run costs as low as possible.  We will be buying construction materials locally and hiring underemployed locals to help with the construction. Repairing the high school will cost approximately $5000. Building a secure computer facility will also cost approximately $5000. Equipping the facility with air-conditioning, WIFI, computers, software, and desks etc. will run about another $5000.  We are applying to Rotary International for matching funds for the computer equipment.  Whatever money we raise above our goal will first create a maintenance fund and second provide transportation to and from the facility for children who live at the far ends of the island.  If contributions exceed this level, we will look at expanding our vision to surrounding islands facing the same issues. 

The Impact

Children in the Philippines learn English from a very young age. Their education is good and their enthusiasm contagious.  The country, however, is comprised of over 700 islands, many poor and remote, lacking industry and employment opportunities.  Computer skills not only open doors in the mainland's thriving IT industry, but will allow students to apply for college, take courses online, create resumes, and fill out employment applications.  One of our team members, a former Green Beret medic and IT specialist, has been successfully running a free clinic on Ponson Island for many years, and has observed first hand the necessity for computer education for these youth.

Overcoming Obstacles

Charitable projects in any developing country are prone to many obstacles that are usually avoided in developed countries by strict regulation and oversight.  In order to avoid these shortcomings, we are working with trusted team members who have demonstrated a longterm commitment to the welfare of the people on the island.  We are also hoping to team up with nearby Rotary clubs to help in the purchase and installation of the computer systems.
Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you can donate to this project, please support us by sharing our campaign on social media and telling friends and family! Thank You!

story:
When life hands you lemons...

Like many of you, I was devastated by the recent loss of one of Regina's signature historic buildings, Connaught School. Even more devastating: learning that rare, irreplaceable century-old brick, limestone and marble had been sent to the city dump, to be crushed into roadbed inside the landfill. 

...make lemonade!

With support from the City of Regina, 25 volunteers spent two mornings rescuing what they could.  They couldn't carry away enough to rebuild a school, but they saved enough to at least create a lasting reminder of Connaught School, to beautify one of Regina's last remaining historic streetscapes, 13th Avenue.   

Rassembler

It means 'to gather.' It's the name that designers Amanda Lang and Christine Bachinsky chose for a brick reclamation art project that will help redefine the entrance to Regina's Cathedral neighbourhood. Using century-old reclaimed brick and limestone from Connaught, Rassembler will transform a bleak, nondescript corner into an artfully-designed gathering spot, with a tree and green plantlife.   

Rassembler matters because:

  • It showcases the responsible recycling of building materials.
  • It celebrates the spirit of our neighbourhood.
  • It beautifies a corner that badly needs TLC (13th and Albert). 
  • It keeps alive our collective memory of a beloved neighbourhood friend of more than 100 years, Connaught School.

Be a part of history!

The base project budget will be about $7,000 for design work, materials and machinery. We have some funds left over from Save Our Connaught's campaign to keep the school open, and support available from the Cathedral Area Community Association. An additional $1,500 will guarantee Ressambler gets completed in the best manner possible, becoming a durable, beautiful, lasting part of our neighbourhood.

We have an experienced design team, a core of volunteer helpers (we could always use more!), support from the property owner at the location, and a generous neighbourhood that appreciates beauty and creativity.

Your help will push this project over the top, so that by the end of summer we'll have a new neighbourhood entrance to be proud of. Let's make it  happen! 


Other ways to help

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Send us a message if you can contribute sweat equity and use of basic construction equipment.
