story:
We are excited to announce that the Rio Rancho Rotary club made a generous grant donation of $1000 towards our project! 

Casa Xalteva (CX) is a non-profit Spanish language school and educational shelter for underprivileged youth in Granada, Nicaragua. They provide Nicaraguan children and teens with scholarships and the tools needed to become responsible, productive individuals that can share these positive attributes with the local community. CX assists youth in achieving their goals with educational, emotional, and social support.

Children from ages 6 to 18 come to CX from varied circumstances.  They come from homes with dirt floors which do not have entire walls or roofs; or homes that, at any given time may or may not have running water or electricity. Many come from broken homes and do not have any communication or support from their parents.

At the most basic level CX provides a safe, positive environment for children and teens to spend their free time. In Nicaragua, one-third of all children never enroll in school, have poor attendance or drop out before the sixth grade. Most of these children do not learn the necessary reading and math skills to succeed in life discontinuing before completing the first grade. Malnutrition, teenage pregnancy, early marriages, child trafficking, sexual exploitation, and gang involvement also threaten the well-being of Nicaraguan youth. 

Casa Xalteva is a loving community and the children come either in the morning or the afternoon, before or after going to school. CX provides a balanced breakfast and lunch that wouldn’t typically be received in the home.  Lead Teacher Larry Roblero and Children’s Welfare Coordinator Jazmin Rose Tinsley, guide and help the children with their homework, research, and other tasks for school. On a daily basis the children practice teamwork, leadership, non-violence, tolerance, and respect for all through a varied and dynamic program, to help the children become happy, healthy adults that have skills to build changes in their community and to break the poverty cycle. The children's involvement with international students and volunteers from all around the world gives them an intercultural awareness that helps cultivate a healthy, global view. This helps reinforce subjects taught in school, introduce entirely new experiences, and foster team building. The education does not end with the students; CX has recently established strong relationships with the parents and families to continue these practices in the home and the community.

An important part of the program is to provide a healthy lunch for all children at Casa Xalteva on a daily basis. In Nicaragua, one of the main reasons for school drop out is tardiness and lack of attendance.  A majority of schools close their doors to children that arrive more than 15 minutes late.  Therefore, it is extremely important to make sure lunch is ready on time and the children do not have to rush to finish their food before heading to school.  The kitchen, which has served for almost 20 years, is worn out and cannot keep up with cooking demands.  The burners are old and function too slowly to cook basic dishes in a timely manner and the refrigerator is too small to store enough food for the week. There are currently 27 children in the program and by next year they would like to expand.  For that to become a reality, they need to purchase new appliances and replace the old, broken cabinetry. 

Our project will greatly benefit the children of Casa Xalteva by making sure their lunch is ready early enough that the students are able to eat in a relaxed fashion before heading off to school in the afternoon.  The larger fridge will also reduce food waste by keeping more food fresh thus saving money that can be reinvested in the children’s program.   

The total cost of implementation of the new kitchen is $5,600.  This amount will include the purchase of a larger refrigerator, a three-burner stove with oven, new cabinets and counter top, and the labor required to install and/or construct each item.  

We are excited about the prospect of the new kitchen for Casa Xalteva and are extremely thankful for your support! Thank you! Muchísimas gracias! 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Come take Spanish classes at Casa Xalteva! Or tell your friends! Come volunteer with the children's program! Help them with homework, teach English, or bring any of your favorite hobbies and share them with the kids! 

Also, PLEASE SHARE our campaign with your family and friends! Let's make sure CX can build their new kitchen and expand to support more children in 2015 and beyond!

story:
Canadians and Egyptians are working together to discover the past and forging important bonds for the future through common restoration projects. You will be doing so much more than helping out a team of young Canadian scholars.

Help Canadians uncover and restore the secrets of one of the most significant archaeological sites in Egypt by sponsoring the restoration of an Egyptian temple.

The Canadian Institute in Egypt is sending a Canadian team of technicians from the University of Toronto, Canada, to join the Institute’s team at Tel er-Rub’a (Mendes), Egypt in 2015, 120 miles north of Cairo. The Tel er-Rub’a site is unique: it has the tallest building north of Cairo and south of Alexandria. This building (the naos – see photograph) needs restoration. On June 9, 2014, a meeting was held at the Mendes dig house. It was decided:

1.  The restoration of the naos would require heavy equipment, such as cranes, front loaders, heavy trucks, generators. These could not be allowed to run over ancient antiquities, delicate and fragile, which have to be preserved.

2.  Therefore the team has to excavate east, west, and south of the naos to (a) make sure no important remains lie under the surface in these areas, and (b) to prepare a solid bed for the heavy equipment.

This is where you come in.  Before proceeding with the actual restoration by architects and engineers, these future archaeologists, under the guidance of Professors Donald and Susan Redford’s field school at Mendes, have to ensure that no artifact is left behind. Who knows what other secrets these budding Canadian archaeologists will find?

Even the smallest donation can help these future archaeologists and the team to achieve their goal.  You will be doing so much more than helping out a team of young scholars.  You will be fostering relations between Canada and Egypt in real, tangible ways.

What we need and what you get

The team needs $8,000. Sponsor a team member, or a portion of the restoration project. Sponsorships range from $5 (for 15 minutes of excavation) to $1,000 (the costs of a participating team member). The funds will be equally divided among the participants to help with the airfare and living expenses of the dig.

In Exchange for your support

As a token of our appreciation, your donation will entitle you:

Amount

Description

$5

An email of thanks from one of the technicians.

$15

A bookmark

$25

A bookmark and a button

$35

A postcard written at the dig site

$45

A t-shirt made by local artisans from a village near the Mendes dig site

$75

A year-long Canadian Institute in Egypt membership.

$100

A year-long Canadian Institute in Egypt membership and a copy of the season’s excavation report

$150

Sponsor (Bronze).  Get weekly email updates from the technicians you are sponsoring.  Learn about the daily life of an archaeologist!

$200

Sponsor (Silver).  Weekly email updates plus photos!

$250

Sponsor (Gold), Weekly email updates, photos, plus a personalized video greeting from the dig house, made by your sponsored technician.

$300

Sponsor (Platinum). Weekly email updates, photos, plus a personalized video tour of the dig site and your sponsored square!  This deluxe option gives you a taste of the real dig life.  Follow along with the work and play Indiana Jones at home!

$500

Sponsor (Diamond).  Weekly email updates, photos, a personalized video tour of the dig site and your sponsored technician, PLUS a live fifteen-minute Skype Q&A with members of the dig team. 

$1000

Sponsor (Hall of Fame). Special mention of your name or corporation in all publications related to the restoration project.

Meet the team

Each participant will learn and apply excavation, conservation and data input techniques in their specific roles.

Name

Country

Role

Aliza Fatima

Canada

Ceramicist

Amira Selim

Egypt

Artist and Translator

Antoine Hirsch

Canada

Information Technology

Leah Bender

Canada

Registrar

Noha Hassan

Egypt

Illustrator

Tristan Samuels

Canada

Epigrapher

What makes this dig different?

Expedition 2015 will use ground breaking recording technology to enhance academic archaeological archives and publications. Professional video recording and broadcasting will enable present and future archaeologists to interpret the site and environment differently through "reality shows" and archives.

Archaeology is a one-time operation: Once you dig, the environment where you dig – layer by layer – is lost forever.  The records being made during the restoration Expedition 2015, however, will be part of an archive that can be retrieved for future interpretation of the site.

Other ways you can help

Some people just can’t contribute but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

·  Share this link on your blog, Facebook, forum, or email it to family, friends, or acquaintances who love the history channel!

·  Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

About the Canadian Institute in Egypt

The Canadian Institute in Egypt is a not-for-profit corporation (Ontario Corporation 1344023) recognized by protocols signed in September 1982 between the Canadian and Egyptian governments (http://www.canadianinstituteinegypt.org).

The Institute promotes study and research in the educational, scientific, cultural, technical, archaeological and historical fields. The Institute serves as the channel for contacts between Canadian scholars and artists and the Ministry of Higher Education, the Ministry of Culture, and the Academy of Scientific and Technical Research in Egypt.


Official Website: www.canadianinstituteinegypt.org

Twitter: www.twitter.com/CieEgypt

Facebook: www.facebook.com/pages/The-Canadian-Institute-i...

Tumblr: www.canadianinstituteinegypt.tumblr.com

Linkedin:  www.ca.linkedin.com/pub/canadian-institute-in-e...

Online Library Scripta Antiqua: www.scripta-antiqua.com

story:
Short Summary

Solar Rollers, a non-profit energy education program, develops engineering design concepts at the high school level. Competitive, creative high school design teams  are racing to build and design the fastest, most efficient, solar powered remote controlled racecar.  Utilizing only the power of the sun, the teams will compete in technical knowledge, endurance with solar power only, and good old fashioned competitive racing

This award-winning program is already well established in Colorado. The Solar Rollers are looking to grow into Texas.  I would like to see it extend its reach to the high schools in Austin area for the 2015 season.  There are at least 8 high school teams actively interested in developing in the Austin area already. 

To make this program really take off, the Solar Rollers are looking for several sponsors that are interested in renewable energy, engineering design, electronics, and construction of R/C solar powered cars and the arrays to power them. The standard solar R/C race kit typically with all components start out around $1,000.  Each school is encouraged to fund raise to earn this.  We also need sponsors for the Trophy Race Event, about $11,000. 

Who am I? 

Anthony Parker is a local high school student at Khabele Strong in Austin Texas.  I was part of the group of students who helped launched the Solar Rollers program in Carbondale, CO, in 2012.  I then organized and led my own high school team last year.  Now I would like to lead the way in launching this program in Austin, Texas. Building the Solar powered race cars was not only fun but I learned advanced mathematics, physics, engineering, design, teamwork, and the list just goes on and on. But the bottom line is we are the future of the world and we are looking to you, the current leaders of the world, to help us. 

What We Need & What You Get

  •  We need the $11,000 simply to pay for the Race Day Event.   
  • Even if you can't give much to our cause, every dollar counts; and we will thank you profusely if all you can do is support us.
  • Your sponsorship will he honored on our Web site and on the Game day program.
  • The top 5 sponsors can hang a banner on Race Day at our event.
  • Until our $11,000 goal is met nothing can be done with solar powered racing in Austin. The money you so generously donate to us will be placed in an escrow account until the goal is met.

The Impact

  • By donating to start this project you will be making a considerable contribution to the education system. We high school students, are so in need of things to do that are fun yet complicated.   
  • As a highschooler you don't get many chances to make an impact, so I helped create the Solar Rollers program to impact the lives of Hundreds. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk is that we are unable to begin this project for the 2014-15 year.  We will have to aim for the 2015-16 year instead.  
My biggest challenge is that I may run out of time to personally check on each team and answer questions.  
After we have been generously funded, the Solar Rollers program will eventually  reach out to a total of four states. With a goal of all the high schools in the world that this doesn't seem like much. But I am confident that with your help we could extend our reach across the globe.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, no sweat, spreading the word to your friends and family is another way you can help. If you support this project you don't have to donate to get listed on our websites as supporters of innovative education. Thank You.

But the bottom line is we are the future of the world and we are looking to you, the current leaders of the world, to help us. 
What We Need & What You Get   We need the $11,000 simply to pay for the Race Day Event.    Even if you can't give much to our cause, every dollar counts; and we will thank you profusely if all you can do is support us.
Your sponsorship will he honored on our Web site and on the Game day program.
The top 5 sponsors can hang a banner on Race Day at our event. Until our $11,000 goal is met nothing can be done with solar powered racing in Austin. The money you so generously donate to us will be placed in an escrow account until the goal is met.    The Impact 
By donating to start this project you will be making a considerable contribution to the education system. We high school students, are so in need of things to do that are fun yet complicated.    As a highschooler you don't get many chances to make an impact, so I helped create the Solar Rollers program to impact the lives of Hundreds.     Risks & Challenges  The biggest risk is that we are unable to begin this project for the 2014-15 year.  We will have to aim for the 2015-16 year instead.  My biggest challenge is that I may run out of time to personally check on each team and answer questions.  After we have been generously funded, the Solar Rollers program will eventually  reach out to a total of four states. With a goal of all the high schools in the world that this doesn't seem like much. But I am confident that with your help we could extend our reach across the globe.   Other Ways You Can Help If you can't donate, no sweat, spreading the word to your friends and family is another way you can help. If you support this project you don't have to donate to get listed on our websites as supporters of innovative education. Thank You.

story:
Who am I?

My name is Violet Nantume. I am 27 years old and I come from Uganda in East Africa. I am a sculptor, jeweler and painter. I love and I am passionate about art and cultural management. This is because I believe it is pivotal for the development of civilization and of people’s minds.

Art elaborates a people’s way of life and indeed defines us, composes us and the sum total of who we are on the inside draws from our artistic and cultural makeup. We express ourselves best through the moulds of our culture. Art and culture are at the very core of the way we see and perceive the rest of the world, the way we innovate and the way we advance ourselves as a people.


Exodus 2011, (123cm x97cm) By Ntensibe Joseph.

The Cook and Her Guest- 2012.(170cm x 130cm) By Ntensibe Joseph

About what I want to do:

I want to become a professional curator. I want to learn the tools and methodologies on how to represent art and artists. I will focus on their artistic development and contemporary approach to the themes of visual art and culture.

I applied for and was admitted to do a Masters degree in Curatorial Studies at the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College in New York in March 2014. CCS Bard is one of the world’s leading universities in curatorial studies and what better place than this to help me become a professional curator.

I want to complete that master’s degree in curatorial studies so that I can come back home and play a leading role in the preservation of the cultures and cultural heritage of the people of my country.

You can help turn my dream into reality:

My tuition fees at the University for the First Academic Year amount to $56,886. Below is the breakdown. 

  1. Tuition                 $37,284
  2. Fees                        $1,602
  3. Living cost p.a    $18,000
I was awarded a bursary of $21,000 from the Bard College office of Financial Aid to cover part of my tuition.I need to raise the balance of $35,886 before June 2015.

I am currently focusing all my fundraising efforts towards raising the balance.Apart from this campaign, I am applying to several organisations and Patrons.  I hope we can pull this off by June 2015 because school is due to start in September.


Artists and Curators at DakArt 2014


Alternative ways to help me:

You may not be in position to support me financially and that is alright. Do not feel left out. Help me otherwise by telling your circle of friends about my campaign. You can do that by liking this page and tweeting or emailing the link to your networks.

This will go a long way in giving wings to my campaign. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word. The visibility of my Indiegogo campaign is directly related to the amount of activity my page receives. I will always be indebted to your time and your generosity, many blessings.

story:
ABOUT THE CODE:MOBILE

The code:mobile is Ladies Learning Code’s newest and biggest initiative to inspire and educate Canadian girls and boys to become passionate builders -- not just consumers of technology.

Think: a travelling computer lab on wheels (Canada's first coding truck)! 

But, it’s more than just a truck or a computer lab. It’s a cross-Canada journey that will bring hands-on, interactive technology education to Canadian youth.  We believe that computer programming and other technical skills are a tool of empowerment, and it is our mission at Ladies Learning Code to ensure that all Canadians -- particularly women and youth -- have access to these learning opportunities.  

And, we need YOUR help!

From May to September 2016, we want to visit our 22+ Chapter cities across Canada plus their surrounding cities and towns based on community requests.

We’ll visit large and small communities, in privileged and underprivileged communities alike, stopping by at local parks, community centres, Summer Camps, street festivals, aboriginal reserves, hospitals and anywhere else we can park the truck and pop-up our lab.

If we reach our funding goal, we estimate we'll travel approximately 35,000km coast to coast teaching over 10,000 kids to code next Summer! 


Help us inspire and teach kids that code has the power to change the world.



WHY DOES THIS MATTER? WHY TEACH CODE? 

Technology is everywhere and it’s not going anywhere. We want to equip Canadian youth with the critical skills they need to navigate the world we live in today and thrive in the future. We think it’s important for youth to learn to code for a few reasons:

  1. Coding is a superpower. Learning to code let’s kids build -- not just consume the technology around them like video games, websites, robots and more.

  2. Coding helps kids develop new ways of thinking and foster problem-solving techniques that gives kids a competitive advantage when applying to colleges, internships or jobs - they are valuable skills that are in high demand.

  3. Coding helps kids understand the world around them better. If we teach biology and mathematics in order to understand the world around them, then knowing the basics of how computers communicate - and how to engage with them -should be a given.

  4. Coding can help change the world empower kids to use technology as a creative tool to build solutions for problems or challenges people face everyday.

  5. Coding is fun!  We want kids to experience the satisfaction and thrill of building something of their very own.


THE CODE:MOBILE APPROACH

Our youth programs: Girls Learning Code and Kids Learning Code are all about coding, technology and changing the world – through teamwork, creativity, and, of course, technology. The code:mobile will be offering 1.5 to 3 hour hands-on coding sessions that integrate web making and game making and all of the core components that our youth programs are known and loved for. Components like:

Our content has been designed specifically with girls in mind and creating gender-balanced tech environments.

We keep in mind a recurrent theme in research on gender and technology: girls approach the computer as a “tool” useful primarily for what it can do; boys more often view the computer as a “toy” or an extension of the self. At Ladies Learning Code, we don’t only teach “how” to build, but also “why” it is important. We offer an opportunity for girls and boys to learn about technology and collaborate together.

Fun and engaging content

We LOVE technology and want to pass it on. With the help of developers, designers and professional educators, we’ve created content that not only showcases beginner-friendly concepts, but also ideas to be excited about.

The opportunity to learn and collaborate alongside like-minded students

Through hands-on team-based exercises kids will feel a part of a resourceful group who are all curious about technology, and find learning about it both intriguing and rewarding.

Tons of support

With a high ratio of kids to expert mentors, questions are always encouraged, discussion is open-minded, and learning is creative and challenging.

We’re all about confidence and empowerment

Our lead instructors, mentors, and guest speakers are ready to teach, motivate and inspire. These are people who are currently in the field of technology, in a professional role, or in a learning opportunity.

We’re all about supporting the communities we visit to keep learning

We want to ensure that every kid, parent and teacher that attends one of the code:mobile sessions has the support and resources to continue learning. As such, we’re creating a resource package of content and teaching materials to leave with each community and an opportunity for anyone to start their own code:club in their home, school or community centre with our support.


WHAT’S LADIES LEARNING CODE DONE SO FAR?


Founded in 2011, we are a Canadian not-for-profit organization with the mission to become the leading resource for women and youth to become passionate builders - not just consumers - of technology by learning technical skills in a hands-on, social, and collaborative way. Our goal is to teach 200,000 Canadian women and youth to code by 2020.

We run one-day workshops for adults in 22+ cities (and counting) across Canada plus Girls Learning Code and Kids Learning Code, which are thriving youth programs for youth ages 6-17.

To date, we’ve taught over 24,000 women and youth in one of our programs across the country. It is exciting and heartening to know that Canadians of all backgrounds are getting a first taste of coding at our workshops, and leaving the event with a greater sense of self-confidence. That’s what digital literacy is all about! It’s this community that we can help grow and foster with your support. Learn more about our history and impact here.


STRETCH GOALS


$50,000

If we reach our funding goal of $50,000 we estimate we'll travel approximately 35,000km coast to coast, stopping in 40+ cities and teaching over 10,000 kids to code in the Summer of 2016. 

$75,000

If we raise $75,000 in funding, we'll have enough resources to keep the truck on the road for the Fall of 2016, too exposing another 5,000 kids to code. 

$100,000

If we raise $100,000 in funding, we'll have enough resources to extend our trip and/or do another cross-country tour in 2017 and/or get another truck and/or expand on our code:clubs curriculum. There’s a lot of possibilities here!



I SEE MICROSOFT'S LOGO ON THE TRUCK. IF A MAJOR CORPORATION IS ALREADY SUPPORTING YOU, WHY SHOULD I HELP?

To date, we’ve been fortunate enough to have the support of many generous individuals and corporations like Microsoft, TELUS, Olson (who put together the awesome video) and more that have allowed us to purchase, retrofit the truck and put this campaign together. But to sustain this initiative, we need to engage teachers, parents and community members across the country.  All donations, regardless of the amount, help further our mission and allow us to reach more students.  Specifically, your financial contributions will help to get the code:mobile on the road and make the cross-Canada journey! Your support will help make our trip possible by contributing to costs associated with bringing on amazing team to deliver workshops across the country next Summer and by helping to cover operating costs like gas, parking, accommodations, insurance, CAA, regular maintenance checks and more. All of the important things that will keep the code:mobile trucking along.



HELP US SPREAD THE WORD: JOIN THE CODE:SQUAD!

Ladies Learning Code has always been by the community, for the community. Our organization and programs are driven by learners, mentors, parents, teachers, sponsors, partners and volunteers who understand the importance of teaching and learning technical skills. Whether you donate to our campaign or not you can still help us reach our goal (and make history).  

How you can help:

  • Spread the word about the #LLCcodemobile on Facebook orTwitter.

  • Recruit a local group — girl guides club, school or community centre and request a visit from the code:mobile.

  • Stay connected. Follow us on Facebook and on Twitter to stay up-to-date on our initiatives and programs and join our mailing list.


RISKS AND CHALLENGES


The team at Ladies Learning Code are social entrepreneurs and technologists that are super dedicated to making code:mobile and our cross-Canada journey happen. The real risks and challenges we face don't lie in completing this trip, but in the problems that we'll face without it.

Our backgrounds and passion for this cause make us the ideal team for this mission . If we raise our minimum funding goal, we do not anticipate any significant challenges or risks in completing our cross-Canada journey. 

As with all crowdfunding campaigns, there is always a risk of delay in delivering some of the rewards, but we've been careful to give ourselves more time than we think we'll need to make sure we get the rewards in a reasonable time.

story:
We're a poetry community in New York's Lower Hudson Valley. All people are welcome to come and share their art at our monthly poetry events in Suffern and Nyack.

Each year, as a community, we choose our top performance poets to represent our region at the National Poetry Slam. It's in Oakland, California this August and we need your help to get there. 

Sending a team to NPS is good because...

  1. Our region will be represented at the national level
  2. These community members will grow tremendously as poets, both in the preparation for NPS and through their experiences in Oakland -- and will bring those experiences back to our scene
  3. We'll have more access with the national poetry scene, providing us access to potential featured poets and workshop leaders
This year's team consists of Tiffany Woodley, Rachel Therres, Nick Yuknalis, and Bryan Roessel. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

  1. Come to our events! Find details at facebook.com/suffern.poetry, meetup.com/Suffern-Slam-Society/, or e-mail us at suffernpoetry@gmail.com
  2. Donate!

WHAT'S THE MONEY FOR

The thousand dollars we want to raise will help pay for the hotel rooms and airfare for our poets competing this year.

If we meet or exceed our funding goals, we'll have an adequate budget next year to  keep bringing in awesome poets to feature at our open mics (like January's Chris August or April's Patrick Roche).

STRETCH GOAL:

If we raise $1500, the team will make daily video blog updates from NPS about our experiences there and the awesome stuff that we're seeing and doing.

story:
Hola Cosmic Family!

I am Yasmina, am 38, study Waldorf Education and Amazonian Traditional Medicine. I live happily in Yelapa, Mexico with my 5 kids, Itzel, Alex, Angela, Yasmina and Aymaro. They are Light, Wisdom, Inspiration and a solid strength source in moments of kicking, screaming, crying on my path of transformation. As I step deeper throughout my growth process into these virtues/energies. I realize the magnificence of our true essence, the great powerful beings we are, our capacities when discovered and developed, the amazing intelligence and wisdom within Creation, the mineral kingdom, plant kingdom, animal kingdom, human kingdom, Light Beings kingdom, each with its own melody, dancing natures exquisite rhythm.
For the last years I have been studying Amazonian traditional medicine. The first year in California,  the last close to 2 years with the indigenous Shipibo- Conibo people in the Amazon, Peru. It has been and continues to be a lifechanging experience. I have lived the truth of their beliefs, traditions. It is thru my personal experience, that a passion for learning grows stronger within. 
My Shipibo Family and Nature have, and continue to significantly assist gain clarity and understanding of who I am, what am I here for? and where am I going?
It has been a powerful journey filled with profound pain and darkness, an intense cleansing, recalibration of my energetic bodies. As all this debris is surfaced, it  makes room for the new... compassion, understanding, LOVE, towards myself and others...   
The deeper I inmerge into my studies with the Shipibo People and Nature, the clearer the path of the healer becomes.  This is my Mission...
I am aware we are all healers, we all have these capacities to heal ourselves. To me, the revelation just gets stronger that this must be shared widely with others. It is a knowing pulsating within my Being.
As this new quest unfolds, I am invited into the mysteries of death and rebirth, in the art of true healing and a new cosmology for humankind.... 
Today, it is clear we face a serious planetary crisis, but it is also clear and true our civilization is on the cusp of a new birth, a birth in which healers are very much needed, in the Inca tradition they are called ~Chacaruna, a bridge person whom can help others cross the river to the other side, from one state of consciousness to another state of consciousness. One that can help others discover their authentic Spiritual Being. What I have experienced is that when one chooses the pathway of Spirit, the Cosmos gradually unfolds certain gifts, which activate the Chacarunas abilities to work with many different manifestations of the Cosmos.
This is my Path, to experience this awareness is what leads me to seek what is needed to make it happen. The next step in my studies is to intern 3 months in Peru, to work closely with shaman teachers and the plants.
In the past,  my children stay in Mexico while I go to Peru,for periods of 2 weeks, occasionally I take one at a time with me, but this time 3 months feels long, and do not want to leave them. I am reaching out to you for support in this stage of my development.  I deeply appreciate your possibilities and heart intention.
Plane tickets and basic accommodation at the center are the highest expense. 11,000 dlls covers just these 2. I realize it is a lot, we are many (4 of my kids and myself)... Once again your contribution big, medium or small, is greatly greatly appreciate it. I BELIEVE in Community, I BELIEVE in Family, I BELIEVE in the power of Intention, the Kindness of the Heart… 
I welcome comments and/or suggestions to reach this goal successfully… Muchas Gracias… ;)
Lastly... the Inca people believe in the promise of Pachakuti, and the new sunrise, the return time of the children of the sun, it is time to recognize the concepts defining the children of the sun in all of us. A time of awakening and remembering who we really are, with a new vision of this reality. It is time for a change of paradigm, opportunity for great expansions of consciousness to open our hearts and live in joy and abundance. It is time for the children of the sun to live in balance, harmony and reciprocity with all of nature.
I also believe in this Promise...
Yasmina ;)
Irake… ~thank you in shipibo 
Muah!

It is thru my personal experience, that a passion for learning grows stronger within. My Shipibo Family and Nature have, and continue to significantly assist gain clarity and understanding of who I am, what am I here for? and where am I going?It has been a powerful journey filled with profound pain and darkness, an intense cleansing, recalibration of my energetic bodies. As all this debris is surfaced, it  makes room for the new... compassion, understanding, LOVE, towards myself and others...   The deeper I inmerge into my studies with the Shipibo People and Nature, the clearer the path of the healer becomes.  This is my Mission...
I am aware we are all healers, we all have these capacities to heal ourselves. To me, the revelation just gets stronger that this must be shared widely with others. It is a knowing pulsating within my Being.
As this new quest unfolds, I am invited into the mysteries of death and rebirth, in the art of true healing and a new cosmology for humankind.... Today, it is clear we face a serious planetary crisis, but it is also clear and true our civilization is on the cusp of a new birth, a birth in which healers are very much needed, in the Inca tradition they are called ~Chacaruna, a bridge person whom can help others cross the river to the other side, from one state of consciousness to another state of consciousness. One that can help others discover their authentic Spiritual Being. What I have experienced is that when one chooses the pathway of Spirit, the Cosmos gradually unfolds certain gifts, which activate the Chacarunas abilities to work with many different manifestations of the Cosmos.This is my Path, to experience this awareness is what leads me to seek what is needed to make it happen. The next step in my studies is to intern 3 months in Peru, to work closely with shaman teachers and the plants.In the past,  my children stay in Mexico while I go to Peru,for periods of 2 weeks, occasionally I take one at a time with me, but this time 3 months feels long, and do not want to leave them. I am reaching out to you for support in this stage of my development.  I deeply appreciate your possibilities and heart intention.Plane tickets and basic accommodation at the center are the highest expense. 11,000 dlls covers just these 2. I realize it is a lot, we are many (4 of my kids and myself)... Once again your contribution big, medium or small, is greatly greatly appreciate it. I BELIEVE in Community, I BELIEVE in Family, I BELIEVE in the power of Intention, the Kindness of the Heart… I welcome comments and/or suggestions to reach this goal successfully… Muchas Gracias… ;)Lastly... the Inca people believe in the promise of Pachakuti, and the new sunrise, the return time of the children of the sun, it is time to recognize the concepts defining the children of the sun in all of us. A time of awakening and remembering who we really are, with a new vision of this reality. It is time for a change of paradigm, opportunity for great expansions of consciousness to open our hearts and live in joy and abundance. It is time for the children of the sun to live in balance, harmony and reciprocity with all of nature.I also believe in this Promise...Yasmina ;)Irake… ~thank you in shipibo Muah!

story:
There are approximately 59 million people around the world who need wheelchairs and other assistive devices, but do not have access to them.  80% of people with disabilities live in developing countries. UCP Wheels for Humanity is here to move people with disabilities lives' forward. 

Quick Facts

  • 1 billion people worldwide live with a disability.
  • People with disabilities in developing nations are disproportionately affected by poverty and excluded from all facets of society.
  • In developing countries there is an average of one physical therapist per 10,000 people.
  • Disability rights are human rights.

How We Help

Mobility

We provide appropriately fitted chairs to individuals in need and build the capacities of local partner organizations to ensure continued access and service.

A boy received a properly-fitted wheelchair during a seating clinic in Costa Rica.

Empowerment

We link people to resources and establish community support networks to improve quality of life.

Children playing wheelchair basketball at from our adaptive sports camp in El Salvador.

Therapy

We train physical therapists and rural health workers in up-to-date best practices in therapy and rehabilitation, namely replacing several older teachings that are no longer in use in the United States and Europe but are still commonly used in the developing world.

Physical therapists helping a boy during a training in El Salvador.

Advocacy

We work with key individuals in the private, public, and social sectors to advocate for the provision of wheelchairs, accessible buildings and workplaces, and inclusive societies.

Sri Lestari, a UCP Wheels staff member and wheelchair user,  spreads the word about disability rights, demonstrates the potential for people with disability, and gain support for people with disabilities and programs that assist them during her annual journey across Indonesia. 

Our Global Footprint

Since our inception in 1996, UCP Wheels for Humanity has helped more than 350,000 people in over 72 countries (including Cuba most recently in June 2015). But there’s still more work to do to keep moving lives forward. 


How You Can Help

With your support, we hope to raise $12,000 for people with disabilities around the world. Your generous donations from this campaign will go directly to our largest fundraiser of the year – Wheels in Motion –  on September 26. Contributions from this campaign combined with Wheels in Motion will help us reach our $300,000 goal to fund our support services, as well as programs for people with disabilities in developing countries. With your help we can continue moving lives forward! 

We have very unique and personal perks to say "thank you" for your support including recognition for your donations on social media, signed postcards from kids attending our adaptive sports camp in El Salvador, autographed artwork by local artist Rocio Villalobos, tickets to Wheels in Motion in Los Angeles and much more! Check out our perks page for more! 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can make a difference in other ways! 

  • Spread the word on social media by using #MovingLivesForward. Make sure to follow us too on: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube!
  • Advocate for disability rights.
  • Share our campaign with family and friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or via email. 
  • Learn even more about our organization and sign-up on our mailing list at www.ucpwheels.org

UCP Wheels is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization. All contributions are tax deductible. Thank you for your support and contributions!

story:
Short Summary

Dear compassionate loving and caring people, no doubt death means same for everyone, the pain and the grievance it leaves behind for the bereaved family members is immeasurable. However, due to the media and internet, only  pain and sufferings from Kathmandu valley has come to spotlight. What about the sufferings of the remote areas? There are villages with no access to vehicles and takes two days to reach by foot !!

The death toll from Nepal's massive quake rises to more than 7,765 with many areas still inaccessible, food and water rare and many residents without proper shelter.

  

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is your support for those earthquake victims in the remote areas like Gorkha and Lamjung , where 7.8 rector scale earthquake had its epicentre. Dear donors, the entire village in Gorkha has been wiped out, whole  village with their livestock has been flattened to ground. The aftermath of the earthquake (which is still reoccurring as aftershock) has changed the entire geography of the hills. Moreover, landslides in this affected areas have added more misery to the victims already ripped by the earthquake.

Dear contributors with our money we may not be able to bring their dead ones back, bring their houses back but we can build a small huts for them to get some shelter. The people from this districts are so poor that most of the survivors will not be able to make a new house out of their own. So, we need your small contribution to bring back their lost hopes to live in and sleep in the days to come.

The Impact

The funded money $20,000  will be approximately Rs 20,00000. This money will be given to Village Development Committee (V.D.C) of the earthquake affected areas of remote hills. We estimate the cost of  making 1 hut to be $200 so we will be making 100 huts, which means 100 families with their children (if any have survived) will be living in this home for many years.

 

Risks & Challenges

We adhere with the word 'transparency', so we have decided to visit ourselves and donate the fund to the secretary of the V.D.C. We will also join hand in making those huts and provide our valued contributors, videos and pictures as a proof. This will certainly add more value to our philanthropic work, satisfaction to the contributors and lastly the most important,  smile in the grim faces of  the victim!


Other Ways You Can Help

Other ways you can help is by donating to 

Red Cross Nepal: http://www.nrcs.org/donate-nrcs

Global Giving: https://www.globalgiving.org/projects/nepal-earthquake-relief-fund/

story:
GREENWOOD ENTREPRENEURS


America is failing our most powerful minds -  This campaign is about innovative programming and a new approach that helps students with ADHD and Dyslexia leverage strengths that are traditionally defined as weaknesses to unleash their potential and become successful entrepreneurs.
THE GREENWOOD SCHOOL'S BREAKTHROUGH UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TO MAXIMIZE THE ENTREPRENEURIAL TRAITS OF ADHD LEARNERS MEANS WE CAN HELP MORE KIDS THAN EVER. 

Entrepreneurialism and ADHD

Creativity and Innovation are hallmarks of people with ADHD. From Richard Branson, to Charles Schwab, there are many powerful examples of successful Entrepreneurs who have ADHD. In fact, those who are diagnosed with ADHD are THREE TIMES more likely to be Entrepreneurs when compared to the general population. 

But without intervention kids with ADHD experience:
  • Problems succeeding at school
  • Problems at work, lost productivity, and reduced earning power
  • Problems with relationships
  • More driving citations and accidents
  • Problems with the law ( 40% of long term inmates are ADHD)

According to Dr. Joseph Biederman, professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, ADHD may be one of the costliest medical conditions in the United States: “Evaluating, diagnosing and treating this condition may not only improve the quality of life, but could save billions of dollars every year"

With intervention these same kids can  grow-up to be wildly successful adults and now with The Greenwood School's breakthrough understanding of how to maximize the entrepreneurial traits these learners have we can help more kids than ever. 

Here are a few typical ADHD traits that can be developed with understanding, perspective, and approach:

ADHD Super Powers 

1.Risk Taking: students with ADHD are intuitive thinkers and are more likely to act on opportunity and take business risks than miss an opportunity due to overanalyzing actions.

2.Creativity: “Thinking outside the box”— An abundance of thoughts and ideas come with the ADHD active mind. ADHD thinkers are creative problem solvers.

3.Ability to Hyper Focus: One way to think about ADHD is having a low boredom threshold—the ADHD brain becomes more easily frustrated with routine, and yet if they find something they love to do, students with ADHD can focus for hours on end. 

4.Multi-tasking: The ADHD brain likes doing several tasks at one time. ADHDers are not necessarily better at multi-tasking than the general population; the difference is they love to multi-task. 

5.High Energy Level: The ADHD brain thrives on stimulation – Entrepreneurs need the ability to manage chaos, unpredictability, and inconsistency. 


Entrepreneurialism and Dyslexia

People with dyslexia are likewise 2-3 times more likely to be Entrepreneurs compared to the general US and UK populations.  Individuals with dyslexia proved more comfortable in a startup role because they have faced hard challenges from a very young age.

Delegation 

Entrepreneurs with dyslexia typically have more staff than non-dyslexic Entrepreneurs, are more likely to own more than one business, are able to grow their companies more quickly, and are more able to delegate.  Delegation is an example of the “coping strategies” folks with dyslexia employ to overcome their difficulties. 

Communication 

Having often struggled with written language, people with dyslexia often develop enhanced communication skills, which are an essential business tool when it comes to inspiring others to achieve a vision. 

Coaching

These kids have often had teachers, parents, and counselors coaching them all their lives. It has been like havign a practive baord of directors. They know how to find mentors and use their resources of their communities.

Entrepreneurialism and The Digital Age

To capitalize on this research (and frankly what we already know about our boys) we've created the first of its kind digital entrepreneurship program GREENWOOD ENTREPRENEURS aimed at transforming these unique skill sets into a successful marketplace of business and opportunity for these bright kids that society cannot afford to leave behind.

With speed and mobility the digital age has changed every major industry we know. The Greenwood Entrepreneur program gives our kids pragmatic, real-world  hands-on experience in building companies, solving problems, and selling themselves and their brand. 

For each company, we create a website, design brand materials, social marketing and media, visit real world companies in the industry, create and make useful contacts, and finally design and produce a real product line to sell.  This year our boys created an ironic clothing brand that celebrates our unique differences called "Conform Clothing" .. Never Conform!™ During our second term we created a dog treat company called "The Distinguished Dog." And our final group started a wrist band cause bracelet to celebrate learning differences called "Think Strong." 

If you were a young person with learning challenges you know how difficult they can be to overcome, but if you're anything like us, you also know what's possible once you're able to harness the power of an often confusing, but unique and powerful mind. 

We need your help. 

If you're an entrepreneur or business person who sees some of yourself in these boys, or who wants to keep these bright creative problme solvers at the table then please help support this program so we can help as many bright young entrepreneurs see the wide-eyed possibilities of their unique gifts and talents. Every dollar goes right into the program.

Our first year has been an inspiring success but we don't want to stop there. We want to empower kids all over the country. With your help we can do just that.

Greenwood School students were most recently featured in The Address, a feature length documentary produced by celebrated American documentarian, Ken Burns:


And, check out STEAM. Greenwood School is making sure these bright minds stay at the table!


We Need

  • Adobe licensing for programs like Photoshop, Illustrator, and Premiere. Currently we have a teams license for just two simultaneous users. 
  • MacBooks for each entrepreneur. Currently we only have 2 iMac work stations.
  • Wordpress templates and server space
  • Startup costs for each company -- everything from stickers, to business cards, to product material, to 3D printing supplies
When you give to our Indiegogo you get all sorts of rewards. Most of which are the actual products our boys have created!
Help us launch the "Learning Differences are Super Powers" campaign across America. Just like we launched the "Learn the Address" campaign by creating a national Gettysburg competition(which is in its third and best year yet), we'll create an all new campaign based on the advantages of our unique minds by celebrating the entrepreneurial spirit. Together, we'll begin an all new LD Super Power Summit with all of our friends in the LD world. 

The Greenwood School has created the first of its kind Digital Entrepreneurship program where students with learning differences like ADHD and Dyslexia create real, working companies from the ground up. But we need your help so we can help more of these wonderful, bright kids succeed.

Please tell everyone you know about Greenwood Entrepreneurs. Help us spread the word so that together we can change the world---one young entrepreneur at a time. After all, learning differences can be super powers.

story:
Sydney Mwamba and the AACDP

I run a non profit here in the States called the African Artists Community Development Project that buys crafts from Zambia at fair market value and sends the profits back to a center for disabled children in the same locality.

I met Sydney in 2007, when he asked me to sponsor him in a business diploma program. His aunt makes crafts for me, so I asked her if Sydney was a good bet. She replied enthusiastically "Sydney is the hardest-working young man and best student in our village." 

With time, education and an intelligent and compassionate nature, Sydney has become an excellent business manager. He ships the crafts, oversees quality control, manages crises and keeps me generally informed about our people and projects in Lusaka and Livingstone.

Now he wants to expand — and run — a craft export business in Zambia that will train and hire local Zambians, including those with disabilities. Employment is hard to find in Zambia, so this would create tremendous opportunity. 

What he needs is more knowledge, and so he is headed for University. But the cost is high -- $5,000 a year is out of the reach of most Zambians, 80% of whom are way below the poverty line. Scholarships are rare and, when you do get one, too small to cover much.

While AACDP has so far been able to support his tuition in other business programs, the university cost is far beyond our resources. Please give Sydney a hand. This degree will mean opportunity for not only for him — but for other Zambian families as well. Opportunity to learn and do is the most useful gift we can give.

story:
ECSS is an organizing retreat for all South Asian & Desi-identifying youth! East Coast Solidarity Summer (formerly known as DC Desi Summer) will be held from July 24-26 in New Jersey, for youth 15-21 years old. ECSS is a radical space for young people to examine local and global justice issues through a critical lens.

About ECSS

ECSS (formerly DCDS) has been a community-funded project for 5 years and running!  With the banning of ethnic studies in many universities and public schools around the U.S., increased surveillance and policing of immigrant and people of color communities, and the recent global and local uprisings a part of the Occupy movement, it is important to support critical spaces of learning, questioning and base-building in our Desi communities.  Last year, 30 youth and adult allies from D.C., New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia, Massachusetts, Georgia, Louisiana, and Pennsylvania participated in our 3-day retreat to address issues of inequality, social justice and youth organizing through critical and Desi perspectives.

Desi refers to people whose "origins" are from Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, and the Maldives, but the diaspora spreads from Fiji to Trinidad, Kenya to the Persian Gulf, South Africa to Guyana, from Southall in Britain to Washington, DC and many places in between.  

ECSS is a FREE event and we want to keep it this way!  We need a little help to cover our primary costs : meals for young people, volunteers, and workshop coordinators and travel scholarships for youth outside of the NJ/NYC area.  

What exactly happens at ECSS? Watch the videos from DCDS 2013, DCDS 2012, and DCDS 2010 to see what really goes down!

What We Need

100% of all funds raised go directly to ECSS project costs.  All organizers (which include youth alumni and adult allies) are volunteers, and housing and facilitator/guest honorariums are either non-funded or incur very small expenses.

This year our overall budget is approximately $4,500.  This includes the following:

  • food (feeding up to 40 people, including healthy home cookin' from our kitchen)
  • transportation (including bus fare for out-of-state youth and speakers)
  • space rental (for 3 days)
  • $2500 for dorm residential space at Rutgers (for 2 nights)
  • miscellaneous (the essentials like photocopies, folders, chart paper, and pens)

Get involved

Any contribution helps, but even if you can't contribute here, we'd love any form of support from the community: 

  • Do you live in the NYC or NJ area and want to help us fundraise or locate housing options for youth participants? Let us know!  
  • Know youth age 15-21 who should apply? Application here! 
  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about the campaign! 

Please feel free to contact us with any questions or concerns at eastcoastsolidaritysummer@gmail.com. 

And don't forget to like our Facebook page!
story_txt:
ECSS is an organizing retreat for all South Asian & Desi-identifying youth! East Coast Solidarity Summer (formerly known as DC Desi Summer) 
will be held from July 24-26 in New Jersey, for youth 15-21 years old. ECSS is a
 radical space for young people to examine local and global justice 
issues through a critical lens. 
About ECSS
ECSS (formerly 
DCDS) has been a community-funded project for 5 years and running!  With
 the banning of ethnic studies in many universities and public schools around
 the U.S., increased surveillance and policing of immigrant and people 
of color communities, and the recent global and local uprisings a part 
of the Occupy movement, it is important to support critical spaces of 
learning, questioning and base-building in our Desi communities.  Last 
year, 30 youth and adult allies from D.C., New York, New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia, Massachusetts,
 Georgia, Louisiana, and Pennsylvania participated in our 3-day retreat 
to address issues of inequality, social justice and youth organizing 
through critical and Desi perspectives.
Desi refers
 to people whose "origins" are from Afghanistan, India, Pakistan, 
Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, and the Maldives, but the diaspora
 spreads from Fiji to Trinidad, Kenya to the Persian Gulf, South Africa 
to Guyana, from Southall in Britain to Washington, DC and many places in
 between.  ECSS is a FREE event and we want to keep it this 
way!  We need a little help to cover our primary costs : meals for young
 people, volunteers, and workshop coordinators and travel scholarships 
for youth outside of the NJ/NYC area.  
What exactly happens at ECSS? Watch the videos from DCDS 2013, DCDS 2012, and DCDS 2010 to see what really goes down! 

What We Need
100% of all funds raised go directly to ECSS project 
costs.  All organizers (which include youth alumni and adult allies) are
 volunteers, and housing and facilitator/guest honorariums are either 
non-funded or incur very small expenses.
This year our overall budget is approximately $4,500.  This includes the following:

food (feeding up to 40 people, including healthy home cookin' from our kitchen)
transportation (including bus fare for out-of-state youth and speakers)
space rental (for 3 days)
$2500 for dorm residential space at Rutgers (for 2 nights) 


miscellaneous (the essentials like photocopies, folders, chart paper, and pens)

Get involved
Any contribution helps, but even if you can't contribute here, we'd love any form of support from the community: 

Do you live in the NYC or NJ area and want to help us fundraise or locate housing options for youth participants? Let us know!  
Know youth age 15-21 who should apply? Application here! 
Help us get the word out and make some noise about the campaign! 

Please feel free to contact us with any questions or concerns at eastcoastsolidaritysummer@gmail.com. And don't forget to like our Facebook page!

story:
Join the worldwide smashbully.com Anti-Bullying movement. Please help us protect the children that can't protect themselves

We are raising capital to help make our world a better, safer place to live. Today 77% of kids get bullied! The challenge is that “bullying” alone is not illegal.

83 percent of girls, and 79 percent of boys report being bullied either in school or online.

75 percent of school shootings have been linked to harassment and bullying against the shooter.

Not shocking, students who are bullies as young adults continue the trend of abuse and violence into adulthood. By the age of 30, approximately 40 percent of boys who were identified as bullies in middle- and high school had been arrested three or more times.

Unfortunately, only 20-30 percent of students who are bullied tell adults or authorities about their situation.

Although bullies can exist just about anywhere, the three most common types of bullies are: School bullies, Cyber bullies and Workplace bullies.

The common result of bullying behavior is that the victim feels powerless. They never know when their bully is going to strike next. They also are confused as to why they are getting bullied in the first place. The reason why bullies pick victims really doesn’t matter. Bullies pick victims because that is what they do. Bullying behavior does not stop until bullies meet bigger or more powerful bullies.

Thanks to your support, Smashbully.com has a solution to this problem.

Smashbully.com has The Simple Secret to Bully Proof your Child and make them SAFE and CONFIDENT

"My parents didn’t know it but I was being bullied and picked on at school. That’s how I ended up in the hospital with an ulcer at the age of 11. I had more anxiety than any child should ever have to deal with."

My name is Master Robert F. Turley, and I have been training and teaching Martial Arts for over 30 years. I am extremely passionate about teaching kids how to defend themselves against Bullying. Why? Because the story above is mine. And I designed this System to teach your kids what to do before a Bully puts their hands on them, but more importantly, what action to take if they do.

I NEVER want your child to go through the emotional, physical or mental abuse I did. Knowing the Techniques in our system will instantly give your child the Confidence to Protect themselves against Bullying.

I wish I knew then what I know now. The techniques on SMASHBULLY.com will help you prepare your children or yourself to defend against a bully’s physical attacks. These are PROVEN Techniques designed to give anyone the confidence to defend against the most common bully attacks such as chokes, body grabs and clothing grabs.

Just follow the simple step by step videos to learn and practice Bully defense.

Check out The Courier Post News Papers review of Master Robert Turley

http://www.courierpostonline.com/story/news/loc...

About 28 percent of students in grades 6-12 experience some form of bullying according to bullying statistics 2013. Over 30 percent of students admit to bullying classmates and peers. When an adult intervenes in a bullying incident, it stops within 10 seconds or more about 57 percent of the time. This is why addressing the problem often cuts down on bullying incidents that happen daily and rescues many students from being bullied.

See some of the children smashbully.com has helped 

https://youtu.be/hV-NdGRuccA

Please HELP us! Pick a perk and change the life of a child today!

story:
Student Newspapers LIVE! Support Cre8ive Feed

Creativity enhances our lives. The most recent fashions. The hottest eateries. The latest movies. Animated graphics. Even a daily immersion of advertisements. 

Students who belong to The Art Institute of Tucson's Student Newspaper Association are the creators and  we represent the creators. We are the future of fashion, food, animation, film, video games, photography, graphic design, and advertising.  

We are your media-makers. We're starting a new hyperlocal student newspaper in which all our art programs collaborate. Cre8ive Feed will be our art school's source of news and inspiration, and we need help getting started. 

Chefs write restaurant reviews and food columns. Fashionistas write about sustainable, stylish threads. Animators discuss character and plot. Filmmakers discuss fellow students' documentaries. Designers design the whole shebang while photographers take pictures so readers can visualize the cutting edge blockbusters. And so on. And so forth. 

All the while, we are becoming professional and ethical leaders. We are accurate reporters. We are technically talented, engaged citizens of the community and world.  

Art is contextual. Art reflects the times. Artists must be aware.

The Art Institute of Tucson’s Student Newspaper Association is publishing its first-ever quarterly newspaper that provides accurate material relevant to and about the student body, faculty, staff, and alumni. 

Cre8ive Feed disseminates information pertinent to our creative community, and embraces our greatest freedoms of speech and press. With your help, Cre8ive Feed is coming alive. 

Help shape students' futures. Donate today. Get us off the ground. All proceeds will go to the printing of our first issue, which will be available print-only on June 5, 2015 for The Art Institute of Tucson's quarterly Family Day so we can show our skills off to our support system. Of course you will get a copy too. 

If you are a Tucson-based business owner in the creative industry and would like to donate or be featured in the paper, please contact us at cre8ivefeed@gmail.com or use IndieGogo. 

Tucson’s creative community is booming. The The Wall Street Journal calls Tucson a “mini-mecca for the arts.” The arts thrive in Tucson because we value the importance of creativity and our artists. Our community embraces the creative types and media-makers enhancing your lives.

story: I have been accepted into a Masters Program at OCAD University starting this fall! As part of my thesis I have proposed to transition my drawings into large scale installation works that will visualize "land as museum". Funds will be used to help with the recording of onsite performances, the documentation of installations, the production of large scale prints and to rent or purchase the necessary equipment and artifacts required for the hill excavations and installations. Help me build my hills!

story:
Bilingual books and Traumateddies for refugee children 

For the Young at Heart:

We reach the unreached. 

We go to the tricky places, to the people in informal settlements and the refugees beyond the reach of bigger organisations. 

We put Arabic-English books explaining and unpuzzling war into refugee children's hands ourselves. 

We are fast. We deliver books hot off the press. 

We have distributed 22,000 books to refugee and vulnerable children in the last 18 months.

We distribute to formal and informal schools, camp schools, and "schools" in informal settlements in the countries neighbouring Syria where the majority of the Refugees find themselves living in limbo. 

We created these books and traumateddies to help children face the realities they see every day, to help them understand their nightmares, and to manage their fears. 

We give children traumateddies and woolly clothes- knitted by lovely ladies across the UK and Ireland. 

We help with books that promote literacy, language, trauma and play. 

We give books to children who know nothing but war, and living with the impact of war.

We do not discriminate. Every child gets a book.

We make a difference.*  

*We know this because the teachers and students who volunteer to teach refugee children keep asking us to come back with more books.

We are now asked to donate books to children doubly displaced -that means they have had to move and seek refuge in a new place more than once - in Europe. 

We don't want to let any of them down.  

We share our adventures and our book and trauamteddy distributions with pictures on www.twitter.com/brehonadvisory 

We do this because every child needs an opportunity to learn and to love to read. 

You can help us. 

You can knit traumateddies for us - if you are time rich. 

You can donate money to fund more books - if you are time poor. 

You can be our champion  - follow us on social media if you too are learning to read and deal with nighmares and just like children's books. 

You can help us print more books, and knit more teddies, and woolly jumpers (or sweaters, if you're American). 

You can start to learn the ABCs of Arabic here with a child-friendly video of Arabic ABCs.

For the grown ups: 

We at Brehon Advisory in partnership with Asala Publishers create, publish, distribute and educate with bilingual Arabic-English books that deal with the effects of trauma, dislocation and war for Syrian refugees and vulnerable host community children.   100% of donations received go to produce  the books and traumateddies. 

Here's what Education Journal Middle East says about us in their September 2015 issue: http://edition.pagesuite-professional.co.uk/launch.aspx?eid=41d0086d-925f-4a45-8468-932b9932d88b&pnum=38

The technical stuff: The books are created by a team of PhD and ABD people (that means we love books so much we lived in a library for at least a decade). 

  • The books are written in Arabic first by a professor of child psychology. 
  • The books are shaped by talented Arab illustrators. 
  • The book are edited by English language professors and academic translators.
  • The books are the brain child of  a rogue professor of government in collaboration with a leading  children's book publisher. 
  • The books are distributed with an Arabic story teller wearing traditional dress. 
  • The traumateddies are knit by ladies across the UK and Ireland. 
  • The wool for the traumateddies is currently donated by an anonymous donor.
  • The woolly clothes, jumpers and sweaters, are created and delivered with love to the children we encounter where we see the greatest need.  (1,500 items to date).
What the teachers, schools and refugee volunteers tell us:

"We would be grateful for support with more books for teaching English to beginners and intermediate level." Irbid, Jordan (Headmistress) 

“You delivered. The psychology students read the books to the children. It was very good. I am glad. Thank you.” Chatilla, Beirut Lebanon (Headmistress)

“We will put a copy of each book in the library so that all the students can read the stories at school as well as at home.” 
Headmaster International College, (Bedawi)

“We think this project is a success. Thank you once again for including us in it. Please do let us know when this activity will be repeated in future as we would love to stay part of it .Please bear us in mind in future.” Relief & Reconciliation ( Bekaa).

“It was our pleasure to have you at our centers in Beirut and in Bekaa, we appreciate your great job ...God Bless your efforts.” 
"Great. Thanks so much for your continued support."  
(Beirut Bekaa) Jusoor 

“There is a primary school in my hometown that would benefit from the books. Let's make it work” (UNICEF)




Here's how to knit your traumateddy 

Trauma Teddy Knitting Pattern

Stuff:

Needle Size 10 3.25mm (or nearest)

Double Knitting Wool  (Yarn)

-Ideally 4 colours  (main colour for head and paws, trouser colours, jumper colour and scarf colour if you want a cosy teddy).

Step-by-Step:

1.  Cast on 10 stitches in main colour. Knit 10 rows (paw).

2.  Change to the trouser colour and Knit 30 rows. Make a second trouser leg the same way.

3.  Knit across all 20 stitches and work 16 rows.

4.  Change to jumper colour and Knit 24 rows.

5.  Change to the main colour for the head. Stocking stitch  for 5 1/2inches.

6.  Change to jumper colour and revert to garter stitch. Knit 24 rows.

7.  Change to trouser colour. Knit 16 rows.

8.  Knit 10 stitches. – put remaining 10 stitches on a holder

9.  Knit 30 rows.

10.  Change to colour for paw. Knit 10 rows. Cast off.

11.  Pick up 10 stitches from holder. Knit 30 Rows. Change to main Colour for paw. Knit 10 rows. Cast off.

12.  To make arms, using jumper colour. Pick up 8 stitches either side of right hand side neck/head join 16 stitches. Knit 20 rows. Change to main colour, Knit 10 rows for paws. Repeat on Left side.

13.  Sew up teddy leaving a hole in the crotch.  PLEASE STUFF WITH EU APPROVED TOY STUFFING and stitch closed.

14.  Sew diagonal top corners of head for ears.

15.  Embrodier a happy teddy face.

16.  For the scarf, cast on 60 stitches. Knit 4 rows and cast off. Then tie the scarf onto the teddy and sew securely to the back of the neck.

Helpful Links:

Garter stitch https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AKRAJEj7lcI

Purl – stocking stitch https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1gWJGGZbO4
