story:
Transitioning Foster Youth need jobs, but they often have the most difficulty getting and keeping them.

  • 70% of all California State Prison inmates are former foster youth
  • 36% of California foster youth become homeless within 18 months of emancipation
  • 51% are unemployed within 2-4 years of emancipation
  • 46% of emancipating youth in Los Angeles County do not complete high school

In Los Angeles County, over 1,400 young people exit the foster care system with no home, no job, no bank account, and nothing but their belongings in a trash bag. 

This is the beginning of life after foster care. 

Even unskilled jobs are hard to keep for former foster youth who lack the confidence and basic skills to be successful in the workplace. More than 50% of youth earn zero dollars in wages within the first four years after foster care. Those who do find jobs, earn an average of $7,500 per year - well below the poverty level. Most of our youth have had no role models to teach them social skills, be polite even on bad days, manage their emotions, and get back on their feet after a mistake.

With the emotional suffering that comes from growing up in the foster care system, it is difficult for our youth to function in a 9-5 job. We have seen many of our kids placed in good jobs, only to lose them soon after because they simply are not ready.

That is why The RightWay Foundation is creating a social enterprise specifically for foster youth. Our social enterprise will provide real life On the Job Training (OJT) that will enable our foster youth to get the same experience that traditional youth receive in a healthy home environment.  

With our social enterprise, we are creating a training ground for them, a safe place where they can learn how to be a responsible individual in the workplace, and get the guidance they need – where no one will give up on them, no matter what. 

We are currently raising funding to launch our new social enterprise, which will prepare our youth for the workforce, reduce homelessness, and lower the poverty rate for this population. Our new screen-printing business will hire our youth for 12-18 months, until they are ready to be placed in a job out in the real world.

Help Launch the Initiative by donating $25 to our cause! $100 will provide one youth with one day of screen-printing training. $250 will provide the full 3-day training for one of our youth!

__________________________________________________________________

About the RightWay Foundation

The RightWay Foundation seeks to revolutionize the delivery of job readiness training, education, and trauma-focused mental health services to foster care youth in Los Angeles County. Located in South Central, RightWay helps current and emancipated foster youth move away from pain and disappointment toward productivity and self-sufficiency.

In June 2012, RightWay launched Operation Emancipation, its flagship employment and life-preparedness program for foster youth transitioning to adulthood. The 8-week program is the first of its kind, pairing mental health services with job readiness and financial literacy training. Its results were startling - 70% of the youth that participated were placed in jobs or went on to higher education after the program.

RightWay is determined to continue this success and expand the numbers of youth we serve. We know that when foster care youth can access a proper support system, they are capable of financial independence.

Our screen-printing business will give our kids a chance to work in a supportive environment for a year or longer, so that they can get the guidance and training they need to become self-sufficient, confident adults.

But we can't do it without you! 

__________________________________________________________________

Risks and Challenges

Creating a viable social enterprise that will have a lasting impact on our youth will take innovative thinking and careful planning.  Our committee of entrepreneurs and business owners will provide guidance to RightWay to ensure we are creating a good model.  We will also be conferring with other successful social enterprises in Los Angeles, to hear their stories and learn from the best.

__________________________________________________________________

More about RightWay:

To learn more about the RightWay Foundation and Operation Emancipation, enjoy a 4-minute video about RightWay's 8-week mental health and job-readiness program.

RightWay is determined to continue
this success and expand the numbers of youth we serve. We know that
when foster care youth can access a proper support system, they are capable of
financial independence. Our screen-printing business will give
 our kids a chance to work in a supportive environment for a year or 
longer, so that they can get the guidance and training they need to 
become self-sufficient, confident adults.But we can't do it without you! __________________________________________________________________Risks and ChallengesCreating a viable social enterprise that will have a lasting impact on our youth will take innovative thinking and careful planning.  Our committee of entrepreneurs and business owners will provide guidance to RightWay to ensure we are creating a good model.  We will also be conferring with other successful social enterprises in Los Angeles, to hear their stories and learn from the best.__________________________________________________________________
More about RightWay:To learn more about the RightWay 
Foundation and Operation Emancipation, enjoy a 4-minute video about 
RightWay's 8-week mental health and job-readiness program.

story:
The 2015 Advice Project Global Leadership and Empowerment Summit needs your help!

Imagine...  10 teen girls and 8 women from Cameroon, Peru, India, the United States, and New Zealand will meet this summer for two weeks at a gorgeous eco-lodge in the Peruvian rainforest so that they can learn how to partner global problems with solutions. 
Listen to an interview about the summit with The Advice Project Cameroon Program Director, Fomuso Blessing Nabila, on Radio France Internationale with Laura Angela Bagnetto :

WHAT WILL HAPPEN DURING THE SUMMIT?

Every morning, our 2015 "fellows" will wake in their mosquito-netted beds to the sounds of howler monkeys and parrots, and amid the lush, green forest, they will spend their mornings writing articles and essays and create videos about teen and women's issues to share with the rest of the world. Together, they will become powerful voices for their communities by learning how to amplify their voices and form partnerships with teens and women that will last a lifetime.

(Fomuso, an Advice Project student in Cameroon, and Jay)

HOW WILL WE USE YOUR DONATION?

Our fellows include girls from an economically diverse backgrounds - most of them won't be able to attend our summit without your full support. 

Your donations will provide full scholarships, which will include: international and domestic flights, meals, lodging, visas for girls living in Cameroon, payments for guides and conservation biologists who will show us the rainforest, payment to hostel for two nights in Lima, and all additional program costs.

One of our fellows, Jay, is a 15-year-old first generation immigrant who crossed the border from Mexico into the United States as an infant with her mother. A writer, poet, and guitarist, Jay lives with her two younger sisters and brother in a Spanish-speaking home, and she has assumed many of the care-taking responsibilities of her siblings. Jay says that this trip is important to her because: "I have a lot of important things to say, but I'm not really sure how to say them all and sometimes I wonder if anyone is listening."

Another of our fellows, Fomuso, is The Advice Project's Country Director in Cameroon. Fomuso has been instrumental in leading our first international class, and she will be chaperoning a teen from Bamenda, Cameroon. Fomuso has been a support staff for several non-governmental organizations to offer peace-building services to women and children in her country.

Fomuso (center, back) and Advice Project students in Bamenda, Cameroon.


Our other fellows include a professor from Hunter College, three generations of women from one family (!), a yoga teacher who has worked for years with disadvantaged teens and children, and a group of teens dedicated to making the world a better place.

The Advice Project reached 100 girls and women through our FREE or donation-based writing and empowerment workshops in 2014. This year, we not only plan to double the number of young women we reach, but we will offer train-the-trainer sessions for any girl or women attending our summit who wants to return to her community to teach classes. 

The lodge where The Advice Project 2015 Global Leadership Summit will be held.


To the right is a list of perks our girls and women are excited to offer you in exchange for your donation. 

With gratitude, love, and light,

The Advice Project

For more information about the 2015 Summit, please visit: http://www.advicetomy13yearoldself.org/2015-global-leadership-and-empowerment-summit-for-teen-girls/about-the-summit/

story:
Secular Student Alliance at Frostburg State University (SSA at FSU)

We are a newly formed and officially recognized campus student group. We are looking to fund a non-profit business checking account to fund general business expenses and pay for invited speakers.

We Need A Non-Profit Checking Account

The details:

  • $100 to open the checking account. The account will be at the commercial bank branch located on campus.
  • This group is the culmination of 2 years of campus organizing!
  • Funds in excess of $100 will be deposited in the new account for general expenses, office supplies, tabling supplies and speaker fees.

The Impact

This campaign is crucial to opening a checking account:

  • We will have the ability to accept credit card payments.
  • Moreover, we will be able to efficiently fund campus speaking engagements and films.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please give our fledgling group  a "like" on Facebook.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks!

story:
Phil and Mary Bowker

At the beginning of April we are flying to Istanbul, Turkey, to start a cycle tour that will take us along the Silk Road to Kashgar, China. On this journey we plan to cycle through Central Asia, including the Pamir Highway, also called the “Roof of the World,” in Tajikistan near the Afghan border.  

We left our home, our house, and our jobs in Bend Oregon about six months ago. So far have cycled over 7000 km across the US and Mexico.

Training for teachers, rubber for the road.

This campaign is about raising money to help us offset the costs of cycling across Central Asia.  Our present budget allows us $20 per day.  This budget does not meet the costs of replacing some of our equipment and applying for the surprisingly expensive visas for many of the countries along the Silk Road.

We recognize the value of adventure in our lives.  In this spirit, we are raising money to support the outdoor and travel programs at Cascades Academy.  Mary is a former teacher at Cascades Academy, a non-profit independent school in our home town of Bend Oregon. Funds raised from this campaign will be used to send teachers on training courses that promote safe and environmentally responsible outdoor education.

What your support will help achieve.

Before we leave for our cycle tour across Asia on the Silk Road, we need to replace several components on our bicycles and apply for visas to enter the countries we will visit. Specifically, we need:

  • New Tires

  • New Drive Chains

  • Lots of Visas

Our journey continues to be inspiring for both us and the readers of our blog. A pair of our followers have just decided to give up their jobs and sail around the world!


Cascades Academy has identified several courses they feel will enhance their outdoor programs significantly.  Specifically, the courses they would like to send teachers on are:

  • Swift Water Rescue, a safety course that teaches the fundamentals of survival and rescue techniques in moving water.

  • Wilderness First Responder and/or Advanced First Aid, a course that teaches invaluable emergency medical skills in a backcountry setting.

  • Association for Experiential Education Conference, a meeting of the minds of educators committed to teaching and learning through experience

Cascades Academy is dedicated to providing exceptional experiential education opportunities for their students.  The quality training they seek is fundamental to operating a safe and environmentally sound outdoor education program.

Cost Breakdown:

Teacher Training

  • Swift Water Rescue                                            - $425, plus travel expenses

  • Wilderness First Responder/ First Aid        - $710/$225 per person

  • NSEE Experiential Education Conference  - $110, plus travel expences


                                                                               Total = $2405


Bicycle Refurbishment


  • New Schwalbe tires                                            - $297

  • Slime inner tubes                                                 - $123

  • Drive train                                                               - $100

  • Visas, across Silk Road                                      - $1100


                                                                                Total = $1620


                                                            Campaign Total = $4025

If we don’t reach our target goal

The funds will be split 60/40% between the Cascades Academy Outdoor program and our Silk Road cycle tour.  

Our Journey

The next portion of our cycle tour will take us along the Silk Road from Istanbul, Turkey to Kashgar, China, also passing through Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Krygistan. In Tajikistan, we plan to cycle the Pamir Highway. At 4665m, it is the second highest altitude international highway in the world. We are both experienced with cycle touring, and Phil is a mountain guide familiar with high altitude environments.  We are attracted to this route for it’s remoteness, scenic beauty and historical significance.

We feel so lucky to have the opportunity to do what we are doing.  We firmly believe outdoor and experiential education programs like the one at Cascades Academy inspire others to live and love the adventure of nature as much as we do.  

We are both passionate about being in the outdoors and preserving the environment. As a former member of the faculty, Mary understands how well Cascades Academy prepares students to take initiative, follow their passions, and become leaders in their communities.  Our hope is for students to develop a deep connection with the natural environment, and in turn, do what they can to protect what they love.

You can also check out the short video below that we made for Phil's 9 year old niece, Serenah.  We were honored that she chose us to report on for a school project on adventurers!  


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Share our campaign with others.

  • Do what you can to protect the wild areas you love.

  • Go on your own adventure and tell us

story:
We are the only democratic school in Minnesota and we need your help to produce our students' artistic visions this Spring (2015). "Mental Potluck" is a one of a kind, musical play created, written, and performed by Gaia youth. We use all funds on performance space rental, lighting and sound equipment, costumes, props, and supplies for our cast, age 5-18. Thanks for your support!

Perks include free tickets, DVDs of the show, unique souvenir props, autographs, eternal gratitude, Advertisement/public recognition in program, Gaia love and other wonderful treasures!

Gaia Democratic School is a small independent school for K-12 grade students. We believe in academic freedom and youth empowerment. Over 90% of our students are on school subsidized scholarships. We are a 501(c)3 nonprofit and do not discriminate in any way. Find out more about Democratic Education and Gaia at www.GaiaDemocratic.org

Even if you can't contribute financially, please help us get the word out about our Indigogo campaign and our upcoming show planned for May 2015. Thanks!

story:
Nanci Boutet 

Is the owner of Aquaholics Surf Shop and the director of Aquaholics Special Surfers. We have been offering this program since 2004.  Special Surfer Night started with three kids and the program has expanded from there.


Special Surfer Night

Special Surfer Night is a free program for children and young adults with physical, mental or emotional disabilities. We currently offer eligibility for 100 Special Surfers for each of the three summer nights we offer the program. We recruit hundreds of volunteers. We provide wetsuits, boards and adaptive equipment.  These Special Surfers often are unable to participate in many sporting activities due to mental or physical limitations. When they come surf with us, they are unlimited in the physical sense, since the ocean and board (and volunteers) do all the physical and mental work. 


What we need

Aquaholics Surf Shop has been funding this program since 2004. With 100 kids on the roster, it has grown into something the shop can no longer fund. Now that we have established 501C3 Non-Profit status, we're asking for more help. We need boards, wetsuits, adaptive equipment, insurance, storage/transport trailer, web services, legal services & staff. We have truly outgrown our little program. 

We plan to buy 96 boards (we have a few from previous donors THANKS AGAIN!), 200 wetsuits (so many sizes need to be in multiples, and we need overlap), 6 adaptive chairs and tumble forms, harnesses, and straps, a trailer or van for storage and transport, incidentals like wetsuit shampoo, rinse buckets, signage, color coded tee shirts,  paper for forms, promo supplies, insurance, legal help and staffing. We've been at this for 11 years, we've got it wired! The budget for this is more than $55,000, (a lot more,) but we'll be happy to get what we can! 

Here's what the budget looks like, for the event in it's entirety, we're hoping to raise all of the funds needed by surpassing our goal, but the indiegogo data suggests it's better to start small and GO BIG, so we're asking you to help us get a jump on the order by at least covering equipment costs. In case you're grabbing your calculator, this comes to $109,541. 

This is what it takes for the immeasurable fun value (for everyone involved) and life changing experience for these kids and their families. Join the fun, share a good vibe.


What You Get:

Perks

These perks are not "for sale". They are our tokens of appreciation for your donation for sharing and being involved in this wonderful program. Please think of us when you enjoy them. 
We have a Ton of cool stuff to thank you with, and we'll be putting up more stuff as we go, so keep checking!

NEW PERKS!

Sorry, other very important things have been demanding my undivided attention, but here are the promised Perk updates. We have a few more rabbits to pull out of the hat, but these are GREAT!

Hand knit infinity scarf by Heather K Ross


Sanuk Sidewalk Surfer boots, size 6. These run small. Donated by Kathleen Donnellon Dziadzio


Guay's Sunoco (Lower Village Kennebunk) Gift Certificate.


A "famous" Meredith Radford Designs Print https://www.facebook.com/MeredithRadfordDesign?fref=ts


A set of sterling earrings from Benoits Kennebunkport.


A fiberglass hand plane from Coastal Roots. Thanks to Apex Skim!


A hand made necklace by Michelle Lavigne.

A super warm, highly coveted Aquaholics Sherpa Fleece zipper hooded sweatshirt, donated by the family of Stephanie (Gidget) Tilley


A handmade necklace & earring set by Michelle Lavigne


See the "Perks" tab to grab these goodies!


STILL AVAILABLE!!!!!!!!!!!! Get em while they're hot!


Surprisingly, we still have the gift certificate from BANDALOOP, the BEST little secret spot in the 'Port. If you're a foodie, you'll go "loopy" for Bandaloop.

                                          


If you missed the Heroes Banquet (Randy Judkins as MC was a HOOT!) at the Nonantum Resort, you can still get a limited edition HEROES BANQUET TEE SHIRT. Don't forget to tell us your size and preference (ladies or men's, limited sizes and quantities) by emailing us at nanci@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org  Orange is for men, purple for the ladies.

                                 



And THEN, we have PIE!  From The MAINE PIE COMPANY. Deliciously Gluten Free!

                               


We have a gorgeous surf necklace (hand forged) by HONEY TRIBE JEWELRY. (You could wear this when you go to Bandaloop!) SOLD OUT!
Is your AAA MEMBERSHIP up for renewal? Get the perk and save yourself some moola!$$ SOLD OUT!

Maybe you need to get your "YOGIBO" mojo working'? SOLD OUT!

SHARE THE STOKE! You could just be interested in seeing these kids get their groove on... So for about a hundred bucks, we buy a wetsuit. 

For $500, we buy a surf board (we'll put your logo or name on it) 

                                            

Thanks Giant Ivy, Susan Finch (and kids) and Timber Island Builders!

or for $1000 we buy a big board (it's a rubber SUP) and gear (special chairs and harnesses...) for the mobility challenged (mostly kids in wheelchairs). We will put your logo on that board too, if you like!

                    

Eric Diana, a father of two of our summer surf campers from Ridgefield, Connecticut has donated a big board in memory of "Joey" Josephine Gay, a schoolmate and first grader with Autism who loved the water and is sadly missed. Thanks Eric, Joey, ride on. 

Read Joey's story from the Doug Flutie Jr foundation. http://www.flutiefoundation.org/ways-to-give/joeys-fund/index.html

Maybe you're already one of our Heroes? You probably need some BOOTIES & MITTS (claws, 3 finger)! Mmmmm, new gear, warmmmmm.

                                          

                         Thanks Marc Angellillo! (Our RipCurl Rep).


Winters sure are LONG here, maybe you need something to tide you over till it's warm out again? Thanks to Andrew Rost, we have the super duper perk of a refurbished retro version of NINTENDO NES with 4 games! 

                             


There's a GIFT CERTIFICATE for $200.oo to be used at Aquaholics Surf Shop, thanks to Gail Hackett Clarke! You MUST need some new flip flops, swim wear, sunscreen, a great backpack chair... This will do it!

Plenty to choose from with more on the way (the "rubber room" is out back).

Maybe you're the "artsy" type. Well, we have something for you too! This photo was donated by f8 Fine Photography and matted by Maine Art. The iPhone photo doesn't do it justice, but yes, this is a body surfer and YES that is snow on the ground! BRR you say? On any given day, when the waves are nice, you'll find DOZENS of surfers in the water. Ice, slush, Nor'Easter, you name it!

                                   


We have different perks for different giving levels, but feel free to decide what is your own level of stoke! We'll shout it from every rooftop (internet, interview, social media...)

How you impact our Supersurfers
This program is and has always been free. Often people suggest that we charge for this program. Not a chance. These kids and their families live everyday carrying a heavy load. Social, physical, mental. They have expenses we can't comprehend. This is our way of giving them an easy, free, no hassle mini vacation from the daily pressures of raising or caring for a kid or young adult (or being one) who constantly redefines what unconditional love requires. Pick a perk, contribute to our vision. Change a life, if even for a few hours. The vibe at these events is indescribable. You can feel the love. Some of these special surfers don't speak, walk or communicate. But when they surf, you can see the pure joy. 

Risks & Challenges

Some of these kids live very limited lives. Some shouldn't get their faces wet.  Think of life in a wheelchair. How exciting it must be to ride a wave? Yahoo(!), and you can see it in their faces. 
To ensure their safety, we have special crews of 6 "Special Ops" volunteers. We have lifeguards and EMTs. An ambulance comes and parks at the beach (also volunteer). The town waives the parking permit requirements.  The "Dog Monitors" keep the dogs away from fearful participants. The neighbors put up with the hundreds of cars bombarding their quiet streets.  Some neighbors provide water and electricity. Local establishments donate shuttle services. In short, this community ROCKS!  We have an amazing volunteer crew and OH!, we've received the Points of Light award... 

                                     


Fans, Heroes and Bios...

Hero Shonee Strickland 

My name is Shonee, and I have been a Special Surfer volunteer since the beginning. Every month in the Summer I look forward to Special Surfer night because you just feel so good after playing in the water with these kids! It's an addicting feeling, kind of like that first time you surf down the line, but even more fulfilling!

I have had parents come up to me afterwards in tears because they have never seen their child show such an emotional response to anything before... and that is an incredible thing to be a part of.

Many of these kids can't express themselves, but when they are cruising down these waves you see their faces light up and their eyes sparkle!

I also do this because I think it's important for these kids to do something fun without having their parents or caregivers hovering over them.  

Supersurfers 

Stephanie Tilley (AKA Gidget)

Scotty                                 AJ

Jack                                    Cam

There are a hundred kids to see smiling and enjoying the fun every third Tuesday of the summer months here in Maine. Please come share the joy.

Our biggest fan... (With Special Ops Surfer, Cam)

(She's actually kinda little).

 

Are you a fan? Please like and share.  Indiegogo has some great share tools, 
Aquaholics Special Surfers on Facebook;
https://www.facebook.com/aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org?ref=hl
Aquaholics Special Surfers Website
http://www.aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org/who-we-are.php
Twitter
https://twitter.com/Aquaholics_surf
Instagram
https://instagram.com/aquaholicsspecialsurfersdotorg/

This is our 2nd round on Indiegogo.  Our first campaign was great, we waited for Non-profit status to start spending the funds, and we've got more equipment ordered than money to pay for it, so help us keep this swell building.

If you'd like a more detailed information, a brochure and financials packet, please email Nanci Boutet at nanci@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org or Melissa Denis, our treasurer (and mom to that tall lanky dude on the chair board, Cameron Hutchins). Missy can be contacted at missy@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org
story_txt:
Nanci Boutet 
Is the owner of Aquaholics Surf Shop and the director of Aquaholics Special Surfers. We have been offering this program since 2004.  Special Surfer Night started with three kids and the program has expanded from there.





Special Surfer Night



Special Surfer Night is a free program for children and young adults with physical, mental or emotional disabilities. We
currently offer eligibility for 100 Special Surfers for each of the three summer nights we offer the program. We recruit hundreds of volunteers. We provide wetsuits, boards and adaptive equipment.  These
Special Surfers often are unable to participate in many sporting activities due
to mental or physical limitations. When they come surf with us, they are
unlimited in the physical sense, since the ocean and board (and volunteers) do
all the physical and mental work. 




What we need
Aquaholics Surf Shop has been funding this program since 2004. With 100 kids on the roster, it has grown into something the shop can no longer fund. Now that we have established 501C3 Non-Profit status, we're asking for more help. We need boards, wetsuits, adaptive equipment, insurance, storage/transport trailer, web services, legal services & staff. We have truly outgrown our little program. 

We plan to buy 96 boards (we have a few from previous donors THANKS AGAIN!), 200 wetsuits (so many sizes need to be in multiples, and we need overlap), 6 adaptive chairs and tumble forms, harnesses, and straps, a trailer or van for storage and transport, incidentals like wetsuit shampoo, rinse buckets, signage, color coded tee shirts,  paper for forms, promo supplies, insurance, legal help and staffing. We've been at this for 11 years, we've got it wired! The budget for this is more than $55,000, (a lot more,) but we'll be happy to get what we can! 
Here's what the budget looks like, for the event in it's entirety, we're hoping to raise all of the funds needed by surpassing our goal, but the indiegogo data suggests it's better to start small and GO BIG, so we're asking you to help us get a jump on the order by at least covering equipment costs. In case you're grabbing your calculator, this comes to $109,541. 



This is what it takes for the immeasurable fun value (for everyone involved) and life changing experience for these kids and their families. Join the fun, share a good vibe.








What You Get:
Perks

These perks are not "for sale". They are our tokens of appreciation for your donation for sharing and being involved in this wonderful program. Please think of us when you enjoy them. 
We have a Ton of cool stuff to thank you with, and we'll be putting up more stuff as we go, so keep checking!


NEW PERKS!
Sorry, other very important things have been demanding my undivided attention, but here are the promised Perk updates. We have a few more rabbits to pull out of the hat, but these are GREAT!


Hand knit infinity scarf by Heather K Ross



Sanuk Sidewalk Surfer boots, size 6. These run small. Donated by Kathleen Donnellon Dziadzio


Guay's Sunoco (Lower Village Kennebunk) Gift Certificate.


A "famous" Meredith Radford Designs Print https://www.facebook.com/MeredithRadfordDesign?fref=ts



A set of sterling earrings from Benoits Kennebunkport.



A fiberglass hand plane from Coastal Roots. Thanks to Apex Skim!



A hand made necklace by Michelle Lavigne.


A super warm, highly coveted Aquaholics Sherpa Fleece zipper hooded sweatshirt, donated by the family of Stephanie (Gidget) Tilley


A handmade necklace & earring set by Michelle Lavigne



See the "Perks" tab to grab these goodies!
STILL AVAILABLE!!!!!!!!!!!! Get em while they're hot!



Surprisingly, we still have the gift certificate from BANDALOOP, the BEST little secret spot in the 'Port. If you're a foodie, you'll go "loopy" for Bandaloop.


                                          

If you missed the Heroes Banquet (Randy Judkins as MC was a HOOT!) at the Nonantum Resort, you can still get a limited edition HEROES BANQUET TEE SHIRT. Don't forget to tell us your size and preference (ladies or men's, limited sizes and quantities) by emailing us at nanci@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org  Orange is for men, purple for the ladies.



                                 
And THEN, we have PIE!  From The MAINE PIE COMPANY. Deliciously Gluten Free!
                               



We have a gorgeous surf necklace (hand forged) by HONEY TRIBE JEWELRY. (You could wear this when you go to Bandaloop!) SOLD OUT!



Is your AAA MEMBERSHIP up for renewal? Get the perk and save yourself some moola!$$ SOLD OUT!







Maybe you need to get your "YOGIBO" mojo working'? SOLD OUT!





SHARE THE STOKE! You could just be interested in seeing these kids get their groove on... So for about a hundred bucks, we buy a wetsuit. 

For $500, we buy a surf board (we'll put your logo or name on it) 



                                            



Thanks Giant Ivy, Susan Finch (and kids) and Timber Island Builders!
or for $1000 we buy a big board (it's a rubber SUP) and gear (special chairs and harnesses...) for the mobility challenged (mostly kids in wheelchairs). We will put your logo on that board too, if you like!

                    
Eric Diana, a father of two of our summer surf campers from Ridgefield, Connecticut has donated a big board in memory of "Joey" Josephine Gay, a schoolmate and first grader with Autism who loved the water and is sadly missed. Thanks Eric, Joey, ride on. 
Read Joey's story from the Doug Flutie Jr foundation. http://www.flutiefoundation.org/ways-to-give/joeys-fund/index.html

Maybe you're already one of our Heroes? You probably need some BOOTIES & MITTS (claws, 3 finger)! Mmmmm, new gear, warmmmmm.



                                                                   Thanks Marc Angellillo! (Our RipCurl Rep).
Winters sure are LONG here, maybe you need something to tide you over till it's warm out again? Thanks to Andrew Rost, we have the super duper perk of a refurbished retro version of NINTENDO NES with 4 games! 

                             

There's a GIFT CERTIFICATE for $200.oo to be used at Aquaholics Surf Shop, thanks to Gail Hackett Clarke! You MUST need some new flip flops, swim wear, sunscreen, a great backpack chair... This will do it!


Plenty to choose from with more on the way (the "rubber room" is out back).Maybe you're the "artsy" type. Well, we have something for you too! This photo was donated by f8 Fine Photography and matted by Maine Art. The iPhone photo doesn't do it justice, but yes, this is a body surfer and YES that is snow on the ground! BRR you say? On any given day, when the waves are nice, you'll find DOZENS of surfers in the water. Ice, slush, Nor'Easter, you name it!



                                   


We have different perks for different giving levels, but feel free to decide what is your own level of stoke! We'll shout it from every rooftop (internet, interview, social media...)



How you impact our Supersurfers



This program is and has always been free. Often people suggest that we charge for this program. Not a chance. These kids and their families live everyday carrying a heavy load. Social, physical, mental. They have expenses we can't comprehend. This is our way of giving them an easy, free, no hassle mini vacation from the daily pressures of raising or caring for a kid or young adult (or being one) who constantly redefines what unconditional love requires. Pick a perk, contribute to our vision. Change a life, if even for a few hours. The vibe at these events is indescribable. You can feel the love. Some of these special surfers don't speak, walk or communicate. But when they surf, you can see the pure joy. 


Risks & ChallengesSome of these kids live very limited lives. Some shouldn't get their faces wet.  Think of life in a wheelchair. How exciting it must be to ride a wave? Yahoo(!), and you can see it in their faces. 
To ensure their safety, we have special crews of 6 "Special Ops" volunteers. We have lifeguards and EMTs. An ambulance comes and parks at the beach (also volunteer). The town waives the parking permit requirements.  The "Dog Monitors" keep the dogs away from fearful participants. The neighbors put up with the hundreds of cars bombarding their quiet streets.  Some neighbors provide water and electricity. Local establishments donate shuttle services. In short, this community ROCKS!  We have an amazing volunteer crew and OH!, we've received the Points of Light award... 

                                     



Fans, Heroes and Bios...
Hero Shonee Strickland 






My name is Shonee, and I have been a Special Surfer volunteer since the beginning. Every month in the Summer I look forward to Special Surfer night because you just feel so good after playing in the water with these kids! It's an addicting feeling, kind of like that first time you surf down the line, but even more fulfilling!
I have had parents come up to me afterwards in tears because they have never seen their child show such an emotional response to anything before... and that is an incredible thing to be a part of.
Many of these kids can't express themselves, but when they are cruising down these waves you see their faces light up and their eyes sparkle!
I also do this because I think it's important for these kids to do something fun without having their parents or caregivers hovering over them.  




Supersurfers 
Stephanie Tilley (AKA Gidget)




Scotty                                 AJ


Jack                                    Cam


There are a hundred kids to see smiling and enjoying the fun every third Tuesday of the summer months here in Maine. Please come share the joy.



Our biggest fan... (With Special Ops Surfer, Cam) (She's actually kinda little).

 Are you a fan? Please like and share.  Indiegogo has some great share tools, 
Aquaholics Special Surfers on Facebook;

https://www.facebook.com/aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org?ref=hl

Aquaholics Special Surfers Website

http://www.aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org/who-we-are.php

Twitter

https://twitter.com/Aquaholics_surf

Instagram

https://instagram.com/aquaholicsspecialsurfersdotorg/



This is our 2nd round on Indiegogo.  Our first campaign was great, we waited for Non-profit status to start spending the funds, and we've got more equipment ordered than money to pay for it, so help us keep this swell building.
If you'd like a more detailed information, a brochure and financials packet, please email Nanci Boutet at nanci@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org or Melissa Denis, our treasurer (and mom to that tall lanky dude on the chair board, Cameron Hutchins). Missy can be contacted at missy@aquaholicsspecialsurfers.org

story:
>>> Aller au texte en français

In (a bit more than) three words


We aim to break the cycle of poverty for the orphans and abandoned children in Congo by helping them realize their full potential and build up their confidence.

The method ?

  • The children are involved with the creation of a music album, where they are the writers of their own songs, based on their own experiences.
  • Through music and work as a team towards a common goal, they find a sense of belonging.
  • We teach them about the world they live in, about everyday heroes and inspiring personalities. We encourage them to share their experiences.
  • Their desire to learn is boosted, directly associating their hobbies to a pleasant learning experience.
« Music for the children in the DRC » allow them self-expression, to expand their minds and become a part of who they are. It gives them the opportunity to break the cycle of poverty and find their place in society.

It is a model that has proven itself countless times before!

Our goal is to inspire these underprivileged children and teenagers, to show them that they also have a chance to succeed in life, that they are talented and have the right to dream of a better life. We have to believe in them first so that they dare to believe in themselves.

CongoChance teams up with Hip Hop Saves Lives and Nunnovation for the project « Music for the children in Congo ».


The project


Music is a powerful tool. It is especially powerful, when it is used to inspire and reach children and teenagers, allowing them to learn about themselves and the world they live in, giving them back the confidence they lost as marginalized youth.

We will fly to the DRC to meet with these children and teenagers in Kinshasa. The method that is used to reach those children has proven itself multiple times before with street youth in the United-States, but also in Ghana and Liberia.

1.  The youth are encouraged to express themselves and think about their fears, their joys, and hopes, as well as the people that inspire them, encouraging them to reflect upon the world they live in. Together, they choose together a topic about which they are going to write.

2.  We help them translate their feelings into words and record a song, that they write and perform.

3.  We shoot a full-length video for each song and post them on Youtube, allowing the youth to have a voice beyond the borders and despite their situation.

4.  We take some time to reflect their work and what they have learned through it.

5.  Lastly, at the end of the project, a digital album is created and offered as a perk and sold online.

This program gives youth global education and the opportunity to express themselves through doing what they love, all while making a difference.

If the funds raised are high enough, we plan to expand our project to several cities in Congo to have a bigger impact and help more youth to find their voice.

If the goal is not reached, all the funds raised will support projects in the DRC for these same children.


About CongoChance

Paul is an abandoned child. Just like him, 20,000 children roam the streets of Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). They are orphans, teenagers or abandoned children.

Illiterate and often stigmatized, they have no possibility to afford education or to find a job, remaining in the cycle poverty.

To break this cycle, CongoChance takes in those children and give them a home. It aims to restore their place in the Congolese society by schooling them, as well as allowing them to grow through sport, theater and language lessons given by volunteers. We don't only want to get those children out from homelessness, we want to fill their childhood with happy memories and positive experiences.


About Hip Hop Saves Lives 

Hip Hop Saves Lives is a non profit organization that teaches humanity through Hip Hop, because Hip Hop came from humanity. Its original purpose was to keep the kids out of the streets, as an alternative to gangs and violence. In the words of its founder Kool Herc "it was just a way to reach the kids, it just happened to come through music".

The program proved to diminish violence, increase their thirst for learning, as the program educates teenagers about issues they may have never discussed and have no true interest in until they investigate it through rhyme.

We don't just teach humanity. We create humanitarians.


About Nunnovation  

Nunnovation gives a platform to the African Society to showcase their Innovation, Share their Success Stories, Celebrate Excellence and Reward Selfless Actions from Individuals, Organizations and Governments. The objective is to motivate Africans towards excellence for sustainable growth in the continent.


Thank you very much for making their voices heard!





>>> En français

En (un peu plus) de trois mots



Nous visons à briser le cycle de la pauvreté pour les orphelins et enfants abandonnés du Congo en les aidant à réaliser leur potentiel et renforcer leur confiance en soi.

La méthode ?

  • Les enfants sont impliqués dans la création d'un album de musiques, dans lequel ils sont auteurs et interprètes de leurs propres chansons, basées sur leurs expériences personelles.

  • A travers la musique et le travail d'équipe pour la concrétisation d'un but commun, ils trouvent un sentiment d'appartenance.

  • Nous les sensibilisons au monde qui les entoure, aux héros de tous les jours, à des personnalités inspirantes. Nous les encourageons à partager leurs expériences.

  • Leur envie de s'informer et d'apprendre est ainsi décuplée, associant directement, loisir et plaisir d'apprendre.

« Musique pour les enfants de la RDC » leur permet de s'exprimer, se libérer et s'ouvrir au monde, leur donnant ainsi l'opportunité d'enrayer le cycle de la pauvreté et trouver leur place dans la société.

C'est un modèle qui a déjà fait ses preuves à maintes reprises !

Notre but est d'inspirer ces enfants et adolescents des milieux défavorisés, leur montrer que eux aussi ont une chance de réussir dans cette vie, que eux aussi ont du talent et qu'ils ont le droit de rêver à une vie meilleure. Il faut tout d'abord commencer par croire en eux pour qu'ils osent croire en eux-mêmes.

CongoChance s'associe avec Hip Hop Saves Lives et Nunnovation pour le projet « Musique pour les enfants de la RDC ».


Le projet

La musique est un outil puissant. Il est particulièrement puissant lorsqu'il est utilisé pour inspirer et toucher ces enfants et adolescents, leur permettant d'en apprendre plus sur eux-mêmes et le monde dans lequel ils vivent. Le processus de création leur rend ainsi leur confiance perdue, ayant toujours été marginalisés.

Nous partirons en RDC pour rencontrer ces jeunes à Kinshasa. La méthode utilisée pour toucher ces enfants a déjà fait ses preuves de multiples fois dans les rues des Etats-Unis, mais aussi au Ghana et au Liberia. Nous voulons leur montrer le chemin et les encourager à s'exprimer, à écrire sur leurs peurs, leurs joies et leurs espoirs, écrire sur les personnes qui les inspirent, les encourager à réfléchir au monde dans lequel ils vivent.

  1. Les jeunes sont encouragés exprimer leurs peurs, leurs joies et leurs espoirs, à trouver l'inspiration à travers leurs modèles et le monde qui les entoure.
  2. Nous les aidons ensuite à transposer leurs sentiments en mots et nous enregistrons la chanson dont ils sont auteurs et interprètes.
  3. Une vidéo est filmée pour chaque chanson créée et nous la publions sur Youtube, permettant ainsi aux jeunes de porter leur voix au-delà des frontières et malgré leur situation.
  4. Nous prenons du temps pour les faire réfléchir sur ce qu’ils ont appris par leur travail.
  5. Finalement, à la fin du projet, un album digital est créé et vendu en ligne.

Ce programme donne l’opportunité aux jeunes de s’instruire et s’exprimer par ce qu’ils aiment faire, tout en ayant un impact positif.

Si les fonds rassemblés sont assez élevés, nous planifions d’agrandir le projets à plusieurs villes du Congo afin d’augmenter l’impact du projet et aider plus de jeunes à trouver leur voix.

Si l'objectif n'est pas atteint, tous les fonds recueillis serviront à financer les projets en faveur de ces mêmes enfants.


A propos de CongoChance

Paul est un enfant abandonné. Tout comme lui, 20'000 enfants èrent dans les rues de Kinshasa, la capitale de la République Démocratique du Congo (RDC). Ce sont des orphelins, des adolescents ou des enfants abandonnés.

Illettrés et souvent stigmatisés, ils n'ont aucun accès à l'éducation et à l'emploi, condamnés au cycle de la pauvreté.

Pour briser ce cycle, CongoChance accueille ces enfants et leur donnent une maison, une famille. Nous visons à leur redonner une place dans la société congolaise en leur donnant accès à l'éducation, mais aussi à des activités sportives, du théâtre, des lessons de langues données par des volontaires. Nous ne voulons pas seulement offrir un toit à ces jeunes, mais remplir leur enfance de souvenirs heureux et d'expériences positives.


A propos de Hip Hop Saves Lives 

Hip Hop Saves Lives est une organisation non lucrative qui enseigne l'altruisme aux jeunes grâce au Hip Hop. Son but original était de sortir les enfants des rues de New York, d'offrir une alternative aux gangs et à la violence. Avec les mots de son fondateur, Kool Herc : « C'était juste un moyen d'atteindre les jeunes, cela s'est simplement passé par la musique ».

Le programme de Hip Hop Saves Lives a déjà fait ses preuves, diminuant la violence et augmentant la soif d'apprendre de ces jeunes en leur ouvrant les yeux sur des problématiques dont ils n'ont auparavant souvent jamais parlé et pour lesquelles ils ne s'intéressaient même pas avant de s'y pencher par la rhyme.

Nous n'enseignons pas seulement l'altruisme. Nous créons des altruistes.


A propos de Nunnovation 

Nunnovation met à disposition de la société africaine une plateforme en ligne pour présenter leurs innovations, partager leurs histoires à succès, célébrer l'excellence et récompenser les actions désintéressées d'individus, d'organisations et de gouvernements. Leur objectif est de motiver la population africaine à tendre vers l'excellence pour une croissance durable dans le continent.


Merci beaucoup pour votre contribution à faire entendre la voix des jeunes et enfants marginalisés de la RDC !

Nous voulons leur montrer le chemin et les encourager à s'exprimer, à écrire
sur leurs peurs, leurs joies et leurs espoirs, écrire sur les personnes qui les
inspirent, les encourager à réfléchir au monde dans lequel ils vivent.

Les jeunes sont encouragés exprimer leurs peurs, leurs joies et leurs espoirs, à trouver l'inspiration à travers leurs modèles et le monde qui les entoure.

Nous
     les aidons ensuite à transposer leurs sentiments en mots et nous
     enregistrons la chanson dont ils sont auteurs et interprètes. 
Une
     vidéo est filmée pour chaque chanson créée et nous la publions sur Youtube,
     permettant ainsi aux jeunes de porter leur voix au-delà des frontières et
     malgré leur situation.
Nous
     prenons du temps pour les faire réfléchir sur ce qu’ils ont appris par
     leur travail.
Finalement,
     à la fin du projet, un album digital est créé et vendu en ligne.


Ce programme donne l’opportunité aux jeunes de s’instruire
et s’exprimer par ce qu’ils aiment faire, tout en ayant un impact positif.
Si les fonds rassemblés sont assez élevés, nous planifions
d’agrandir le projets à plusieurs villes du Congo afin d’augmenter l’impact du
projet et aider plus de jeunes à trouver leur voix.
Si l'objectif n'est pas atteint, tous les
     fonds recueillis serviront à financer les projets en faveur de ces mêmes enfants.




A propos de CongoChance



Paul est un enfant abandonné. Tout comme lui, 20'000 enfants èrent
dans les rues de Kinshasa, la capitale de la République Démocratique
du Congo (RDC). Ce sont des orphelins, des adolescents ou des enfants abandonnés.


Illettrés
et souvent stigmatisés, ils n'ont aucun accès à l'éducation et à
l'emploi, condamnés au cycle de la pauvreté.


Pour briser ce cycle, CongoChance
accueille ces enfants et leur donnent une maison, une famille. Nous
visons à leur redonner une place dans la société congolaise en
leur donnant accès à l'éducation, mais aussi à des activités
sportives, du théâtre, des lessons de langues données par des
volontaires. Nous ne voulons pas seulement offrir un toit à ces
jeunes, mais remplir leur enfance de souvenirs heureux et
d'expériences positives.




A propos de Hip Hop Saves Lives  


Hip Hop Saves Lives est une
organisation non lucrative qui enseigne l'altruisme aux jeunes grâce
au Hip Hop. Son but original était de sortir les enfants des rues de
New York, d'offrir une alternative aux gangs et à la violence. Avec
les mots de son fondateur, Kool Herc : « C'était juste un
moyen d'atteindre les jeunes, cela s'est simplement passé par la
musique ».


Le programme de Hip Hop Saves Lives a
déjà fait ses preuves, diminuant la violence et augmentant la soif
d'apprendre de ces jeunes en leur ouvrant les yeux sur des
problématiques dont ils n'ont auparavant souvent jamais parlé et
pour lesquelles ils ne s'intéressaient même pas avant de s'y
pencher par la rhyme.


Nous
n'enseignons pas seulement l'altruisme. Nous créons des altruistes.




A propos de Nunnovation  



Nunnovation met à disposition de la
société africaine une plateforme en ligne pour présenter leurs
innovations, partager leurs histoires à succès, célébrer
l'excellence et récompenser les actions désintéressées
d'individus, d'organisations et de gouvernements. Leur objectif est
de motiver la population africaine à tendre vers l'excellence pour
une croissance durable dans le continent.


Merci beaucoup pour votre contribution à faire entendre la voix des jeunes et enfants marginalisés de la RDC !

story:
Short Summary

Education is the key for a better life and better society.

In 2010 and 2011, students marched in the streets of Santiago de Chile, claiming for free and good quality education.

Polititians have been discusing how to improve it, but from my point of view the QUALITY topic haven´t been implemented, not even planned yet.

My project is simple, but at the same time, with a lot of projections:

  • A Free web site where students as a way of learning can upload video classes to their classmates. They can use their creativity, have fan, and in their own local accent and slang, teach school topics.
  • Students from all the country, that don´t have good teachers, no good classmates, will have the opportunity to learn from others. The government is installing internet in many rural schools, but there is not many spanish lessons on the web. With one site organised, it will be easier to find video classes. 
  • Students will be able to rank classes, so the best of them will be easily founded later on. They might even get motivated to explain a topic in a better way.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to keep this personal project that I already started I need funds for:

  • Promote the concept in schools with their directors.
  • Promote among students making presentations and also in social networks.
  • Get help to filter videos that have appropriate language. That requieres people revising the videos.
  • If the money is good enough, to develop a better website.
You will get the satisfaction on helping for a good cause, and will be posted in the Thanks page (not implement yet) of the web site.

The Impact

As I see the impact could be a lot, but if we help a couple of kids to learn it will be worth. Among others my plans are:

  • Promote the usage of the site in Santiago de Chile.
  • Promote VideoClases in regions in Chile.
  • If the reaction is good, my plan is to expand to other spanish speakers countries in Latinamerica.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help with money, but also help to promote Videoclases in the following alternatives:

  • Promote the page in facebook about VideoClases or the website VideoClases.org
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to get the funds!
  • Help me promoting in media, social networks or email about this campaign!
  • Introducing me to Bill Gates :-)

story:
The Challenge

Can we provide quality early education to ten million children under age six in urban slums by 2020? 

Around the globe, more than a hundred million children under the age of six who are living in slums do not get the quality education to prepare them for primary school and to be competitive in society. New research shows that early education, both formal and informal, starting from zero to six years, is the critical and unmet need of this century. Unfortunately, most parents and care givers do not provide adequate early childhood development. Government, NGOs and private sector efforts are not enough to solve this challenge. Social enterprises may be an effective option to address this issue; however, building social enterprises will be difficult. 


Why our project

•Simple

•Transferrable

•Cost efficient

•High reach

•Local integrity

•Expandable


In order to reach the millions of children around the world with no access to education, we are planning to partner with large consumer goods companies in order to use the empty space on the back of labels to place educational material. This educational material will be tailored to specfic regions and ages, in order to allow and encourage care givers to interact with children with fun and accessible ways. The activities will incorporate a thermochromic paint layer, which, once touched will reveal the answer to the question, allowing for feedback and interaction. This element also allows for the transferability of the activities to others, and thus, communities form around the sharing of activities. 

Below are a few key details explained, but if you have any further questions, please do not hesistate to get in contact with the team. 


Design Elements



Parent’s element

•Provides useful tools and hints

•Shows age range

Children’s element

•Tailored to region and age

•Different education elements (Maths, Soft skills, Language activities)

Feedback element

 •Heat sensitive (thermo chromic)

•Answer displayed under element

•Used for sharing

Community element

•The series make a textbook to act as community teaching aids


Our Impact

Society

•Provide worldwide education

•Create a better, sustaining life

•Micro-retail, self-employment

•Celebrating motherhood




Other Ways You Can Help


•Help us get the word out 

•Use the Indiegogo share tools

story:
Every year President Bill Clinton gives a challenge to the university students worldwide through the HULT Prize competition. The challenge for 2015 is to improve the early childhood education at urban slum area. Five of us from BRAC University, Bangladesh formed a team to provide a solution and we came up with a prototype; we named our brand ‘Sneho’.

The core product of our solution is a ‘Durable Alphabet Mat’ with different design for different age group. What we found is that the kids from slum areas drop out from schools because they start to see alphabets and receive education at the age of 4-5 years. The main difference between the early childhood education of a privileged kid and the kids from slum areas is the early exposure to the learning material. Thus we have designed our alphabet play mat which is:
  • Printed on durable outdoor PVC vinyl, the same material used on billboards beside streets and highways.
  • It costs only US$3 to print and distribute 1 mat; less expensive than a cup of coffee.
  • We can distribute it to the target group at zero cost to them.
  • The mat is washable, multipurpose and weather proof. A highly suitable learning material for slum areas which will be with the kids 24/7.
  • Mat with different design for different age group. Such as very basic mat for the age of 6 months to 2 years, mat with advanced elements such as 'idea of time (clock)', 'color recognition' for the age group of 2-4 years. A mat for 0-6 months target group can be designed to encourage breast feeding and natal care. Following is a sample design of an advanced mat which will help to learn time and color:

  • Kids love game and games have different stages that they have to win. We will monitor the progress of a child and reward him/her with next mat with appropriate design to have a sense of game and fun in learning.
  • Older kids in the slum areas will become the facilitator of the younger group while playing on the mat, making the learning process sustainable at slum area.
  • Parents of the kids at slum do not need to go through any training or expense to be able to facilitate the learning. The mat is designed to reduce word gap by having a visual impact. 
  • Location and culture independent. Design of the mat can be updated easily to meet the local demand.
  • Download and read a report on our full product and services and please visit our website www.sneho.org for more information.

What We Need & What You Get

Our initial target is the Korail slum area in Dhaka city of Bangladesh. Our estimates show that there are about 40,000 people living in that close community with about 10,000 kids. We want to distribute at least 5000 durable alphabet mats to the age group of 2-4 & 4-6 years old kids. Each mat will cost us $3 and in total we are seeking US$15,000 to cover the production cost.

If we are able to raise $15,000, it will allow us to provide early childhood education (ECE) material to 5000 kids at slum. For every extra $3, one more child will be helped. There are thousands more kids in need of ECE and don't stop donating at $15,000. The more money we raise, the bigger impact we will have.

BRAC is the largest NGO of the world and as a team from BRAC University, our costs to travel to and from the slum area will be covered by the official vehicle. Our time for this project is totally free as we are helping these kids to come out of the cycle of the poverty.

We cannot build a better society without sharing the cost of social improvement and you will become the part of the next wave of early childhood change by contributing to this cause. $3 or even $30 to sponsor 10 mats may not put a dent on your wallet but it will change the life of a kid and beyond. Won’t you feel good to be able to help in this noble way? This video shows the expression of a 13 months old baby when she sees the play mat for the first time.

We then went to a urban slum area to distribute our product and watch the impact in this video. Don't you want to gift the same joy to thousands of kids at slum? Please donate if you care.


The Impact

The impact is straightforward. Currently kids at slum do not have appropriate early childhood education material which can assist to reduce word gap. This mat will make alphabet a part of their household and learning will not seem so hard once they will get to the level of formal education at schools. At the end, the number of school dropouts will be reduced and these kids will break the cycle of poverty with their education.

We randomly picked a family living in slum and given a mat to Sadia (4 years) and her brother Belal (2 years) shown in the image below. The sister took the leadership straightway and started to help her brother play on the mat and learn. We expected this outcome but we were surprised to see such immediate impact.

The family and the community appreciated the product as well. They were very happy to receive a learning material for their kids which is very suitable for their living environment. They appreciated the fact that the product does not involve any technology and easy to understand and maintain. They want more of it!

We have seen teams answering this challenge with technology such as mobile push message and other means of innovation. But we believe technology alone is not the answer to a social problem. We need to establish a process which tackles the early childhood education issue at its root and prepare kids for the formal education at the age of 5-6 years. Sneho offers such solution with its products and services, and we are aiming to make a big impact in the target community.  Following is our prototype:



Your Money is in Safe Hands

Your fund is secured with us and we provide transparency in many ways:

  • Our project and finance is mentored by one of the faculty members of BRAC University.
  • The project is fully supported by BRAC Business School, BRAC University, Bangladesh. We are existing students at the university.
  • We have been featured in national media, international competitions and social media.
  • Our website will show the details of all contributor if the donor wishes to disclose their details. See sponsors here: http://www.sneho.org/sponsors
  • Our website will show the details of every recipient of your contribution. See recipients here: http://www.sneho.org/recipients
  • We will track the process of each recipient over the time and progress reports will be published online to show the impact of your contribution.
  • Please visit our website www.sneho.org and feel fee to contact us for more details. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, you can at least help us spread the word. Please ask your friends and family to join our cause by donating $3 i.e. sponsoring a durable alphabet mat for kids at urban slum areas. 

Our Partners

    

Scholastica: http://www.scholasticabd.com - Helping us with awareness program and fundraising.

BRAC University: http://www.bracu.ac.bd - Providing all types of support to let 'Sneho' compete at HULT Prize.

BIZ BEE University Student Club: Assisting with fundraising campaign.

UpoharBD: http://www.upoharbd.com - A prominent gift delivery service in Bangladesh. We are grateful to receive funding and administrative support from UpoharBD. They are also helping 'Sneho' to seek fund from Bangladeshi people living overseas. 

Spreeha: http://www.spreeha-bd.org - A local NGO supporting us with durable alphabet mat distribution. 

IABC: International Association of Business & Communicators - All team members of Sneho are the member of this student club at BRAC University. All members helped us with their support along the way. 

Central Women's College: http://www.cwcedu.com - One of the first and leading private girls' college in Bangladesh, whose teachers have helped Sneho by donating and thus sponsoring mats.

Dhaka City College: The teachers of Dhaka City College contributed hugely for Sneho and the students helped spread Sneho's idea via social media. 

BRAC: https://twitter.com/bracworld - Lets not forget where it all started! BRAC's culture is in the vain of Sneho and we were able to reach a bigger audience by their Tweet and re-Tweet. A special thanks goes to BRAC US CEO  @SusanDavisBRAC

story:
Short Summary

F.A.W.K. - Foundation for Advancement of Women on Kilimanjaro has been regularly interviewing candidates and is proud to introduce our first student, Jessica Peter! For a shared one time cost of $3500 we can fund her education and training, changing her life forever. Help us provide Kilimanjaro with it's 5th licensed, female guide!

The primary function of F.A.W.K., is to oversee the progress of candidates and facilitate direct sponsorship campaigns to support the education, licensing, and internship costs necessary for women to obtain sustainable employment as guides on Kilimanjaro. The physical requirements to work this mountain 2 to 4 weeks per month is extraordinary, and we aspire to elevate the socioeconomic status of the women who are committed to taking on this physical and courageous career. The discrepancy in pay and social status between a porter and a guide is significant, as is the physical toll and academic knowledge required. There is an estimated 30 female porters operating on the South side of Kilimanjaro; over 400 men. Currently, only 4 of the women working Kilimanjaro, are educated guides.

Follow our mission: https://www.facebook.com/womenonkilimanjaro

What We Need & What You Get

Fundraising for direct sponsorship and securing private donors, will be an on going mission for F.A.W.K. - Foundation for Advancement of Women on Kilimanjaro, as the number of girls we seek to advocate for, increases. Our first student Jessica Peter, has already completed the course in tourism and to finalize the process we've assessed the costs for her mentorship and licensing through Nyange Adventures, as follows:

  • English classes provided by African Impact 4 days/week FREE!
  • Bus fare to Moshi for training and English class attendance $2.50/week for one year, $130US
  • Mandatory training and licensing through Kilimanjaro National Park & Nyange Adventures, $300US
  • One year paid internship and hands on training with Nyange Adventures Ltd., $2200US
  • Weather appropriate, quality gear and shoes necessary to work and sleep on the mountain. $600US 
  • ** remaining funds are to cover the administrative costs associated with Indiegogo/bank fees, any extra will be rolled back into the F.A.W.K. program

I have the utmost confidence we will reach our goal. The funds appropriated, regardless of what they are, will be used to begin the process of: busing Jessica to English classes, the upcoming National Park licensing to take place in May, and the start of her paid internship. In addition, any funds generated beyond our goal will be dutifully managed into the budget of the next young woman we intend to directly seek sponsorship for, and so on.

The Impact

Many women in the local area are up against family and cultural odds when seeking a career, not just one on the mountain. At just 16 years old, Jessica visited Lake Manyara National Park on a school trip, and her eye happened to catch one of the few female guides operating in Tanzania. Never before had she considered a career in guiding as a feasible option but through this encounter she became inspired to pursue her studies at a local college. Jessica was extremely blessed, her mother and brother supported her dreams and funded her education; she successfully graduated in 2013. Unfortunately, unemployment is soaring in this region and many local companies do not adhere to fair hiring practices for women. Jessica has been boldly applying for positions as a porter on Kilimanjaro and has been routinely overlooked for the past 2 years.

F.A.W.K. was formed with reputable and well organized allies. NGO was instituted to set up a basic framework, set objectives, and financial expectations.  Nyange Adventures, a local tour and guide company, is respected throughout the region for fair wages, employment practices and social outreach. They are an integral part of this program and without them it would not be possible. The support structure at Nyange, and hands on training they are offering, will introduce this young woman to the best chance she will have at succeeding as a self- supporting woman. Their staff of skilled and socially adept mountain guides, are excited for the opportunity to mentor her in this process. We hope that then, Jessica too will be the inspiration for many girls to come. When we met with her about this opportunity her words cemented the motivation behind this project, Jessica said, 'I was just surviving in the dark until now, and now there is light.' Help us bring light over the mountain, now and many more times to come.

Risks & Challenges

In light of the fact that there is already a number of women working the mountain or interested in working, the biggest challenge we face is finding women who have family support, confidence in themselves, and are committed to the time table it takes to complete; education, training, proficient English and licensing. Many young women are expected to marry or have children but even if they do choose to have a family, if they are committed to having a career, they do not need to give up guiding or a career in tourism.  African Impact Director, Gill Carter, has also partnered on this initiative and will provide free English classes, and guidance through a local women's support network.

Other Ways You Can Help

I certainly understand that some folks find themselves more fortunate than others and in a seemingly sea of worthy causes we must all pick the ones most dear to our hearts. It is with this notion I implore you, that even if you feel you are unable to make a donation at this time, your support through social media, friends and family and word of mouth is invaluable to our cause.

proud to introduce our first student, Jessica Peter! For a shared one 
time cost of $3500 we can fund her education and training, 
changing her life forever. Help us provide Kilimanjaro with it's 5th licensed, female

internship costs necessary for women to obtain sustainable employment as

work this mountain 2 to 4 weeks per month is extraordinary, and we aspire to

social status between a porter and a guide is significant, as is 
the physical toll and academic knowledge required. There is an estimated 30 female porters operating on the South side of Kilimanjaro; over 400 men. Currently, only

story:
Making A Difference By Education


Our students are going to change the music and entertainment industry.

Be part of the future! Support Florida Academy of music & entertainment 

as we establish a firm educational program for the entertainment industry 

that inspires students to be hands on and knowledgeable in their field of study. 

Your funds will help us secure the space to grow and continue contributing to

 a young and growing community through the first phase of establishment.


                                                                    What We Need

1. Building

2. Equipment

3. Working Capital for Instructors 

Donations over $100 will be recognized with their names engraved on a brick on a

 T-Shirt. These bricks represents the building blocks contributed by you, 

supporting to make the vision of F.A.M.E Recording Arts school a reality.

Donors who contribute $100 or more will receive a charitable donation receipt 

for tax purposes.


                                                                        

                                                                        Impact

Mission Statement

To prepare students not just with educational knowledge 

but hands on experience in and out of the classroom.

We also emphasize that student involvement in community and environmental

 issues is essential for progress in a changing economy and society. 

Our understanding of local, regional, and international communities provide

 the foundation for how our students can positively impact the world around them.



F.A.M.E 

RECORDING ARTS SCHOOL

FLORIDA ACADEMY OF MUSIC & ENTERTAINMENT LLC

RECORDING ARTS COURSE

This course will consist of 5 key subject, that will prepare you, 

for a successful career and any field in the music industry.


*ARTIST DEVELOPMENT

1.Public Relation

2.Work Ethic

3.Networking (Local Artist and Producer)

4.Marketing

5.Indep/Major Distribution

6.Creative Writing

7.Copyrights

8.How to book Gig’s

9.Make a Social media present (Online & Community)

10. Stage Performs


*PRODUCTION/ AUDIO ENGINEERING

1.Intro to Control Room Equipment and Set up

2.Intro to DAW (FL Studio & Studio One) 

3.Recording/ Vocal Room

4.Mixing and Mastering 


*MUSIC BIZ GENERAL KNOWLEDGE

1.Music Industry Terms and Language

2.Independent vs Signed (Record Labels)

3.Different Jobs, Titles, and Duties


*EVENT COORNATOR

1. Event Promotion 

2. Event Services 

3. Event Sales

4. Club Event Operations 

5. Lodging Operations

6. Networking (Venus)

This will be a 8 month program, with not just book work and studio time, 

but actually working in the field via OJT, through local record labels, 

assisting producers, and local artist to showcase talent, 

also finding events within central FL area.


                                                 Other Ways You Can Help

We need your support. Even if you are unable to contribute a financial donation, 

you can still help us:

Please share our vision! 

Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.

Act now and use the Indiegogo share tools to let your circles, your tribes,

 your friends and your families know about the important initiative 

F.A.M.E is driving forward.

Speak to your local school about what they are doing to prepare their 

students for the future, how they are engaging and inspired to make a difference

 in the entertainment industry.

story:
Short Summary

The Trenton Council of Civic Associations has given monetary awards to the winner of 'Student of the Year' at our annual awards banquet for some time.  In honor of Don's decades of extensive involvement in Trenton's civic health, we are naming the scholarship the Don Wallar Memorial Scholarship and would like to increase the amount given to $1000.

What We Need & What You Get

Each year, the TCCA has relied on a sponsor to fund that year's student of the years scholarship.  Now, we'd like to crowd-source that responsibility, giving the hundreds of people that cared for and knew Don Wallar a way of continuing in his footsteps in civic engagement.  We need: anything from $1 up?  You get: warm fuzzies on your inside knowing you honored a great man, and helped an upcoming student from Trenton.

The Impact

School is expensive and getting more so every year, so your donation will help cover costs for a graduating senior as they begin their college career.  More impactful will be the connection made between that student and the city they come from, showing support and encouragement as they 'leave the nest.'

Other Ways You Can Help

Give, share, spread the word, attend the awards banquet, and think about a time when Don made you smile.
