story:
Short Summary

Audax Solutions Ltd is an e-learning, training, and assessment solutions company based in Lagos, Nigeria.

Our code school program is an initiative launched in 2013 to teach children aged 5 -16 in Lagos area primary and secondary schools, computer programming using Scratch, HTML/CSS and JavaScript, which started in 2013. In 2014, we won a Google Rise Awards to assist in promoting Computer Science Education to the less privileged children in Nigeria. 

Together with our local and international partners, we believe that teaching children programming is essential to develop their problem-solving, creative and communication skills.  We hope to foster an interest in technology, by learning how to build a website, games and apps by the end of the program. 

To further our efforts to reach more under-served girls and boys in public schools and orphanages, often with little or no access to modern technology, we have created this campaign to raise funds that would allow the children participate in the summer code school 2015 for FREE!. Our Summer Code School will hold in two sessions from 3rd August - 28th August 2015 and 31st August - 2nd October 2015, where we aim to train 500 girls and boys from Lagos State Motherless Babies Homes, Vigilant Heart Foundation, Paradigm Initiative Nigeria, and Gbara Public School, Lagos Nigeria.

We do believe that teaching programming skills is essential to preparing young Nigerian children to move forward in the 21st century and provides a strong competitive advantage sorely needed. Our vision is to embed computer programming as an important part of our school curriculum so every African child will start at a young age. 


What We Need & What You Get

We therefore seek to raise money that will cover tuition, lunch and transport for a month. Estimated costs for study and writing materials, trainer and equipment rental  per child is 200 dollars/month. 

We are expecting to get funding for at least 100 students however the more funds we raise, the more students we train. After the one month training, they become part of the weekly Audax Code Club for sustainability and impact, efficient mentoring and career growth. The students will be trained at a state-of-the-art training facility that has over 150 laptop computers to facilitate learning in a comfortable and safe environment.

We have developed partnerships with experienced developers and teachers who are capable of teaching relatively complex concepts in a manner that will be accessible to children. Our teachers are experienced at handling groups of school-aged children while providing one-on-one attention as needed.


The Impact

The children we teach will immensely benefit from the computer education program. Some of the children we have taught never used a computer before but they ended up creating a website and learning the fundamentals of programming. One of the best things about learning how to code is that children do not need to have prior experience of using a computer or learning how to type. Our method of teaching inspires creativity, critical thinking, and problem solving.

Encouraging programming classes for children helps them realize that they can achieve a lot of success from acquiring the skill and it empowers them in the society. They also get exposure to the Google Rise community and local Google partners that encourage and mentor them by providing more resources. 

Most public schools do not have an adequately equipped computer room and the any computer science curriculum is outdated. However at Audax summer code school, the programs are all project based so the children will end up building tangible applications.  We assign one computer to a child and one trainer to ten children to making learning easy. We have previously had a few local companies sponsor 15-30 children from orphanages, who have learnt to create exciting things like games, e-cards, animated characters etc. This year, we are hoping for increased participation of at least 300.

Risks & Challenges

Training at Audax comes with minimal risk and challenges as we are located in a serene and controlled environment with adequate equipment to facilitate learning.

Other Ways You Can Help

All contributions are welcome, but if you can't make a contribution, you can share the campaign to your friends and family via the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
April 2015

Dear Students, Friends, Family, Partners, and Prospector Supporters!

It is time to take our school to the next level! I am pleased to inform you that I will be significantly upgrading our school facilities this summer by relocating to a new location at 393 Dundas Street East, just east of Spadina at Beverley (a 5 minute walk from our current location). We plan to move all our classes to the new location on June 1st, 2015 and there will be no disruption for the summer term classes.

The new space is 5,550 square feet. To put this into perspective, it is roughly a little more than 5 times the size of our existing training area. It is located on the second floor with elevator and stair access and will be wheelchair accessible.

We plan to begin renovations in May. The vision of the layout will include an extra large training area, a large training area, and several washrooms. We will expand our programs in the future to offer pre-shool classes, more childrens classes, classes simultaneously for parents and children in separate rooms, beginner, intermediate, and advanced martial arts kung fu classes, meditation and Ch’an workshops, tai ji yang and chen styles, pregnancy exercise programs, public events, and more! A high capacity ventilation system ensures a well controlled and healthy air environment.

The new space will also include the first Shaolin Tea Cafe in Canada, offering a unique and peaceful  place for people to sit down and enjoy high quality tea and snacks while enjoying the energy of the environment.

This is an important strategic venture as it will become a stronghold for traditional Shaolin culture in Canada and a basis for growth and expansion. It is my extended vision in support of my Shi Fu’s vision, which is to help people and communities through the traditional Shaolin arts.

I want this space to be a place that you will continue to be proud of. The profits will be used for projects to help children, adults and seniors in need; the deaf, the blind, the poor, and those with other disabilities. Profits will also be used to build the first Shaolin Retreat Centre at Rice Lake where we already have access to 40 acres of donated land. You will be able to stay there for a weekend or a whole week for self-cultivation or join in kung fu camp programs.

With your help we will arguably have the largest Shaolin and kung fu establishment in the downtown Toronto area if not the entire city!

The initial investment cost is quite significant and at this time I am seeking financial assistance to ease cash flow as well help further renovations and allow better facilities. My target is to raise $30K by July 1st, 2015. There are many ways that you can help and I encourage you to participate in the future and success of our community.

Yours Truly,

Shi Chang Dao

35th Generation Shaolin Disciple

The vision of the layout will include an extra large training area, a large training area, and several washrooms.  We will expand our programs in the future to offer pre-shool classes, more childrens classes, classes simultaneously for parents and children in separate rooms, beginner, intermediate, and advanced martial arts kung fu classes, meditation and Ch’an workshops, tai ji yang and chen styles, pregnancy exercise programs, public events, and more!  A high capacity ventilation system ensures a well controlled and healthy air environment.The new space will also include the first Shaolin Tea Cafe in Canada, offering a unique and peaceful  place for people to sit down and enjoy high quality tea and snacks while enjoying the energy of the environment.  This is an important strategic venture as it will become a stronghold for traditional Shaolin culture in Canada and a basis for growth and expansion.  It is my extended vision in support of my Shi Fu’s vision, which is to help people and communities through the traditional Shaolin arts.  I want this space to be a place that you will continue to be proud of.  The profits will be used for projects to help children, adults and seniors in need; the deaf, the blind, the poor, and those with other disabilities.  Profits will also be used to build the first Shaolin Retreat Centre at Rice Lake where we already have access to 40 acres of donated land.  You will be able to stay there for a weekend or a whole week for self-cultivation or join in kung fu camp programs.With your help we will arguably have the largest Shaolin and kung fu establishment in the downtown Toronto area if not the entire city!The initial investment cost is quite significant and at this time I am seeking financial assistance to ease cash flow as well help further renovations and allow better facilities.  My target is to raise $30K by July 1st, 2015.  There are many ways that you can help and I encourage you to participate in the future and success of our community.Yours Truly,Shi Chang Dao35th Generation Shaolin Disciple

story:
Why We Are Doing This

Our plan is to open the very first democratic school in Lithuania. It will also be the first in the whole of Eastern Europe.

Our belief is that the current education system in Lithuania is not working in the way it should be. In 2013 UNICEF published their study titled: ‘Child’s welfare in rich countries. A comparative review’ which placed Lithuania in 27th position out of 29 countries in the field of quality of eduaction. We see the main failure of our education system being the lack of focus on the needs of the students. 

We believe that students should not feel like the least important people in their school. Schools are created for them and because of them. The absence of respect for children, the absence of listening to children, and the general lack of communication have created an environment in which children do not feel motivated to learn. The current education system is outdated, inflexible, and many things have not changed since the Soviet times. Schools are incapable of adapting to different children, different learning styles and different paces of development. 


Mission of Our School

Having visited and seen examples from other democratic schools in other countries, we have been inspired to open a democratic school in Lithuania (Demokratinė mokykla).

The mission of this school is to provide possibilities for every child to feel important, and to be heard, i.e. we aim to:

·  involve them in decision-making

·  allow them to choose the education content and form that satisfy their needs

·  create conditions which will support the achievement of the best academic results. 


Our Team

We are excited, enthusiastic and fully committed to our mission. This is being further reinforced by seeing how many people here in Lithuania care about changing the current system. For now we have a great team working on publicity here in Lithuania, and we are being supported by experts from democratic schools in the UK - Summerhill and Sands School - who are helping us with creating the educational content. We also have teachers who are open-minded and enthusiastic about this form of teaching. We already have parents who trust in the system of democratic education, and in us. And most importantly, we already have children who are ready and willing to join our school!


HELP US TO MAKE IT HAPPEN!

What we need right now is YOUR help to make the school ready for the students. We have found a public school which is surrounded by an amazing forest. It will provide a place where children will be able to run and play freely, where they will be able to have their tree-house or a little garden in which they can grow whatever they want. Our challenge is that the school is old and in great need of renovation.Here are some pictures of how it looks right now.

                  

Our Budget

The renovation of the school will cost $ 158,850. This includes a range of work including replacing windows, renovating toilets, renovating the classrooms, changing the old furniture and creating the outdoors space. The budget also includes salaries for the workers and the materials.

Where We Are Now

We already have:

·  $ 16900 from winning an award from the organisation: Reach for Change

·  $ 22350 support provided by Sėkmės mokykla

Our hope is to raise an additional $35 000 through crowdfunding. This will take our total fund to 46% of the whole amount required to complete the renovation project. We hope to get the rest of the amount from business partners and/or private investors.


      

Our Thank You

 

$10

We love you

No doubts, you are one of us now! Thank you for helping us to dream big.

$20

Digital thank you

We will email you our team photo with your name on it. Even if digital – this thank you is so much real!

$50

Hand made post card

Hand made – heart made! You will get a personal post card and thank you note from one of our students. It‘s special because you make us feel that way!

$100

Branded tote bag

We know it‘s not for the  tote, but our „thanks“ is something natural + practical + fashionable and Lithuanian! Hope it makes your day brighter.

$500

Wall of Heroes

We will share your favorite quote/motto with your name on our School's sponsor wall. Everyone has their own heroe, you will be one for somebody!

$10000

Unseen Lithuania!

That big investment in education says a lot about your heart & soul. We definitely want to meet you!! We offer a special 7 day visit program, guidance & accommodation in a 4 star boutique hotel (flight and catering not included). P.S. Even if you are local – be ready for an alternative tourist track ;)

We are grateful for every donation!!!

story:
Dusty Feet is a project started by Dr. Dirk Redman and his wife Christina Redman in Namibia, where they live in a area of great imbalance. Dr. Dirk Redman is a born and raised Namibian and Christina Redman is a Swedish citizen who has lived in the Namib Desert for 5 years now.

In Namibia, wealthy people live in close proximity to super poor communities. Our aim is to help in the communities wherever we can.

Our main projects focus on feeding and education of very poor children, as well as access to health care. We also aim to create awareness in the wealthier community and get everyone involved in helping where they can.

  • Feeding underpriviliged children:
Our feeding projects function by collecting food from individual donors, restaurants and by collecting funds to support existing Soup Kitchens throughout the poor community.

  • Education:
Education Projects currently are focusing on building, supplying and supporting Community Day Care Centers throughout the informal settlements, who look after pre-school children and feed/educate them, while their parents are out working/looking for work.

  • Access to Medical Care:
Dr. Dirk Redman is a local G.P and works in private practice. He helps the local community who struggle to get health care from the overloaded government clinics. He helps them with free consultations and medicine, working together with government clinics to help seriously ill patients and by raising funds to pay for specialized treatment for underprivileged children, such as physiotherapy, Occupational therapy, X-rays, Surgery, Hearing and vision testing etc.

We are having local fund raising events and collection points for people from Swakopmund, Namibia to donate and get involved. Obviously the more funding we get, the more we can do. Therefore we are reaching out on crowdfunding sites to increase our donations. 

Our current project involves building one such Community Day Care Center and stocking up two existing centers with furniture and educational material as well as clothes for as many children as possible. For this we currently need USD 5000. 
This will go towards buying building material, toys and educational material. The centre that we are helping to build is very rudimentary and mostly built from poles and hardboard.
The children of the existing Centers just sit in the sand with no books or crayons to stimulate their imagination. This is also where we got the name for our project. All those little bare feet in the Namib Desert sand makes for very "Dusty Feet".
Even if we don't reach our goal of USD 5000 here, every cent donated will go towards buying what we can for the children. We are also raising funds elsewhere. We never take a cent for fuel, phone or personal costs. We donate our time and personal resources with love!

Our project has been doing very well so far and we are creating a lot of local awareness with local businesses and individuals getting involved.  We are extremely grateful for all the help so far and cannot thank you enough for your involvement!
Check out our Facebook page for some previous and current projects and photos! Dusty Feet:
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Dusty-Feet/15044...

story:
Short Summary

Jazz Walk of Fame, Inc., (JWOF) a non-profit 501 (C) (3) doing business since 2008, supports the development of the total individual students interested in music being an intrical part of their life or a career in the music industry.

We’re commencing our “Second Phase Educational Initiative Master Syllabus” that will provide superior musical instruction by professional musicians. Other caring professionals will cover jazz history through video, music business, life skills and self-esteem instruction.  Every student deserves a well-rounded education experience, one that includes an introduction to the rudiments of Jazz music.

I am Kyle S. Jackson, Founder and President of Jazz Walk of Fame Inc. and it has been my vision and mission to restore the noble sound of Jazz to its rightful position as America’s music, our only true American Art-form. Jazz music’s disciplined course of study can provide the catalyst and the impetuous to improve learning and development in all areas of academia. A generation ago, music and the arts were mandatory in all schools. Today, because of budget cuts and indifference thousands of students have no musical education at all.  JWOF will fill that void and be the stabilizer to add to the student’s total educational needs. Let JWOF be the conduit to inspire and channel students to their fullest potential.

Jazz Walk of Fame developed a curriculum that motivates student’s creativity in a series of training activities in music, theater and dance. The students will be instructed to develop their own musical theater productions as a result. Therefore, we would like to introduce, The JWOF Fundamental Preparatory Liberal Arts Institution to commence in the fall of 2015.

Jazz Walk of fame is in need of $85,000 which will be used to startup the Jazz Walk of Fame Fundamental Preparatory Liberal Arts Institution and  will be broken down as follows:

  • New Instruments     $10,000
  • Rent                              $30,000 annually
  • (5) Instructors          $16,200 annually
  • (7) Mang./Admin     $25,300 annually
  • Miscellaneous           $3,500

We will offer this program to students in grades 7th to 12th. Students that don’t have liberal arts programs at their school are eligible to enroll. The program is designed as to grade level of learning, but they are not restricted to their level of experience.

He or she could be the next Miles Davis or Sarah Vaughn. 

All Contributions are tax deductible.

In the event our goal is not attained the funding attained will go towards a building fund for the conservatory. JWOF currently does not own a building.  The budget as is only allows us to rent a space for the conservatory.

The Impact

There are other music, theater, dance and production programs listed in Houston. However, these are structured as departments instead of a curriculum. Combining the experience as a curriculum will give a pupil an opportunity to study hands-on industry training in a full musical theater production.

JWOF produced a program to cover the need of fine art within the community(s) and can be tailored to the need of students without the full states education restrictions. The services are the fine arts dimensions of a normal professional career.

The after school program will provide a series of technical skills and inner personal skills. This is a student-ran project with guidance from professional or paraprofessionals in the Houston area. The emphasis is on the student to build relationships between each other and explore their creative ability to develop a hard working show/production.

During 2013 thru 2014 JWOF partnered with Change Happens and successfully ran an after school program which was a mini model of the conservatory.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the risks and challenges we may face on our way to attaining our goal are as follows:

  • not attaining adequate funding
  • not having enough students .

JWOF plans to overcome these hurdles by using social media to attain our goals. We have experienced instructors and a proven track record.

     Other Ways You Can Help
 If you cannot contribute monetary wise we are asking that you please make some noise on behalf of our campaign and let people know of this worthy cause.  Please  use the Indiegogo shared tools  provided on this site to help us get the word out.  In addition you may contact us and volunteer your time.

"Can you imagine a Life without Jazz?”

story:
UPDATE April 10, 2015

We have raised up to $395 dollars in 8 days! Thanks so much! We are at 20% of our goal. It may not seem like much, but it actually is! Thanks to all the 15 contributors. This is truly making a difference. We just need 160 folks to donate $10 to reach the goal in time! I am really appreciative! 

UPDATE    April 7, 2015

Thank you so much to the 7 people who have contributed! That only leaves us $1860 dollars to go! If 186 people decide to donate $10 each, we will reach the goal! Thank you!

Short Summary

Hello,

My name is Maleny and I am fundraising to PAY OFF DEBT! 

In the past 5 months of my pregnancy, I have made it a goal to pay off all my debt. Thus, I can start the new chapter of my life with out living paycheck to paycheck.

Since November of 2014, I have knocked out 6 debts! Woot! Yet, a few weeks ago I was just notified that I owe another $1725 to Great Lakes Christian College. Which, really puts a set back on things. If you could help me out, that would be much appreciated! 


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

I am hoping that wonderful friends and strangers will give whatever they can to reach $1725 by the end of May of 2015. There are 4 weeks in each month. So, if we divide 2000 by 8, that would mean that 250 would have to be raised each week.

Another way to look at it would be if 200 people decided to pitch in $10. Do not worry! I too will be doing whatever I can to reduce the cost! 

I know that we can reach our goal by late May! We got this! 


The Impact

The $1725 will leave me debt free and will also give me the opportunity to live my life to the fullest.

I am done with feeling weak, overwhelmed and tired with giving money to these institutions.

You will take this weight of my shoulders and give me a second chance to start things out with ease and possibilities to focus on my schooling, getting a car and housing. 


Risks & Challenges

If I do not pay the amount by May, then it will be handed to collections and drastically affect my credit report.
I will have to work everyday just to pay back the $1725, with out having the freedom to truly focus on my pregnancy, plans postpartum and live independently. 
You do not risk anything by helping a friend out! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Getting the word out will be very helpful!

Sending me comments of encouragement!

Informing me of other resources that could help with this fundraiser!

We can do this together!

story:
Introduction

I have been accepted for a PhD placement at the University of Leeds next year, which is home to the Centre for Ethnic and Racism Studies. I will be under the supervision of the inspirational Dr. Shirley Tate. My research is called ‘Black British and Mixed Race identity: The intersectionality between race, class and political affiliation’. I wish to explore this area of study through trying to understand why we have simultaneously seen a rise in the activity of black liberationist groups in the UK, and the largest number of Black Minority Ethnic (BME) people voting for the Conservative party in the 2015 election. This opportunity is very exciting for me, but the cost of part time tuition fees for the first 2 years at the University of Leeds is £4750, well out of the financial reach of  myself and my family. However, I believe that my research is of real value to the black and left wing community, and projects such as mine are where we should invest our support if we wish to create material changes and narratives that support the world we envisage.  

Project in brief 

  • This research looks  at black identity through the simultaneous growth of black liberation politics and BME people voting for the Conservative party. 
  • This research hopes to promote public academia  that produces knowledge that can be understood by more people and used in a democratic way to mobilise people against contemporary issues like racism. 
  •  To promote crowdfunding as a means to create a better world by investing in economic activity and narratives that support our values rather than investing our money and time in systems that oppress us.

Research  

Rationale

At a social gathering just prior to Jeremy Corbyn’s first overwhelming mandate to lead the Labour Party, I was chatting to my friend about what Corbyn’s victory could mean for a resurrection of left wing politics in the United Kingdom. Before I could reach my conclusion I was interrupted by a girl of the same mixed British/ Caribbean heritage as me. “Oh you’re a bounty, black on the outside, white on the inside” she interjected. For her perhaps, it was not the place of black people to talk about politics, or maybe like myself and many black radicals she was disillusioned with the parliamentary system, I fear it was the former. I thought short and brief about my response ‘Fuck you!’ I drunkenly replied. At first I felt angry at her for policing my identity, but this soon disappeared into sympathy, her analyses of me was a reflection of how larger social structures place whiteness and blackness in a binary.  ‘Fuck you’ was my rejection to societies idea that places blackness outside of the intellectual life of politics and inside the stereotype of “tom-toms, cannibalism, intellectual deficiency, fetishism, racial defects, slave-ships” (Fanon, 1952 [2008]:92).  I want to provide a more academic answer to society's white/black binary than ‘fuck you’.

For myself politics is inseparable from the social construction of blackness. Black liberationist and anti-fascist groups have fought for the inclusion of BME people in the public sphere in countries such as the United Kingdom, where even today the facts suggest a disproportionate amount of BME people exist economically and culturally at the peripheries of society. We have seen a rise in the action and coverage of black liberationist groups in the wider public domain with the creation of groups like Black Lives Matter, which have reawakened the political discourses of the civil rights movement. Following global trends, the United Kingdom has seen groups rallying against the violence of the state against black bodies, the gentrification and destruction of ethnic minority communities and the coloniality of education. Simultaneously, we have seen a rise in BME conservatism with the Conservative party getting over 1 million BME votes, the largest it has ever achieved (Survation, 2015).  This Conservative victory came despite numerous displays of racism within the Tory Party (Smith, 2016), and the disproportionately negative effect of Tory austerity on the ethnic minority/ ‘Black’ community (Runnymede Trust, 2015). Some commentators have even had the temerity to suggest that Black conservatism is a sign Britain is a ‘post-racial society’, due to a ‘normalisation of the black presence in Britain’ (Goodhart, 2011). This research hopes to answer three key questions in order to understand how the BME community can better mobilise itself from the peripheries of society to the centre.  

Research questions

1. What is the relationship between race, class and political affiliation in the identity formation of people of black and mixed race heritage?

2. How do people of mixed race heritage negotiate these aspects of identity and in particular the intersections of blackness and whiteness in their own identities?

3. What are the assumptions behind individuals being perceived as ‘race traitors’?

Methodology

This research is dedicated to producing knowledge that is public and decolonised, what I mean by this is that I shall reject the academic snobbery and elitism of most work produced in the ivory towers of the university and instead opt for an approach of producing knowledge that is more participatory. My research respondents will be given greater agency and the results will be more open to being understood by wider sections of the public. To understand what it means to be black and mixed race in contemporary Britain, I will be have three main cohorts of participants: members of black liberationist groups, BME Conservative voters and Mixed Race people. I will use three methods to investigate my key questions:

Semi-Structured interviews: Using a Critical Race Theorist (CRT) perspective I will use semi-structured interviews to understand the experience and knowledge of my participants. Using Kimberlé Crenshaw I will look at how the different social categories of race, class and political affiliation interact on multiple and often simultaneous levels to create identity, other categories like gender and sexuality will be explored. In the case of mixed race participants, a key focus will be on which particular aspect of their experiences they identify themselves or perceive others to associate as either blackness or whiteness. Once the research has started I will allow my participants to label themselves. I will then use thematic and discourse analysis to analyse the interview transcripts across the three participant cohorts, focusing on identifying which ideas around what it means to be black are stable and contested. I will then show my analyses to my participants and give them a chance to respond to my analysis of their interview. By doing this I hope to avoid the academic trope of labelling communities in ways they disagree with and not providing them with any means of criticism.

Ethnography: I will use ethnography to study Black Liberationist Groups this means immersing myself in their meetings, protests and online activity. I hope to understand how these groups mobilise to solve issues they believe to be in the black interest. I wish to negotiate access to groups like Black Lives Matter UK, London Black Revolutionists and Black student groups. Ethnography as a research methodology has been utilised to study the inner workings of political organisations. It is anticipated that this ethnographic fieldwork will develop insight into how these groups can better mobilise to oppose racism.

Open question/ Open 'creative' response: This will achieve greater equality between the power of myself the researcher and my participants by asking the participants to respond in any way they wish to the question: ‘What does it mean to be black (or however they identify) in Britain today?’. Knowledge can be produced in multiple pluriversal ways, yet Eurocentric academia prioritises essays written by academics/ experts. Black culture has used various vernacular art forms to express knowledge about Black experience from poets like Linton Kwesi Johnson and Dean Atta, to Grime and Rap Artists like Akala and Dizzee Rascal. My open question will allow my participants to respond in any way they wish. The knowledge produced by the open question will be open to wider audiences. The creative responses of my participants will be displayed online.

 

Research Impact 

I hope that my research will help to achieve three things: 

1)From the ethnography of the black liberationist groups I wish to provide an analysis on how best these groups can mobilise the black community into a unified struggle against racism and its consequence. 

2)  I want to start a discussion on black identity through the research website where the public can submit their own creative expression of what it means to be black. I hope through this website people can share experience and understand the broad nature of black identity and the need for solidarity against common issues. 

3) I hope that this research will encourage more people from communities that exist at the  peripheries of society to invest and start small projects that challenge inequality. 

lastly, I hope this research will promote research values. 

My research values 

1: A rejection of the neo-liberal marketisation of education  

 At the same time as the government initiative 'Widening Participation' encourages more students from under-represented groups to go to university; there have been changes such as the increase of tuition fees to £9000 (of which I was in the first cohort of students to pay), and the abolition of student maintenance grants (from which I benefited immensely). These changes have left poorer students leaving university in huge amounts of individual debt, and disincentivised state school students from going to university. The marketisation of higher education entrenches social class immobility. Education is a social good and therefore shouldn’t depend on the wealth of a young person’s parents. Consequently, I believe that communities from under-represented groups should crowdfund academics and knowledge that will be empowering to the community and a challenge to the narratives of neoliberalism which creates social stagnation. The more individuals from minority groups we can get into institutions the more power we will have to change institutions from the inside for the benefit of all.  We have to be responsible and invest in economic activity and create narratives that challenge the status quo.

2: The production of a public sociology

This research will be a piece of public sociology; this is sociological knowledge that is created for wider non-academic communities. Too many academics write about important contemporary issues in a way that can only be understood by audiences within the ivory towers of the university. This means knowledge produced by the university is usually of no practical use to the communities that it is concerned with. This means only experts have the knowledge to make decisions, which could be made more democratically by the mobilisation of a well-informed community. This research will produce multiple forms of knowledge that can be digested by different communities in the forms of layman language, explanations of technical terms and the production of creative works by the researches participants. My goal is to become a public academic and produce knowledge that is:

  • owned by the public
  • understood by the public
  • practical in solving contemporary problems relevant to the public

3: The decolonisation of knowledge

As you will see in my research proposal I will decolonise my research process by producing pluriversal forms of knowledge. This means I am attempting to redress the unbalanced power dynamic between myself the researcher and the research respondents. Respondents will be able to identify themselves and everything written about them will be in layman language so that they can respond if they believe they have unfairly represented. Crowdfunding BME students also provides more routes into the academic profession in which they are highly unrepresented. Lack of BME staff means that BME students rarely see role models from their own communities and therefore the academy doesn't seem like their place. More BME staff would help to propel changes to university curriculums that are Eurocentric and ignore the contributions of non- white academics.     

Supporting my research 

I'm looking for people who are energised by my values to donate whatever they can afford. I would like this be part of a mass people movement in which lots of people invest small amounts of money in order to plant the seeds for a more equal and fair world. If you aren't in a position to contribute financially I would really appreciate if you could help me share my project. If you have any advice on how I could better share my project please don't hesitate to send me an email: jamallangley11@gmail.com  

THANK YOU!!
story_txt:
Introduction
I have been accepted for a PhD placement at the University of Leeds next year, which is home to the Centre for Ethnic and Racism Studies. I will be under the supervision of the inspirational Dr. Shirley Tate. My research is called ‘Black British and Mixed Race identity: The intersectionality between race, class and political affiliation’. I wish to explore this area of study through trying to understand why we have simultaneously seen a rise in the activity of black liberationist groups in the UK, and the largest number of Black Minority Ethnic (BME) people voting for the Conservative party in the 2015 election. This opportunity is very exciting for me, but the cost of part time tuition fees for the first 2 years at the University of Leeds is £4750, well out of the financial reach of  myself and my family. However, I believe that my research is of real value to the black and left wing community, and projects such as mine are where we should invest our support if we wish to create material changes and narratives that support the world we envisage.  

Project in brief 

This research looks  at black identity through the simultaneous growth of black liberation politics and BME people voting for the Conservative party. 
This research hopes to promote public academia  that produces knowledge that can be understood by more people and used in a democratic way to mobilise people against contemporary issues like racism. 
 To promote crowdfunding as a means to create a better world by investing in economic activity and narratives that support our values rather than investing our money and time in systems that oppress us.

Research  
Rationale
At a social gathering just prior to Jeremy Corbyn’s first overwhelming mandate to lead the Labour Party, I was chatting to my friend about what Corbyn’s victory could mean for a resurrection of left wing politics in the United Kingdom. Before I could reach my conclusion I was interrupted by a girl of the same mixed British/ Caribbean heritage as me. “Oh you’re a bounty, black on the outside, white on the inside” she interjected. This research hopes to answer three key questions in order to understand how the BME community can better mobilise itself from the peripheries of society to the centre.  
Research questions
1. What is the relationship between race, class and political affiliation in the identity formation of people of black and mixed race heritage?
2. How do people of mixed race heritage negotiate these aspects of identity and in particular the intersections of blackness and whiteness in their own identities?
3. What are the assumptions behind individuals being perceived as ‘race traitors’?

This research is dedicated to producing knowledge that is public and decolonised, what I mean by this is that I shall reject the academic snobbery and elitism of most work produced in the ivory towers of the university and instead opt for an approach of producing knowledge that is more participatory. I hope to understand how these groups mobilise to solve issues they believe to be in the black interest. I wish to negotiate access to groups like Black Lives Matter UK, London Black Revolutionists and Black student groups. story:
The Project


Over the years we have continuously improved our concept, creating new treatments, produces our own cosmetics line Ligne Saint Claire. Now we have formed a very competent team last year, which may teach the secrets and subtleties of cosmetics in three languages. This is unique in this business. We want to use our potential in its full depth and size. We will offer our special trainee program also unique. Cosmetic is our passion, teaching students our motivation. To create a perfumery and beautysalon is our great desire.
Two times per year we teach 4 people "pro bono" and give them the opportunity to learn one of the best professions in the world.


 

A personalized learning resource for all ages and nationalities

We teach our students only in private lessons, this which guarantees the full attention of teachers and students and promotes the intensity of training. Our E.P.I. (effective, professional and intensive) teaching method is unique. 
 




The cosmetic professionals can be roughly divided into 2 areas “care and beautification” and “health and wellness” divided. Both areas are facing enormous challenges because of the shortage of skilled workers does not stop in front of the cosmetics industry. Professional cosmetologists, massage therapists, SPA therapists and SPA managers are urgently needed- and this in the whole world.

story:
Quien es "chilo".

 

La verdad no sé porque me dicen así, desde muy niño y no me molesta. Soy huerfano desde los 11 años de padre y madre y nunca se me ocurrió preguntar el porque de mi apodo.

Amante de las motos desde niño, pero más desde que a los 8 años pasó por mi lado un "tipo" disfrazado de "astronauta" y me saludo con su mirada. Desde ahí quede enamorado del enduro, a los 26 años competí por primera y me gustó. Campeón nacional RALLY 2007 y 2011, dos ISDE 2007 Chile (finisher), 2010 México (medalla bronce).

Para mi es muy importante este proyecto porque alienta a futuras generaciones a luchar por los sueños. Me gusta transmitir mis conocimientos para que a los pilotos no les pasen las "novatadas" que me pasaron a mi aprendiendo en el RALLY DAKAR

Que lograría yo al estar de nuevo en el DAKAR?

  1. Llevar con orgullo la bandera colombiana.
  2. Ser ejemplo para futuras generaciones.

 

FINANCIAMIENTO:

El rally DAKAR no sólo es el evento más seguido por millones de personas en el mundo, es peligroso y aventurero, también es el más costoso.

La solo inscripción cuenta $14.800 euros y la participación total, sin entrenamientos ni competencias cuesta alrededor de 75.000 euros.

  •  Si tu me apoyar el dinero irá directamente a una cuenta de UN CLUB DE MOTOCICLISMO, donde luego será girada EXCLUSIVAMENTE para pagos de MECANICOS Y ASISTENCIA EN CARRERA.
  •  
  • Si tu me apoyas te nombraré en mis redes sociales con más de 40 mil seguidores como sponsor, si eres empresario y quieres hacer publicidad podría mandarte mi presentación. El patrocinio deportivo también incluye que te entregue un CERTIFICADO DE DONACION.

Quiero contar con tu apoyo para llegar mejor preparado a este magno evento.

Si no logro recaudar el dinero por este medio del crowfounding mi obligación es recaudarlo por todos los medios para llegar al RALLY DAKAR. NO TENGO COMO OPCIÓN NO IR!!!

Por eso dicto cursos de offroad, enduro, dicto charlas motivacionales en empresas privadas, hago travesías en moto, vendo camisetas, gorras, calcomanías. 

 

 

 

 

El impacto

 

Este año será importante para mi participación POR QUÉ? Porque no hay marcas gigantes apoyandome, el proyecto será de los colombianos y de los amigos que estan aportando su grano de arena para ir a competir en el DAKAR. 

Recuerda que el deporte significa entrega, compromiso, humildad, superación. Mi obligación como atleta es que los niños capten esto y lo lleven a sus vidas.

Cuando era niño quería ser odontologo pero la violencia me quitó esa posibilidad. He demostrado que sin hacerle daño a nadie y con mucha dedicación cualquier persona puede lograr sus sueños sin ser millonario. 

  

De que otra forma me puedes ayudar sino tienes dinero?

Comparte mi información de esta campaña, hay mucha gente alrededor del mundo que me podría ayudar.

También puedes darle ME GUSTA  mis publicaciones en redes sociales y compartirlas, eso hace que las estadísticas suban y lo verán las empresas que me apoyan o que me quieran apoyar.

Puedes comprar mis productos, o comentarle a tus amigos de lo que yo hago.

Comparte mi información de esta campaña, hay mucha gente alrededor del mundo que me podría ayudar.
También puedes darle ME GUSTA  mis publicaciones en redes sociales y compartirlas, eso hace que las estadísticas suban y lo verán las empresas que me apoyan o que me quieran apoyar.
Puedes comprar mis productos, o comentarle a tus amigos de lo que yo hago.

story:
Hi there,

My name's Roberta Verdant. I'm a freelance writer and workshop facilitator. I believe in the de-stigmatisation of death and dying, and that dying and grieving people need more support of every kind. I want to help dying people to have the best deaths possible. This'll involve training as both a Soul Midwife - a companion to dying people - and as a psychopomp (a soul guide to the dying).  

I see this as a challenging, important, and profoundly beautiful service to provide for a largely death negative world. Here's a blogpost from me at The Huffington Post about it.

Why I'm drawn to working with death

My pull towards this path is threefold: personal, spiritual and social. These elements cross over.

I can't remember a time in my life when I wasn't aware of grief, and the hidden/secret quality death often commands in our world. Though I have lost people I love, those weren’t my first experiences of grief.  

I am a third generation descendant of Holocaust survivors. 40 of my ancestors were decimated by the Nazis. There were few survivors on that side of my family, but I have known several of them, to varying degrees: my grandmother, great aunts and great grandmother, all of whom survived concentration camps. Many years after her time in Auschwitz, my grandmother is now 92 years old.

I always loosely knew this part of my family's history, and grew up acutely aware of grief which wasn’t being communicated. At some point in my childhood, my grandmother first began to tell stories about that time. There were also stories never detailed to me, which I would later piece together.

As an adult, I've undertaken a vast amount of work to provide space for some of these stories. I've also weathered years of chronic physical illness, and found a lot of peace with my own mortality.

These various aspects of my experience have fed my conviction that we need space for our most difficult stories around death and dying - and for grief itself. Dying people need more care, support and companionship. Soul Midwives' training (followed by voluntary ‘sitting with the dying’) will teach me how to safely offer that.

I feel that within any community, people need to be supporting one another at every stage, in myriad ways. In my training, I’ll learn both holistic and practical methods of offering assistance to dying people, e.g. helping them to plan for their deaths.

I'm self-aware, boundaried, open and non-judgmental. I can't think of any more positive action I'd like to enact in this world than to go into communities and help support the dying. I'm also a Pagan, so dedicated to the practise of earth/nature spirituality. I believe in keeping my spirituality socially engaged. Companionship to the dying is (in part) my offering in those terms.

My Pagan path has always been partially a Shamanic one. Training in the role of psychopomp (a soul guide to the dying) feeds into this, and will serve as complementary to my study in Soul Midwifery.

Through training and volunteering, I envisage creating a metaphorical toolbag – but in order to do this, I need your help. My income as a writer isn’t high. Until recently, I had been housesitting almost full-time for several months, which means I've been able to keep many of my practical expenses low. However, I currently lack the funds necessary to start my training.

If you're able to financially contribute, I'm offering various rewards. 

Rewards

One, two or four letters from my journey

I'll keep you informed of my progress as I undertake my journey to work with the dying, in the form of receiving one, two, or three letters. (Obviously, I'll never disclose confidential information within these). You'll be able to both get a sense of what your contribution has helped fund, and follow me on my path.

One hour one-to-one Skype writing session

My background is as a workshop facilitator. I love facilitating writing workshops. So here, I'm offering guided writing sessions. These can either focus on a topic of your choice, or be writing sessions I'll create on the themes of death and dying. 

One hour one-to-one Skype conversation about death and dying

A conversation between the two of us on the themes of death/dying/mortality: these sessions aren't therapy, but offer non-judgmental time and space for you to share whatever you'd like on this theme.  

I write for you!

I'm a published author of prose, poetry and non-fiction, with a particular interest in rewriting fairy tales and mythology. So I'm offering to write for you. You provide a prompt (which we agree upon) and tell me whether you want me to write a story, poem, or rework a myth or fairy tale. I write it. It becomes your property (though please cite me as author!).

 

A breakdown of my costs

£227: to pay off the balance of my psychopomp training.

£70: for my Soul Midwifery introductory training. This is a mini-bursary which Felicity Warner, who runs the Soul Midwives school, has very kindly offered me.

£750: to cover my Soul Midwives’ practitioner training, level one.

£350: to cover accommodation for the training. 

£203: to cover travel expenses.

£85: to cover the 5% Indiegogo receives.

Total: £1,685

If I raise some funds but don't succeed in reaching my goal, I'll still be able to use any money raised towards my training. All contributions are most welcome. If you’re not able to financially contribute, sharing on my campaign (Indiegogo has helpful share tools), as well as telling others about the campaign and/or publicising it would be extremely helpful and much appreciated. 

Here's a little beauty surrounding death: Bristol's lovely Arnos Vale cemetery.
story_txt:
Hi there,
My name's Roberta Verdant. I'm a freelance writer and workshop facilitator. I believe in the de-stigmatisation of death and dying, and that dying and grieving people need more support of every kind. I want to help dying people to have the best deaths possible. This'll involve training as both a Soul Midwife - a companion to dying people - and as a psychopomp (a soul guide to the dying).  
I see this as a challenging, important, and profoundly beautiful service to provide for a largely death negative world. Here's a blogpost from me at The Huffington Post about it.
Why I'm drawn to working with death
My pull towards this path is threefold: personal, spiritual and social. These elements cross over.
I can't remember a time in my life when I wasn't aware of grief, and the hidden/secret quality death often commands in our world. Though I have lost people I love, those weren’t my first experiences of grief.  
I am a third generation descendant of Holocaust survivors. 40 of my ancestors were decimated by the Nazis. There were few survivors on that side of my family, but I have known several of them, to varying degrees: my grandmother, great aunts and great grandmother, all of whom survived concentration camps. Many years after her time in Auschwitz, my grandmother is now 92 years old.
I always loosely knew this part of my family's history, and grew up acutely aware of grief which wasn’t being communicated. At some point in my childhood, my grandmother first began to tell stories about that time. There were also stories never detailed to me, which I would later piece together.
As an adult, I've undertaken a vast amount of work to provide space for some of these stories. I've also weathered years of chronic physical illness, and found a lot of peace with my own mortality.
These various aspects of my experience have fed my conviction that we need space for our most difficult stories around death and dying - and for grief itself. story:
What is Let's Talk Equality?

Founded by two eighteen year old high school students, Let's Talk Equality is a project based on social entrepreneurship. Anna Hasselgren and Tilde Holm, founders of Let's Talk Equality and bloggers for Girls' Globe, wanted to expand the conversation about the current midwife crisis. White Ribbon Alliance is an incredible organisation that takes maternal health issues very seriously. They do amazing work in their Alert Villages, where the volunteers educate and help families realise the importance of maternal health. We need to support grassroots movements, just like the White Ribbon Alliance (WRA), to fight for things important to women and girls. Therefore, we will be visiting White Ribbon Alliance in Jakarta in February 2017, to document and produce a short documentary series in three parts, to be used to promote their work, raise awareness and inspire others to take action. The documentary films will include interviews with midwives, the head coordinator and also shoots from their Alert villages. 

We must do something about the midwife crisis. In Indonesia, only 73% of babies are born attended by skilled personnel. With a little help from you, we can inspire others to make a difference for mothers around the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We hope to raise 2000 dollars for this campaign. Through these contributions, we will be able to:

  • Create an inspiring documentary on the current health situation of mothers and babies in Indonesia.
  • Engage the work of White Ribbon Alliance Indonesia in the documentary, in order to expand the conversation on maternal health and grassroots movements.

By donating, you will empower the volunteers of the White Ribbon Alliance, help raise awareness of their important work and inspire others to take action for safe motherhood, and contribute for a better world for mothers and babies! And of course, check out our amazing perks!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone might not have the possibility to donate. Luckily, there are more ways to help:

  • Share our campaign! There are plenty of people in your network that would love getting engaged. Use the Indiegogo Share Tools to spread the word!
  • Follow Let's Talk Equality on Facebook and girlsglobe.org.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Impact

Climbing is a sport that teaches life skills that will benefit kids on an immeasurable scale, from the hard skills of knot tying, to the soft skills of encouraging a friend to get to that next hold and achieve that next level. It encourages relationship building, trust, mental and physical awareness, problem solving, fitness and of course fun and adventure!  Sadly in recent times, our community has been affected by youth suicides, drug addiction and overdose.  This programming can be used as a tool to create a proactive approach to our children, our community, mental health and wellness from a young age. Unfortunately to date our reactive approach has often come too late. This competition will allow us to introduce a large volume of kids to the sport of climbing, promoting leadership qualities, a healthy and active lifestyle while creating a positive culture of adventure in our community.    

About Us

Hoodoo Adventures:

Founded in 2007, Hoodoo Adventures provides quality outdoor adventures, Indoor Climbing and team events that truly highlight the best the Okanagan has to offer. Hoodoo Adventures has brought together some of the most energetic, personable and dedicated individuals in the industry. They have been selected for their passion, outstanding instructional skills, playful attitudes and their knowledge of safety management with a wide range of backgrounds, experience and qualifications.

In February 2016 Hoodoo Adventures expanded and built a climbing gym in the community of Penticton, a town world-renowned for its outdoor climbing. Since then the climbing gym has been providing exceptional climbing programs for youth and adults alike, however due the high cost of the build the gym is not complete and their offerings have been limited.  

Lyndie Hill, the founder of Hoodoo Adventures, is passionate about getting kids active and away from their screens.  She has spent 15 years developing successful programs that engage youth in outdoor activities and invested countless hours in fundraising efforts with the goal that all the children in the community will have equal opportunity at outdoor education.  

YORS

Founded in May 2016, The Youth Outdoor Recreation Society (YORS) is devoted to providing opportunities for mainstream and at-risk youth in the Okanagan to participate in outdoor recreation, education and leadership activities by subsidizing programming within the community. These activities will provide a platform to help youth develop and nurture their physical, emotional and intellectual selves by enhancing their relationship with, and confidence in the natural environment.

Our Goal

YORS in partnership with Hoodoo Adventure Company wants to host a kids climbing competition. We believe that an open competition  will be a great way to encourage and engage youth in the sport of climbing. Indoor climbing is a great activity for youth during the winter months and helps to promote a healthy and active lifestyle, keeping them busy and away from those screens!  

What We Need

​ Our goal is to raise $10,000 which will be used to buy safety equipment and the supplies needed to host our climbing competition. Most of your contributions will be used to complete the safety/crash mats in the gym. Currently half of our gym has crash mats but we need to put them throughout the entire climbing area before we can have enough space to host a competition and full programming.

With the rest of the money we will purchase more kid friendly climbing holds and help subsidize school groups to come and try out the gym.  Given the small ratios of instructors to kids, climbing programs can be expensive, but this is also what makes them so unique and therapeutic.  In a classroom kids share their teachers with 25+ other children, when climbing kids have the opportunity to create a one on one bond/trust with their leader and their peers.  

If we don't reach our goal we will continue to raise the remainder of the money through special events and fundraisers. 

Perks

Donations over that are $1000 or more will receive a free year membership at the climbing gym.

Donations of $200 or more will receive a free 10 punch pass that can be shared with others.

Donations of $40 or more will receive 10% off their next visit to Hoodoo Adventures Climbing Gym.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word, share this link and help us reach our goal.

story:
Who We Are:

The ASA Restoration Project was established by Anthony Browder in 2008 and is named in honor of the distinguished and renowned educator, psychologist and historian Dr. Asa G. Hilliard, III. 

What We Do:

The primary mission of the ASA Restoration Project is to complete the excavation and restoration of two 2,700 year-old tombs located on the west bank of Luxor, Egypt near the Valley of the Kings and Queens.  The importance of this archeological and cultural work for Africans and African Americans is the direct connection to the history and legacy of the greatest people on earth.  Without a true and comprehensive understanding of the incredible ancestry of Black people, we remain lost and disconnected from our past which keeps us from fulfilling our ordained destiny.  So, everything in these tombs that is uncovered and restored is another critical piece of our history which serves as a reminder of who people of African ancestry are and our remarkable contributions to human civilization.

Historical & Cultural Significance:

Dr. Elena Pischikova, director of the South Asasif Conservation Project, discovered these ancient tombs in 2006. Her partnership with the ASA Restoration Project has resulted in discoveries that have shed light on one of the most overlooked periods in Egyptian history. The tombs were built to honor Karabasken and Karakhamen who lived during the 8th century B.C. They were the final resting place for two members of the Kushite royal family that ruled Egypt during the 25th dynasty. Both tombs were carved into the limestone bedrock and each has a staircase that descends 20 feet into the earth and terminates at a large open-air sun court. At the western end of the sun court is a subterranean tomb that consists of pillared halls that lead to a burial chamber.

We now know that Karabasken was the mayor of the ancient city of Luxor – the administrative and religious capital of ancient Egypt. Karabasken also supervised the restoration of the Temples of Luxor and Karnak, which are two miles apart but are connected by an avenue of 1350 sphinxes and were the site of spectacular annual festivals. 

We now know that Karakhamen was a priest at Karnak Temple, which is the largest temple in the world and the residence of Amen (the unseen presence of God Almighty). Karnak Temple is said to have housed over 83,000 priest and priestesses, while we don’t yet know the exact role Karakhamen played at Karnak, the size and grandeur of his tomb is an indicator his importance.

The tomb of Karakhamen is four times larger than the tomb of King Tut. Even though it was robbed of its treasures long ago, it contains a treasure trove of literary and architectural artifacts. Karakhamen’s tomb consists of two pillared halls inscribed with text from The Book of the Hours, The Book of the Dead and Pyramid Text. Every inch of his tomb was carefully carved with hundreds of lines of text and dozens of painted images. 

Karakhamen’s burial chamber is 60 feet underground and is accessed via a large shaft. Its walls are beautifully adorned with painted images of the “weighing of the soul” and the 42 judges of the deceased. The ceiling is painted with a wonderful image of Nut, the goddess who represents the Milky Way.

Why We Do It:

The reconstruction of Karakhamen’s tomb can only be fully appreciated when looking at before and after photos of our work. One of our most significant accomplishments was the reconstruction of the western wall and False Door at the end of the 2nd pillared hall. This wall depicts offerings to Karakhamen and Ausar and was constructed 40 feet above the burial chamber.

The speed with which the 2nd pillared hall was reconstructed was made possible by the generosity of Douglas Barnes who purchased a stone cutting machine for us in 2014. We will unveil the newly restored 2nd pillared hall on September 24, 2016 at a ribbon cutting ceremony with the Governor of Luxor, Minister of Antiquities and other dignitaries. 

In 2014 we began excavating in front of Karabasken’s tomb and uncovered a staircase that led to an impressive large open-air sun court that allowed us to directly access the underground tomb. We began excavating Karabasken’s burial chamber in June 2016 and we made one of our biggest discoveries to date. We uncovered a ramp that descended into the burial chamber at a steep 45˚ angle and found the burial chamber filled with flood debris. When the debris was removed weeks later we found the 2700 year-old surprise was patiently waiting for us for so many years. Protocol prevents me from revealing any more details until the Minister of Antiquities releases news of our discovery but believe me…it is huge!

Recent excavations of the superstructure surrounding both tombs revealed the ancient remains of pylons that were constructed at the entrance to the staircase, sun court and tomb. Since pylons were typically built at the entrances to temples, their presence now suggests that these tombs were originally built as Temple Tombs, similar to the ones built in ancient Kush.

How Your Investment Can Make A Difference:

Unfortunately, both tombs have been ravaged by man and nature since their construction. Over the centuries they have been used as a residence, stable and quarry by local residents. They have also been subjected to numerous floods that have covered them under millions of tons of debris. But thru the hard work of Dr. Pischikova, and the fundraising efforts of the ASA Restoration Project, we have been able to excavate and restore both tombs and slowly reconstruct the lives of Karabasken and Karakhamen.

Every year of excavation yields new discoveries that dramatically increase our understanding of the Kushite presence in ancient Egypt. The ASA Restoration Project is proud to be the first and only African American organization to fund excavations in Egypt and conduct primary research on the world’s oldest documented civilization.

We are grateful to the hundreds of people who have supported the work of the ASA Restoration Project through their generous contributions over the past eight years and we trust that the fruits of our labor have proven be a worthwhile investment. 

We have done good work, but we still have much more work to do. The transformative impact of our discoveries for people of African ancestry cannot be overstated, so your gift can be impactful not just for the study of history, but for Black youth, families and communities in America and the world. Our annual expenses for excavation and restoration have doubled since we are now working in two tombs and the value of fundraising has never been greater. This new crowd funding campaign represents our desire to reach a larger audience and secure new investments so that we may close our 2016 season with the resources to purchase tools and equipment for our 2017 season to accelerate our work and create new discoveries that further validate the unparalleded impact of Africans on the world.

We invite you to share the information below with your family, friends and associates, and we are offering the following premiums for your continued support of our work.

  • $50 — A 16x20 color poster of the Temple Tomb of Karakhamen
  • $75 — A Karakhamen T-Shirt (available in L thru 3X only)
  • $100 — A print or digital copy of Finding Karakhamun
  • $150 — DVD Report on the 2016 excavation season
  • $300 — 3D model of Karakhamen’s Temple Tomb and poster
  • $500 — A complete set of all of the premiums

Contributions By Check

If you prefer not to make online contributions to our current Crowdfunding Campaign and would rather pay by check. That is perfectly acceptable and we will honor your investment in the ASA Restoration Project by sending you a premium that corresponds to the level of your investment. We will also add your name on our website among the list of those who supported this campaign online.

Please make your checks payable to IKG CC and mail to:
IKG / 1816 12th Street, NW / Washington, DC 20009 

Be sure to visit www.ikg-info.com for information on study tours to Egypt, opportunities to participitate in excavations with the ASA Restoration Project, books, DVD’s and other products.

Thank you,

Anthony T. Browder
Director, ASA Restoration Project
www.asarestorationproject.com

One of our most significant accomplishments was the reconstruction of the western wall and False Door at the end of the 2nd pillared hall. This wall depicts offerings to Karakhamen and Ausar and was constructed 40 feet above the burial chamber.The speed with which the 2nd pillared hall was reconstructed was made possible by the generosity of Douglas Barnes who purchased a stone cutting machine for us in 2014. We will unveil the newly restored 2nd pillared hall on September 24, 2016 at a ribbon cutting ceremony with the Governor of Luxor, Minister of Antiquities and other dignitaries. In 2014 we began excavating in front of Karabasken’s tomb and uncovered a staircase that led to an impressive large open-air sun court that allowed us to directly access the underground tomb. We began excavating Karabasken’s burial chamber in June 2016 and we made one of our biggest discoveries to date. We uncovered a ramp that descended into the burial chamber at a steep 45˚ angle and found the burial chamber filled with flood debris. When the debris was removed weeks later we found the 2700 year-old surprise was patiently waiting for us for so many years. Protocol prevents me from revealing any more details until the Minister of Antiquities releases news of our discovery but believe me…it is huge!Recent excavations of the superstructure surrounding both tombs revealed the ancient remains of pylons that were constructed at the entrance to the staircase, sun court and tomb. Since pylons were typically built at the entrances to temples, their presence now suggests that these tombs were originally built as Temple Tombs, similar to the ones built in ancient Kush.How Your Investment Can Make A Difference:Unfortunately, both tombs have been ravaged by man and nature since their construction. Over the centuries they have been used as a residence, stable and quarry by local residents. They have also been subjected to numerous floods that have covered them under millions of tons of debris. But thru the hard work of Dr. Pischikova, and the fundraising efforts of the ASA Restoration Project, we have been able to excavate and restore both tombs and slowly reconstruct the lives of Karabasken and Karakhamen.Every year of excavation yields new discoveries that dramatically increase our understanding of the Kushite presence in ancient Egypt. The ASA Restoration Project is proud to be the first and only African American organization to fund excavations in Egypt and conduct primary research on the world’s oldest documented civilization.We are grateful to the hundreds of people who have supported the work of the ASA Restoration Project through their generous contributions over the past eight years and we trust that the fruits of our labor have proven be a worthwhile investment. We have done good work, but we still have much more work to do. The transformative impact of our discoveries for people of African ancestry cannot be overstated, so your gift can be impactful not just for the study of history, but for Black youth, families and communities in America and the world. Our annual expenses for excavation and restoration have doubled since we are now working in two tombs and the value of fundraising has never been greater. This new crowd funding campaign represents our desire to reach a larger audience and secure new investments so that we may close our 2016 season with the resources to purchase tools and equipment for our 2017 season to accelerate our work and create new discoveries that further validate the unparalleded impact of Africans on the world.We invite you to share the information below with your family, friends and associates, and we are offering the following premiums for your continued support of our work.
$50 — A 16x20 color poster of the Temple Tomb of Karakhamen
$75 — A Karakhamen T-Shirt (available in L thru 3X only)
$100 — A print or digital copy of Finding Karakhamun
$150 — DVD Report on the 2016 excavation season
$300 — 3D model of Karakhamen’s Temple Tomb and poster
$500 — A complete set of all of the premiums
Contributions By CheckIf you prefer not to make online contributions to our current Crowdfunding Campaign and would rather pay by check. That is perfectly acceptable and we will honor your investment in the ASA Restoration Project by sending you a premium that corresponds to the level of your investment. We will also add your name on our website among the list of those who supported this campaign online.Please make your checks payable to IKG CC and mail to:IKG / 1816 12th Street, NW / Washington, DC 20009 Be sure to visit www.ikg-info.com for information on study tours to Egypt, opportunities to participitate in excavations with the ASA Restoration Project, books, DVD’s and other products.Thank you,Anthony T. BrowderDirector, ASA Restoration Projectwww.asarestorationproject.com

story:
Who are we?

Helena River Steiner School is based in Western Australia in the beautiful city of Perth.  The idea for a Steiner school in this area began in 2013 and took shape as 'River Blossom Steiner Playgroup'. It has expanded steadily since then and now offers a 3-6 year old kindergarten program as well, prompting us to change our name to 'Helena River Steiner School' this year. We also run a craft group where parents can learn new skills whilst making toys for the school, as well as a study group where people can learn about the philosophies that underpin Steiner education.  Both groups are open to wider community.

Our school has expanded quickly and we need primary classrooms and resources to sustain the education of our children as they grow older. There are also families in the wider community with primary age children who are very keen to move to a Steiner school once we have a class to offer them. The next step for us is to expand our programs for a primary classroom and all the resources and equipment that will require - inside and outside the classroom. We are in the process of applying for school registration (which will attract some funding), however, it is a long process and until then we need all the help we can to get established.

Our Location

We are located in the very central suburb of Midland, just a two minute walk from the railway station, and within 1 km of the beautiful Helena River. We are the only school of any kind to be situated in Midland, so we provide a vital community service for families in this area. We have already secured the premises for our primary classroom which is right next door to our kindergarten and playgroup premises. We have families who are waiting to enrol their children in the primary classroom, which we will be offering this year. 

What makes Steiner education different?

Steiner schools have a child-focused learning program founded on principles of the healthy and holistic development of the child, and of moral and social responsibility. The primary years in a Steiner school are a shared journey. Children keep the same teacher from Class 1 to Class 6 so as to develop strong and caring relationships, and to build upon each child’s known strengths every year. There are very few discipline issues as the teacher knows the children so well.

The curriculum in a Steiner school is based on the developmental needs and stages of the child year by year, so that topics and skills are introduced at the right time to fully engage the curiosity and striving of the child. Steiner/Waldorf education is inherently steeped in the Arts, so that children often learn their core subjects through the artistic mediums of music, painting, crafts, woodwork and drama. Classes are small and children develop a sense of community service, which starts with care of their own school environment and extends through to their place in the wider world.

More information about the Steiner curriculum and method of teaching can be found at www.steinereducation.edu.au

What we need

We have been successful in establishing a Steiner kindergarten and playgroup that meets the needs of families in our community. These families now need a primary class so that children can continue with their learning in the Steiner method, whilst staying in their home community. We are a small school, currently running on a shoestring budget with the assistance of committed parents and teachers in the community. Our goal is to secure the funding to set up and run our first primary classroom to meet the growing needs of our families and children.

We are currently in the process of applying for school registration which we hope to achieve by next year. Once the school registration process is complete, we will be able to receive government funding to help us operate effectively as a school. We intend to build classrooms at the rear of the property as our primary enrolments grow.

Our Goals

We have a crowdfunding target of AUD35,000.

Teaching resources          $20,000

We need capital to support the children in their learning with resources such as lesson books, art and craft materials, musical instruments, woodworking equipment, library of books, chairs, blackboards, teaching resources for the teacher etc

Communications and marketing          $5,000

We require funds to help inform people in the wider community about the existence of our school and to inform people about what Steiner education is. We need to extend our communications and marketing of the school in order to increase enrolments of students.  

Primary playground equipment          $10,000

We have already built up a playgroup outside play area, and also a kindergarten play area. We have a large section of land that we wish to turn into a nature-based primary playground with play equipment, garden beds and a storage shed for woodworking and construction tools.

What next for our school?

We anticipate that the primary program at our school will expand year by year, as numbers increase and children progress in their learning. We aim to build further primary classrooms at the back of our premises to cater for this.The primary program extends to Year 6 and we also anticipate, in the future, to establish a secondary school!

Stretch Goals

We have big plans for our primary school this year so we have set up some stretch goals. We would like funds to finance the running costs of a marketing campaign for one year.  For this, we need to employ a communications officer on a part-time basis to work on community outreach and implement a marketing campaign.

Lastly, more inside and outside play toys, equipment and resouces would be hugely appreciated by our playgroup and kindergarten children.

Pass it on!

We strongly believe in the value of Steiner education in shaping and forming the healthy futures of our children. Please pass the message on to support our campaign! If you would like to help us in others ways (ie by donating resources, time or skills) please contact us.
